author: @Curious_Southerner
textdisplay: Grant, thank you for this beautiful video! I have a naive question: we stated that when the polarized light goes through the solution, certain wavelengths get rotated more than others. However, if we were to look at the end of the pole, we would still observe white light, indicating that the superposition is similar to the initial linearly polarized light. Is it expected or intuitive that the superposition of the income light that is in the same plane should be the same as the superposition of the wavelengths that are rotated and are in different planes? Sorry if it is a confusing question; I can clarify if needed.

author: @lunkel8108
textdisplay: The wavelengths will be polarized in different directions. But your eyes can't tell the difference between differently polarized light. The outgoing light is "similar" to the incoming light in that it contains the exact same wavelengths at (pretty much) the exact same amplitudes, so it looks the same to our eyes. That's all they measure.

author: @samculver8279
textdisplay:
I love the video, but Im skeptical about the explanation for the diagonal bands. In the graphic the viewer is shown very close to a very large tube, which makes up maybe 40 degrees of their field of view. This would correspond to a large change in perceived angle by the viewer, and would be a plausible explanation for the strips.

In the actual video though the tube is very small compared to the field of view of the camera, it maybe makes up a 3 or four degree angle for the field of view. This would correspond to an equally small change in perception of the direction the light is polarized, again maybe 3 or 4 degrees. (Comparing the top of the tube to the bottom in a vertical strip). Lets compare that to the visual evidence we see in the video.

We see the light go through nearly a full rotation as it travels through the length of the tube, meaning it changes its angle about 300-400 degrees along the full length of the tube. (for one wavelength of light, each wavelength having a unique total change in angle as we saw).

Just from eyeballing it, it looks like the bands of equal intensity light travel about a sixth to a quarter of the tube as they go from the top of the tube to the bottom. From my earlier aprox that would correspond to somewhere around a 50 degree change in perceived polarization angle from the top to the bottom, because our percieved polar angle is shifted this much as we go from the top to the bottom of a vertical slice. (and 50 is 1/6 of 350).

This is very wishy washy and just form me eyeballing the footage, and I could just have a critical error in my reasoning but that seems wayy to drastic of a difference, (a 50 degree visual approx to the 2-5 percent angle I think we would see just from perception reasons) Let me know if I am misunderstanding or f you think there might be more to this.

That said I have a degree in physics and this was a better explanation of light waves than I got my entire college study, love the channel and the vid.

author: @groseran
textdisplay:
joining to the previous commenters with admiration and gratitude for your amazing videos!
however...
I'm pretty sure your explanation about the X/Y asymmetry (where Z is in the direction parallel to the length of the tube ) is wrong.
your explanation doesn't actually explains any kind of broken symmetry along the perpendicular direction that wouldn't be symmetrical with regard to the (viewer * Z) plane. I currently cannot reproduce this experiment at home but I'll suspect one of the following:
1. liquid density/composition/impurities gradient - can be easily verified by agitating or mixing the solution, may cause a shift in the overall phase shift per unit Z
2. your first polarizer might be slightly shifted or damaged so that light getting into the tube with slightly different polarization along the Y axis
3. light source / optics - might cause light to be already polarized. please notice that if you use any type of semi crystalline material in your optical path such as polycarbonate or polystyrene, you might get quite string polarizations initially...
you can verify this easily by looking at a beam of light through your optics without any solution in the tube

author: @TheAzerty100000
textdisplay:
About the challenge question :
- Take any point A in the middle (vertically) of the tube. Observe the color at this point.
- Now if you look at the middle of the tube 10cm further, say point B, you dont get the same color because twisting happened.
- However, you can look for the same color you had at point A searching vertically from B.
- If you find the color you had on A above B, because we're looking at the tube from the left, it means the resulting vector has rotated left side, if you find this color beneath B, the vector rotated right.
Diagonal stripes "going down" here mean that we are in the second case. The resulting vector is rotating to the right side, meaning that left-handed light is more slowed down.

author: @groovyfan
textdisplay:
1) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ‚âà x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

2) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word ‚Äúphase space‚Äù to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. You should know, though, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the ‚Äúphase space‚Äù here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term ‚Äúconfiguration space‚Äù, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we do next video.

author: @johndoyle2347
textdisplay:
Proving the Riemann hypothesis: Moments after a Big Bang, dual numbers to be considered at the origin, repulsive and gravitational forces are balanced, but dark matter is breaking up. "Dual numbers?", you might ask. Isn't that the square root of zero? (Actually, it's a great way to start a proof that ends with division by zero - a vertical line, and corresponds to what I call Doyle's constant that deals with a brief window in time starting with taking the eth root of e and ending with a vertical line. Delanges sectrices for the unflaking of dark matter, Archimedean spiral for spinning up dark matter, Ceva sectrices for that dark matter breaking into smaller, primordial dark matter and black holes, Dinostratus quadratrix for impacting surrounding black holes, and Maclaurin sectrices for dark matter being slowed down over time. Split-complex at one, noting the more gravitational nature of diagonal ring/cylinder singularities of baryonic matter from broken dark matter. Using repetitious bisection (from arbitrary angle trisection), one gets added (SSA) for when dark matter dominates a universe and one gets added for when black holes and rarified singularities make things more gravitational, leading to a Big Crunch. At 2 = a Big Crunch, the solution to the Basel problem, and the "bellows method" drives things. A Big Crunch event needs the net gravity from the localized area AND gravitational effects from surrounding universes. The 2 represents how locked up black holes are making a stacking, planar contact. Everything else are harmonics - effects on surrounding universes.
I see this proof as like trying to climb a steep cliff with the process of dark matter breaking up, getting to the top of the hill (like stable atomic nuclei) and then skiing down the "hill of many black holes" past an inflection point where black hole formation and spaghettification happens, leading to the final vertical line tensor of the Maclaurin trisectrix. This is much like I have posted about considering the recursive form of Euler's Identity as being like an old incandescent light bulb that you can see having first, second, and third degree critical points.
Ramanujan's Infinite Sum of negative one-twelfth: each positional jostling, mass, and gravitational/attractive exchange between universes (defined by Big Bounce events, considering Ramanujan during both Big Crunch and Big Bang sides) ADDS up to evenness (or a partner in marriage - like half of the whole, I guess).
Net gravity increases over time from the breaking up of dark matter, much like a vertical asymptote. It continues to increase, but hits a critical point, much like a vertical tangent, when enough dark matter has weakened and been broken up into the more gravitational baryonic matter (split-complex numbers). Then, the effects of gravity reach their upper limit - much like a vertical line - at e to the negative e.
Over a decade ago, I said that the potential energy of a Big Bang was 1/6 times (the speed of light, cubed). If I had said Big Bounce instead, I would have been correct, in a sense.

author: @againstfasces5222
textdisplay:
You keep saying the tank tread thing isn‚Äôt helpful,
But it‚Äôs literally the same underlying phenomenon. Two parts of a whole approach on parallel paths at the same speed. One encounters a region that slows its progression first, and so the other one is able to catch up and close the distance, until it too is slowed. When the ‚Äúwhole‚Äù (either tank or light wave) is always propagating perpendicular to the line defined by these two parts, this implies a ‚Äúturn‚Äù or bend in trajectory.

I agree you can‚Äôt just tell someone the tank tread thing without additional details to explain how the principle applies in this case, but it‚Äôs one of the better physics analogies out there since the principle is in fact the same.

author: @davidgustavsson4000
textdisplay:
Hello! I've been stuck behind a couple of long video essays, so i know I'm late. I wrote this on the looking glass video too.

I'm a PhD student in atomic physics, studying the slow light effect which is when a sharp dispersion causes group (=pulse) velocities much slower than c. We can actually make the group velocity much faster than c too, and even negative. Just not simultaneously with a faster-than-c phase velocity. What matters to information transfer is not actually either the transfer of phase or the transfer of pulses, but the transfer of discontinuities in the electric field, and those travel at a third velocity, the information velocity, which is typically close to the lower of the two others.

author: @YodaWhat
textdisplay:
There have been examples of information being transmitted faster than c. One such example was shown on BBC TV and on the PBS science series NOVA (both in 1999), beginning at 32:33 in the episode called Time Travel, in which the German physicist G√ºnter Nimtz (born 22 September 1936) encoded Mozart 40 onto a microwave beam and placed the transmitter directly against a solid block of metal about 5.5 inches long (14 centimeters long). Out the opposite side of the block, greatly attenuated, came an easily recognizable rendition of Mozart 40... about one-half nanosecond sooner than it "should" have been able to.

In other words, some tiny fraction of the microwave photons had TUNNELLED through the solid metal, faster than light. In that example, Nimtz claimed "only" four point seven times c, because of his experimental limits on precision, but other experimenters have greatly exceed that rate. Within experimental limits, tunneling takes approximately ZERO TIME. Those experiments do not prove "time travel" but they do demonstrate FTL communication. So to all the dogmatists, there it is: QED!

I note that objections based on the notion of "causality violation" are an example of flawed logic. Such objections are not at all relevant, since causality violation is incorrectly assumed to result from anything going faster than c. While Special Relativity implies causality violation as a possibility of superluminal travel, there is nothing which says that it must result in causality violation.

That NOVA episode is available for viewing and/or downloading from The Wayback Machine (aka archive org) but I was not able to find it here on YouTube. You also can read much more about this in the Wikipedia article on G√ºnter Nimtz.
@3Blue1Brown

author: @Windprinc3
textdisplay:
I encountered a simple problem with a rather counterintuitive solution: of two manufacturing lines, one showed 20 defects from a random sample of 200 (10% defects). The other showed 25 defects from a random sample of 400 (6.25%). Yet, the proportions_ztest() function in Python says that there is no statistical difference, and consequently it is not worth the money to look into whether the two lines are different or to improve the one that has a higher percentage of defects. While I understand that the 2 different samples are random, and may just have these defect rates by accident, and that these rates are not indicative of the "population," it still seems counterintuitive. If you have the time, would you mind creating a video with a few of these seemingly counterintuitive results to emphasize the importance of statistics?

Thanks!

author: @3hustle
textdisplay:
üìä The video discusses the Galton Board and the Central Limit Theorem, which explains the common occurrence of the normal distribution in probability.
00:00
The Galton Board demonstrates how even chaotic and random events can have precise statements about the distribution of outcomes.
00:00
The Normal distribution, also known as a Bell curve, is a common distribution in probability.
00:27
The Central Limit Theorem is a key fact that explains the prevalence of the Normal distribution.
01:09
The video aims to provide the fundamentals of the Central Limit Theorem and normal distributions.
01:21
The video plans to delve deeper into the theorem's proof and the underlying formula of the normal distribution.
01:35
The simplified model of the Galton Board is used to illustrate the Central Limit Theorem.
02:05
The final position of the ball in the Galton Board model is the sum of random choices between plus one and minus one.
02:31
The number of balls falling into different buckets gives an idea of the likelihood of each bucket.
03:10
üé≤ The central limit theorem states that as the size of a sum of random variables increases, the distribution of that sum approaches a bell curve.
04:15
The central limit theorem applies to random variables, which are associated with numbers based on the outcome of a random process.
04:15
By taking multiple samples of a random variable and adding them together, the distribution of the sum tends to resemble a bell curve as the size of the sum increases.
05:11
The central limit theorem allows for making predictions about the range of values a sum of random variables is likely to fall within.
05:27
The central limit theorem has three assumptions that must be true for it to hold, which are revealed at the end of the video.
05:56
The central limit theorem applies to both fair and weighted dice, demonstrating its generality.
05:56
Simulations of rolling a weighted die demonstrate that the central limit theorem still applies, regardless of the distribution of outcomes.
06:25
Running multiple simulations of summing samples from a skewed distribution shows that the resulting distribution approaches a bell curve.
06:40
The video encourages viewers to predict the three assumptions of the central limit theorem before they are revealed.
06:59
üé≤ The video explains the central limit theorem using simulations and theoretical calculations for different dice distributions.
07:25
üé≤ The video discusses the central limit theorem and how the mean and standard deviation of a distribution affect its shape.
10:57
The central limit theorem states that as the number of samples increases, the distribution of the sums tends to resemble a bell curve.
10:57
The distributions in the video are shown to shift to the right and become more spread out as the number of samples increases.
11:13
The mean of a distribution is a measure of its center of mass and is calculated as the expected value of the random variable.
11:36
The variance is a measure of the spread of a distribution and is calculated by squaring the difference between each value and the mean.
12:18
The standard deviation is the square root of the variance and is a more intuitive measure of spread.
12:45
The mean of the distributions increases linearly with the number of samples.
13:15
The variance of the sum of two random variables is equal to the sum of their individual variances.
13:53
The standard deviation does not add when summing random variables; it is the variance that adds.
14:07
üìä The video explains the central limit theorem and the formula for a normal distribution.
14:20
The variance of the sum of 'n' different realizations of the same random variable is 'n' times the variance of the original variable.
14:20
The standard deviation of the sum is the square root of 'n' times the original standard deviation.
14:33
The distributions are realigned so that their means line up and rescaled so that all standard deviations are equal to one.
15:13
This process results in a universal shape described by a normal distribution.
15:28
The formula for a normal distribution involves the function e^(-0.5x^2/Sigma^2).
16:00
The constant Sigma represents the standard deviation of the distribution.
17:27
The area under the curve of a probability distribution must be one.
17:42
üìä The video explains the concept of probability density functions and how they relate to the area under the curve of a bell curve distribution.
17:54
Probability density functions represent the probability of a value falling between two different values.
17:54
The area under the curve of a probability density function represents the probability of an event occurring.
18:08
The basic bell curve shape of the function does not have an area of one, but dividing it by the square root of Pi gives the desired area.
18:20
The factor in front of the function ensures that the area under the curve is always one, regardless of the value of Sigma.
18:49
The Standard Normal Distribution is a special case where Sigma equals one and plays an important role in the lesson.
19:20
The mean and standard deviation of a distribution can be used to describe the sums of random variables.
20:02
By modifying the expression to have a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one, the distribution can be visualized in a more elegant way.
21:00
The modified expression tells us how many standard deviations away from the mean a sum is.
21:14

author: @wadelamble5462
textdisplay: Can someone help me with a question? I was hoping this video would help me understand why, to paraphrase a text I'm reading on signal processing, "complex exponentials are the eigenfunctions of translationally invariant operators"? I think "translational invariance" is another way of saying a convolution as both are defined by O(x, x') being always K(x - x'). The proof is actually easy: Integral(dx'K(x - x')exp(iwt) = (integral(dt''K(t'')exp((-iwt))esp(iwt) where t'' = t - t'. But I don't have any intuition about "translation invariance" and why convolution kernels are translationally invariant. I have no doubt my question is a muddle, please be gentle.

author: @wadelamble5462
textdisplay:
Correction: Integral(dx'K(x - x')exp(iCx')) = Integral(dx''K(x'')exp(iC(x-x''))) = Integral(dx''K(x'')exp(iCx)exp(iCx'')) = exp(iCx)Integral(dx''K(x'')exp(-iCx")). And, because substituting x' back in for x can only shift the phase, exp(iCx) = Constant*exp(iCx') proving that exp(iCx') is an eigenfunction.

But can someone motivate this visually. Why doesn't a kernel "smooth out" the complex exponential the way it would, say a sine, or a series of delta functions.

author: @KopaPguiN
textdisplay: Another example to help you visualize (or audiate) the premise of this video... Convolution is heavily used in digital audio processing as a way of simulating reverb of specific spaces in a very precise manner based on a recorded (or simulated) "impulse response" from the space, defining how the space responds to different audio frequencies. Ideally, the impulse that the space is responding to can be defined as a perfectly short burst of white noise, but realistically if you can't do a sine wave sweep covering all audible frequencies, you're going to use something like a gunshot (starter pistol), balloon pop, or clap. But really you want to be able to play an audio file you can then use to deconvolve your field recording to get an impulse response. In any case, a normal distribution for audio would be a sample or generator of white noise (not technically but close enough and I bet your Central Limit Theorem video which I haven't watched yet explains why). Other kinds of noise could have other distributions but either way, if you progressively, iteratively re-convolve any audio sample with white noise or a source of normally distributed noise, it will get closer and closer to that noise distribution. This can be done in any audio editor or DAW with convolution reverb.

author: @KopaPguiN
textdisplay: The same technique is also used in guitar amp simulation, since a "space" captured by an impulse response can really be any two signals: an impulse and a response. It's very easy to play a sine sweep through a guitar amp, recording the result directly back to the mixing console/audio interface, and then de-convolve them to capture most of the character of that specific amp.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
I made a video covering a proof of the central limit theorem, that is, answering why there is a "central limit" at all. It's currently posted for early viewing on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/posts/draft-video-on-i-87894319

I think the video has room for improvement, and decided to put it on a shelf for a bit while working on other projects before turning back to it. In the meantime, though, if you are curious about why all finite variance distributions will tend towards some universal shape, it offers an answer.

Also, you may be interested to know that a Gaussian is not the only distribution with the property described in this video, where convolving it with itself gives a (rescaled) version of the original distribution. The relevant search term here is "stable distributions", though all others will have infinite variance, so don't fit the criteria of the CLT. Often when the CLT doesn't apply, it's because the independence assumption doesn't hold, but another way it can break is if you're starting with one of these infinite variance cases.

author: @ddognine
textdisplay: 11:18 I have often wondered, "Why the Gaussian?" Finally, Grant explains it in Step 2 which, of course, depends on Step 1. There is a universal shape that the process of convolutions tends towards in the infinite. What is that shape? Well, a Gaussian always results in another Gaussian after N convolutions, so the universal shape must be a Gaussian. Wow, I think my brain just did some Aristotleian gymnastics there. And if you can wrap your head around that and convince yourself that the logic is true, then ok.

author: @strehlow
textdisplay:
I'd love to see a video on deconvolution, and its applications. One noteworthy one is basic processing of an image from a telescope. The aperture (typically circular) applies a convolution of a rectangle function to the incoming light. Convolving the resulting image with the inverse of the rect function will remove the distortions caused by the aperture.
One strategy on smaller telescopes (especially using film instead of digital sensors) to avoid this is to put a filter on the aperture whose opacity follows a Gaussian, clearest in the center and darkest at the edge. This minimizes the distortions of the image coming through the telescope and avoids the need to process it afterward.

Simply amazing. That is a very simple yet very rich explanation for the central role played by the normal distribution, and the visuals are amazing as usual!

author: @steffanjansenvanvuuren3257
textdisplay:
"But what is the Fourier Transform? A visual introduction"
In that video you showed that the "Centre of weight"(hypotenuse max peak) reaches its peak on the right side, x(real) axis
whenever the input sinewave frequency is the same as the rotating frequency.
But that only happens if the input sinewave is in phase with the rotation frequency and the rotation starts exactly
at x=0 and y=1 on the complex plain.
ONLY then does the vector/hypotenuse max peak line up perfectly with the x axis.
In reality we have to continuously plot the vector/hypotenuse on a separate graph to get the information we want
because on the complex plain the vector/hypotenuse max peak can point in any direction or fall in any quadrant depending on the phase difference between the rotation and the input sinewave signal.

author: @frankfurtcs
textdisplay:
Might wanna go back and correct that little speech bubble in the end there my friend. The actual quote by FDR is: "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself."

And indeed, as was unfortunately expected by too few, fear turned out to be a far greater danger than anything else, as it was used to pressure people into giving up their rights, handing over more power to an already powerful minority, cultivating hate, distrust and division amongst friends, families, communities and nations, directly or indirectly (and absolutely legally) forcing people into taking part in medical experiments, thus making them risk the lives of themselves and even their children, while actively keeping them from taking care of their physical and mental halth and much more...

All while continuously supplying them with bits of hope, feeding them with easy to understand facts, graphs, videos like this and simple explanations to extremely complex problems, making them think they understood what was going on and were on the same level as "The Experts", maintaining their trust in who they believed to be their saviors, their teammates, acting solely in their best interest, definitely not exploiting the situation as money hungry corporations and power hungry politicians usually would, because this was a crisis and who would ever take advantage of people in a crisis...

Not to mention that merely questioning the fallable nature of those seemingly unbiased, neutral and selfless people who provided 99% of the population with "true" information, as opposed to mis-, dis- or whatever else type of information not approved by "The Science", was seen as an act of civil disobediance and thus punished by 1984-like censorship and social isolation, and worse.


Yeah. This is great Math video about things that work well in Mathland. The real world looks a little different though. I love these videos and I have nothing against Grant. But this is a beautiful example of how things can go terribly wrong if we approach complex societal problems as if they were math problems. On any board dealing with big issues like a pandemic there absolutely need to be scientists, mathematicians, doctors etc. But also psychologists, social scientists, philosophers, historians and real world blue collar men and women to keep them all in check.

Alright that's my 2 cents, peace!

author: @poloceccati
textdisplay:
Very nice, love your videos,
BUT here these models are just false for covid: experimentally it has been observed that the WAVES WERE CAUSED BY VARIANTS/mutants and not at all or just marginally because of social distancing stopping. In 2022 we now observed that immunity is lost very fast, and that cross immunity is weak from one variant to the next.


The real mechanism for a covid wave extinction is still not a scientific consensus: the heard immunity, either natural or by vaccine is not the only candidate to explain the wave stopping.
Very detailled PCR observations over the last 2 years are strongly suggesting that a variant is genetically weakened during its propagation/replication until it is unable to propagate anymore, thus stopping the wave. And also that eventually new variants comes from recombinations, not really mutations.

And also that animals such as furets and felines are now endemic reservoirs. All those new experimental facts are game changer for this kind of mathematical models interpretation.
The parameters of those SEIR models are very off, the models are forced to fit the real epidemics plot but is is just a false positive result. This is well know issue in chemical kinetics or plasma kinetics models.
Sad that the majority of epidemilogists still refuse to admit their errors.
Thanks again for your videos.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
There are many questions around contact tracing apps, and I'll try to address some of them in this pinned comment. What's presented is, in essence, the DP-3T algorithm, but needless to say it's a much-simplified version, so most security-related questions can be answered by going to https://github.com/DP-3T and reading the full details. For example, if you're thinking that when Bob's phone recognizes some signals in the hospital's database, it can deduce when Bob met with the someone now known to be sick by looking at where that message shows up on its "What I heard" list, you may be interested to learn how the full details of how these ids are generated and uploaded don't quite make that as possible as it would be for the simplified version outlined in Nicky's post.

One of the biggest concerns is over the efficacy of Bluetooth systems like this. For example, false positives due to signals shared through apartment walls, and false negatives due to touching a shared surface without ever being near someone. No one claims that these will catch all contacts, but the goal is to have a system more scalable than in-person interviews, and what you need is for R to stay consistently below 1, not to catch all cases. Any serious plans for reopening including a system like this also would include other practices driving this reproductive number down, like mask-wearing and distancing where possible. Also, to the accuracy concerns, it seems worth mentioning that at least one person I know is working on https://www.novid.org/ which incorporates ultrasound to get a better sense of proximity.

Many government-issued contact-tracing apps do use GPS in some way, so you'd want to stay informed about whatever specific system is being advertised to you. The purpose of Nicky's post is to make clear that contact tracing does not imply location tracking. If people (or governments) really want to use GPS based contact tracing too, there's no reason you can't have both. But if you're in a country where people can choose to opt-in, you won't be including people who are concerned about privacy.

As to the status of the Google/Apple system, the first phase of their plan involved putting out an API that developers can use to build apps according to these standards, which is now done. The second phase will involve doing something built into the phone's OS, which people can opt in to. For my part, I think the most plausible scenario where we have mass adoption comes something in the OS like this.

author: @AbiGail-ok7fc
textdisplay: If it comes to developing something with good privacy, Google will be near the bottom of the list of organizations I'd look at.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay: @The Different Commenter Great question, look at https://www.novid.org/

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay: @oH well,lord! That's a great question.  Take a look at the DP-3T white paper.  What's actually being sent is a seed to a pseudorandom generating function, not the messages themselves.  You can't look at the outputs of other pseudorandom functions and deduce the seed (if they are cryptographically secure).

author: @noamtashma2859
textdisplay: I want to say, that with the right cryptography, GPS based tracing does not imply privacy loss. For example, in israel's hamagen (shield) app, you can opt into tracing yourself, so that you will be notified if you met someone with covid, but if you become infected, you can either opt in and share your locationa anonymously, or just opt out of that and not send them.

author: @NilesBlackX
textdisplay:
Hello 3blue1brown, long time subscriber and I love your videos. However you've made several critical errors in your assessment here. As a security researcher, I'd be happy to talk to you more about this, but a brief summary can be found below;

First of all, the concern people have isn't generally that other people with the app (Bob) can infer their GPS location. That's what your video describes the protection through obfuscation against. The concern is around that central tabulary, and it takes literally one string of data (the device ID) being leaked through the application, which could happen in a later update and doesn't have to be currently present in the code, to make Alice and her network of contacts trackable (definitely and trivially by 'Big Brother' but also by any bad actor). More concerning is that, from a 'Big Brother' standpoint, there are innumerable ways of making that happen without even needing to modify the app itself.

Again, I'd be happy to go into detail with you on this, but what I want you to understand is that these apps as designed in no way protect privacy, and do constitute a substantial overreach. The timing corresponding to an extension of the warrantless surveillance act is also of concern for privacy advocates.

Please feel free to reach out to me, I'd welcome the opportunity to repay the gift of knowledge by teaching you something for once.

author: @natewaltz1835
textdisplay: So you are generating pseudo-random numbers/cryptographic-ally secure numbers, it doesn't really matter for this scenario. There is an extremely small but still sort-of existent chance that the number being sent out by your phone is a duplicate of someone else's, assuming that this operates offline. The side effect of this is that people would be forced to isolate when they don't necessarily have COVID-19 (although the likelihood is very, very low, and dependent on the key size). If it operates online with a method of preventing collisions, then it is possible to compromise your privacy because things connected to the internet can be traced, and thus the consumer would have to trust the dev's implementation of the DP-3T algorithm in some sort of tracing app. Nothing is perfect I guess, but this is pretty close.

author: @deleenstallings3236

It‚Äôs been bugging me for a while as a math teacher that the formula for finding the x-coordinate of the vertex and the descriminant are taught separately and then students are taught the quadratic formula as though they are separate ideas.

The quadratic formula is this beautiful combination of the two that you explain in a unique way, here.

I love how this explanation focuses on that idea by making ‚Äúm‚Äù your ‚Äú-b/2a‚Äù (in a slightly different order). Then you attach meaning to how the desriminant finishes finding your solutions, or zeros. Conceptually this is beautiful on several levels.

7:45 I actually first found out about this mental math trick from the talk you gave on how math pedagogy can be improved, and find that, when paired with the trick for squaring big numbers that I learned from "surely you're joking mr. feynman" mental multiplication is fairly easy to do consistently without error, which I love. any excuse to not have to hope my calculator is charged while tutoring students (they are expected to have their own calculator and know how to use it, so my mental math is just a way for me to ballpark whether they typed it into the calculator correctly...)

also, last week I spent some time trying to find a pattern in the maclauren series expansions for sin(x)^2n (which would make it a bit easier to find an integral to compute the perimeter of an ellipse, as a bunch of the calc 3 students I was tutoring in the quarter that just ended were crashing and burning against this particular problem that their teacher had given them as an alternative to taking the final (my advice: just take the final exam. it will be easier)... I gave up after realizing that the coefficients for the terms of sin^6, after dividing by even powers of 2, were a sequence of numbers so unpleasant that the oeis gave me no results...)
but for sin^4, I actually found a difference of squares hiding in the coefficients, mostly because of you having brought my attention to just how powerful the difference of squares actually is as a tool for working with numbers, and not just for working with variables

author: @nickm3694
textdisplay:
We're dividing the whole equation by 'a' which technically changes the line of the equation, but doesn't change where the zeros are, because scaling by anything doesn't change 0
We do this because we can then write the b' and c' in x¬≤+b'x+c' (where b'=b/a and c'=c/a) in terms (x-r)(x-s), where r and s are the two solutions, and we get b'=-(r+s) and c'=r*s

author: @ASLUHLUHCE
textdisplay:
Reference to self:

"When you got to about the midpoint of the video and started to talk about the Pythagorean Identity of the Trig Functions, I would like to elaborate on this and add to it. We know that the Pythagorean Theorem is: A^2+ B^2 = C^2. Let's keep this in mind.

I will show and prove 4 - 5 different things that most math classes never fully express and these are the following:
* The Pythagorean Theorem and the Equation to a Circle are symbolically similar, also The equation to the Unit Circle centered at the origin is, in fact, the Pythagorean Theorem! It's just that one is in terms of right triangles and the other is in terms of a circle with a radius of 1.
* That there is a direct relationship of the Trigonomic Functions and linear equations in regards to their slopes.
* Without considering the use of limits and applying them, the Tangent Function is, in contrast, the definition of the slope function that is used to define a derivative within Calculus.
* That vector notation is symbolic of both linear and trigonometric calculations. For example ‚ü®a,b‚ü©=‚à•a‚à•‚à•b‚à•cosŒ∏ which states that the dot product between two vectors is the product of their magnitudes multiplied by the cosine of the angle between them. So if you know the lengths of two vectors you can find the angle! After you calculate the dot product, then you would have to take the arccos of that value, however, make sure you are using the right system (degrees, radians) to get the correct result you are looking for.
* All of this is rooted in the simplest of all mathematical expressions, not even an equation or a function, just a simple expression, being the very first one we are ever taught: (1+1) and that the operation of adding one to itself satisfies the construction of both the Unit Circle and defines the Pythagorean Theorem. Also, when we turn this into an equation (1+1) = 2 we will see that there is perfect symmetry, reflection, and rotation that is embedded within this.

The comparison of the Pythagorean Theorem and the Equation to a Circle:
The equation to an arbitrary circle is defined by (x ‚Äì h)^2 + (y ‚Äì k)^2 = r^2 where (h,k) is the 2D coordinate of the center of the circle.
Let's center this at the origin (0,0) and refer to the unit circle with a radius of 1. We now end up with: (x-0)^2 + (y-0)^2 + 1^2 = x^2 + y^2 = 1.
Let's compare this to the Pythagorean Theorem. x^2 + y^2 = 1 == A^2 + B^2 + C^2 when C = 1. So for any circle that is centered at the origin, it's equation is the Pythagorean Theorem.

The direct relationship of the Trigonometric Functions and Linear Equations:
We will use the slope-intercept form of a linear equation: y = mx+b. We know that m is defined by rise/run or (y2 - y1)/(x2 - x1) where can use the coordinate points to find the slope. The value of this slope is a proportion of how much change in height over the change in the horizontal. All angles will be relative to the line y = mx+b and the x-axis. In other words, it is the angle that is above the X-axis or the Horizontal axis up to the line itself. Here I mentioned the rate of change. We can take rise/run or (y2-y1)/(x2-x1) and rewrite this as dy/dx. We know that we can make a right triangle from the x-axis up to the line in question. By doing so we can see that the dy is also sin(t) and dx is cos(t). We can see that the slope of the line m is also the tangent of the angle above the horizon to that line. So we can rewrite the slope-intercept form y = mx+b to y = tan(t)x + b or sin(t)/cos(t)x + b. This will lead us to the next section about derivatives!

The Tangent Function and the Derivative: We know that when we have a curve that its slope is not constant. We can take two points on that curve that are relatively close and get a good approximation of its slope near that point, however, the farther the gap the more margin of error this is. This approach is what is referred to as finding the secant slope. If we make smaller and smaller incremental steps where we get closer and closer to that point where the limit of the size of that step approaches 0, we then end up with a line that has the slope of that point which is tangent to that curve at that point. This is seen in the difference quotient in Calculus to find a derivative. f'(x) = lim dx->0 (f(x+dx) - f(x))/dx Which is basically taking the slope form of a line (y2 - y1/(x2-x1) and rewriting it from point notation into function notation with respect to x, changing the difference in points to rate of change by using delta x and delta y, which is still all algebra, and the only part that is Calculus is when you actually apply the limit! So in a sense, we can see a direct relationship and similarity of (f(x+dx) - f(x)) / dx and tan(t). If we substitute tan(t) as sin(t)/cos(t). We can see that cos(t) = dx which is straight forward. However, if we look at f(x+dx) - f(x) it isn't quite obvious but this would be equivalent to sin(t). Where t is the angle above the x-axis and up to the point on the curve whose slope is the tangent of that angle produced by that linear equation.

The vector portion should be self-explanatory as I had already mentioned the most important piece and that is the dot product in relation to the cosine of the angle between those two vectors. Not much more needs to be expressed about this here, but will be referred in the last section.

(...continued in a reply to this post)

author: @ASLUHLUHCE
textdisplay:
(...continued)

How (1+1) ties all of this together! Consider the value 1 to be an arbitrary unit length, it could be 1 inch, 1 mile, 1 cm, it doesn't matter! Now, take a piece of square paper and mark a point near the center of the paper, then draw a line from there in any direction and stop a little less than 1/2 across the paper and make another point where you stopped. Now go back to the center and mark this as 0. Then mark the endpoint as 1 and make a slight arrowhead at that point. Direction here is completely arbitrary and agnostic to the length or magnitude of that line segment or vector that you had just drawn. Now this will be a unit vector. The starting point labeled 0 will be the 0 vector, this will be important later on. Now rotate this paper until the line segment is parallel with your body and that the 1 is to the right side. What we are going to do next is to apply the operation of addition to this unit vector with itself. By convention addition in the positive sense will be towards the right. So what you now need to do is visualize that entire line from 0 to 1 sliding across itself so that the 0 point is now at 1 and the new endpoint of 1 is near the edge of the paper you can mark this with a 2 and put another arrowhead there. By drawing these two vectors you have physically done (1+1) = 2. Okay, so we saw this being done through vectors. I had you do this to express the importance that Addition is a Linear Transformation. It is Translation to be exact. Now without knowing it, by performing that addition you also simultaneously performed multiplication. You see Addition is a 1 Dimensional Operation, but it introduces us into 2 Dimensional Space. It doesn't seem apparent yet, but I will get to that! We know that (1+1) = 2 and we know that 1*2 = 2. So we can easily see that (1+1) = 1*2 = 2*1.

Multiplication is embedded within addition, however, multiplication can be both a 1 and 2 Dimensional Transformations. A 1D Transformation of multiplication is scaling or shearing in a specific direction and a 2D transformation is a Rotation or defining Area. Now, how does this relate to the Unit Circle, Triangles, Trigonometry, The Pythagorean Theorem, and even Calculus? It's quite simple... let's take a step back and remember when I said to draw a line in any arbitrary direction... then I had you rotate that paper to position the line to be parallel with your body and the line pointing to the right. Now, we denoted this as being +1 which could be symbolic with the direction East. Nothing stopped us from being able to go West by 1 unit. So now let's make another unit vector that goes from the origin 0, and mark this Western or Left point with a 1. Now, when it comes to vectors, the magnitudes of the first vector, and this new one are the same, but their directions are Opposite. So we can use the negative sign to represent the opposite direction. So we can now add a - to this 1. If we add these two values (1) + (-1) we end up with 0 which leads us back to the starting point or the 0 vector. However, their combined value |1| + |-1| = 2. These three values of 0, 1 and 2 are all related to each other. Now we said that addition is a 1D transformation translation to be exact. We also said that 1+1 =2 is also multiplication. Well we have a line and there is no area, so the 2D transformation here must be rotation. Let's take the first line 0 to 1 and rotate that about the 0 point and see what happens when we end up at -1. We did a 1/2 rotation of a full circle.

We know that the arc length is PI and that the central angle is 180 degrees. We also know that a line has 180 degrees of rotation which is also the addition of all 3 interior angles of any triangle. We know that the unit circle has a radius of 1 and a diameter of 2. Its circumference is 2PI and its area is PI unit^2. Yes, even the value PI is embedded in the expression (1+1). This expression has a perfect symmetry and complete rotation embedded within it. It also has perfect reflection too. And if we understand what Derivatives and Integrals are, we also know that (1+1) doesn't just introduce multiplication but it also introduces powers because (1+1) = 2^1 which is a 3D transformation provided there are three components to the vector. For each component of a vector <x>, <x,y>, <x,y,z>, etc... the number of elements or the size of that vector is the dimensional space we are working in. Each dimensional space has specific attributes or properties. 0D = an arbitrary point. 1D = length, magnitude, line. 2D = rotation, area. 3D = multiple rotations and volume. etc... We also know that when we look at the polynomials in algebra: f(x) = x, f(x) = x^2, f(x) = x^3 that x is just x which is a scalar quantity and is linear and that x^2 represents the area of all squares, and that x^3 represents the volume of all cubes provided x is +, there is a case where x can be - in to define a - volume, but this involves complex numbers and is completely abstract! We also know that x, x^2, and x^3 are partially derivatives and integrals to each other so to speak. F(x) = xdx = 1/2x^2 + c. which states that the integral of f(x) = x is the family of functions f(x) 1/2x^2 + c. and so on, and the reverse is true too. All of this is embedded in (1+1) = 2. All of your irrational numbers are embedded within it. Your logarithmic and exponential functions are embedded within it! Everything is integrated or derived from (1+1)!"

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: 1) the definition of a complex number contradicts to the laws of formal logic, because this definition is the union of two contradictory concepts: the concept of a real number and the concept of a non-real (imaginary) number - an image. The concepts of a real number and a non-real (imaginary) number are in logical relation of contradiction: the essential feature of one concept completely negates the essential feature of another concept. These concepts have no common feature (i.e. these concepts have nothing in common with each other), therefore one cannot compare these concepts with each other. Consequently, the concepts of a real number and a non-real (imaginary) number cannot be united and contained in the definition of a complex number. The concept of a complex number is a gross formal-logical error; (2) the real part of a complex number is the result of a measurement. But the non-real (imaginary) part of a complex number is not the result of a measurement. The non-real (imaginary) part is a meaningless symbol, because the mathematical (quantitative) operation of multiplication of a real number by a meaningless symbol is a meaningless operation. This means that the theory of complex number is not a correct method of calculation. Consequently, mathematical (quantitative) operations on meaningless symbols are a gross formal-logical error; (3) a complex number cannot be represented (interpreted) in the Cartesian geometric coordinate system, because the Cartesian coordinate system is a system of two identical scales (rulers). The standard geometric representation (interpretation) of a complex number leads to the logical contradictions if the scales (rulers) are not identical. This means that the scale of non-real (imaginary) numbers cannot exist in the Cartesian geometric coordinate system. Consequently, the theory of complex numbers and the use of the theory of complex numbers in mathematics and physics (electromagnetism and electrical engineering, fluid dynamics, quantum mechanics, relativity) represent a gross methodological error and lead to gross errors in mathematics and physics.

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: Also, I noticed you depict the imaginary axis unit i having the same length as the unit on the real axis. Does it mean that sqrt(-1) is equal to 1??? Or is it less than 1? Or is it more than 1?

author: @AndresFirte
textdisplay:
No, because having the same ‚Äúlength‚Äù as another number doesn‚Äôt mean both numbers are equal. For example, 5 and -5 have the same ‚Äúlength‚Äù but 5 and -5 are not equal.

And no, ‚àö(-1) is not bigger than 1, or lesser. When we start using complex numbers we lose the notion of order. To be more specific: the CN can‚Äôt be ordered in a way that is compatible with addition and multiplication.

This is an obvious consequence of generalizations: the more you generalize some concept, the more specific properties you lose.

When you generalize from natural numbers to real numbers you lose the property that every subset must have a least element.

When we generalize from real numbers to complex numbers you lose the property of ordering

When we generalize from complex numbers to quaternions you lose the commutative property for multiplication

When you generalize the quaternions into octonions you lose the property of associativity

And so on

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: @@AndresFirte I'm still waiting for your opinion on Kalanov's paper.

author: @AndresFirte
textdisplay:
@@pelasgeuspelasgeus4634 and I already told you that we have to close the other topic first, otherwise we‚Äôd just leave unfinished conversations.

You argue that CN's don‚Äôt make sense because making the assumption that they do leads to absurdities like 1 = -1.

I pointed out that you also made an extra assumption: that ‚àöa √ó ‚àöb = ‚àö(a√ób) for a, b ‚àà R. If you don‚Äôt prove this is true (either as a consequence of the real number axioms or the complex numbers definition), then you can‚Äôt use it for the proof.

So please do one of the following:

Option 1) Give me a proof that ‚àöa √ó ‚àöb = ‚àö(a√ób) for a, b ‚àà R (in which case I‚Äôll admit that you have found irrefutable evidence that CN's lead to nonsense. In this case it‚Äôs completely unnecessary to move on to the paper you mentioned because I‚Äôll be convinced CNs are fake)

Or

Option 2) Admit that this particular argument you gave is not sufficient to say CN's are fake. They could still be fake, but because of a different reason. In that case we can move one to the paper you mentioned, which I‚Äôd love to discuss.

In case you don‚Äôt agree these are the only options available, then let me put it this way (I hope you‚Äôve taken a class on logic, since I‚Äôll use some logic notation now):
Your proof uses many assumptions. Most of them are proven as theorems from the axioms of real numbers (and are therefore not assumptions, but theorems). But there‚Äôs two that are assumptions:

Assumption A: CNs make sense, we can take the root of negative numbers

Assumption B: ‚àöa √ó ‚àöb = ‚àö(a√ób) for a, b ‚àà R (or at least for a = b = -1)

And we get the Contradiction C: -1 = 1

You initially argued that A -> C, and since C is false, then A is false too.

So I‚Äôm pointing out that we actually have (A and B) -> C. Since C is false, then (A and B) is false.

If (A and B) is false, then A is false, or B is false, or both A and B are false. So we have three possible scenarios.

If you prove to me that B is true (or that A -> B), then we‚Äôll be able to discard two scenarios and we‚Äôll be left with the scenario where A is false, and I‚Äôll then admit that CNs are absurd.

So I‚Äôll wait for you to choose Option 1 or Option 2.

In which case, I probably can‚Äôt, for the same reason I can‚Äôt prove that real numbers ‚Äúare legit‚Äù (consistent). Because of Godel‚Äôs Incompleteness Theorems. However, we haven‚Äôt found any contradictions in them and they are incredibly useful.

But let‚Äôs not change the subject, and stay on the previous argument you were trying to do: that CNs implied that 1 = -1. You chose Option 1 or Option 2?

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: I'm curious to know where do we find sqrt(-1) in the real world. Anybody? BTW, anyone who answered other than E needs medical attention...

author: @AndresFirte
textdisplay:
What do you mean with ‚Äúfind sqrt(-1) in the real world‚Äù. I‚Äôve never found a 5 walking around the park, and I‚Äôve never seen a 7 hidden behind a bush.

Numbers represent concepts, they are an abstraction. The natural numbers, for example, is the abstraction of amount: 5 apples, 3 sticks, 2 dots.

Negative numbers are a generalization of natural numbers: a further abstraction. And they happen to be useful to represent debt for example.

Real numbers are a further abstraction of the integers and rational numbers and can be used to represent a variety of measures in science for example.

Complex numbers are yet another generalization, and they also happen to be able to represent concepts used in the real world: one example is rotations.

So if your question is ‚Äúare there real world concepts that can be represented by complex numbers?‚Äù then the answer is: Yes. 2D rotations can be represented and worked with with complex numbers

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: @@AndresFirte Have you ever bought sqrt(-1) apples or seen sqrt(-1) birds on a tree?

author: @AndresFirte
textdisplay:
@@pelasgeuspelasgeus4634 no, but have you seen -6 birds flying? Have you seen -3.62 fragments of rock?

If you think that ‚Äúnumber‚Äù is a concept ONLY used to describe an amount of things, then you are thinking about Cardinal Numbers. There are more types of numbers. Some of them are can be used to describe amounts (like Natural numbers and Cardinal numbers), and some of them can be used to describe more abstract things like debt (like negative numbers) and some others can describe 2D rotations and scaling (like Complex numbers).


To be even more precise: ‚Äúnumber‚Äù is an ambiguous concept in mathematics. We intuitively call ‚Äúnumber‚Äù anything that can be added and multiplied, but there‚Äôs things (like polynomials and matrices) that can be added and multiplied and yet we don‚Äôt usually call them numbers. Why? Because ‚Äúnumber‚Äù is a fuzzy word, with an ambiguous definition.

In mathematics we have many other words that are far more precise: Real Number, Integer numbers, Rational Numbers, Elements of a field, Elements of a ring, Complex numbers, etc. all of which formalize the intuitive notion of ‚Äúnumber‚Äù in different ways

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Summary of the confusion on problem 2. TL;DR, given the spirit of the question it should have also specified that f(x) > 0 for all x, and I'm clearly prone to deep confusion while trying to juggle the many balls of live broadcasting.


The question asks about a function f satisfying f(a + b) = f(a)f(b). The relevant part of the question was whether f(-1) must be 1 / f(1).


- It was originally graded in a way to suggest that this does indeed need to be true.
- While "explaining" it, I realized that the explanation required that f(0) = 1, and questioned whether this is necessarily true. I even said, "oh, you could just scale it". This thought of scaling is not correct, since (c*f(a))(c*f(b)) = c^2 f(a + b), so the lhs and rhs doesn't scale the same way.
- At 27:48, Sam points out that the constant function f(x) = 0 doesn't work, which I misread as asking about whether f(x) = 0 for some x (sorry Sam!).
- Crispin points out that f(0) must be 1 because f(x) = f(x + 0) = f(x)*f(0). This is true, as long as f(x) does not equal 0 everywhere, but at that point, I was still weirdly blind to that edge case and enthusiastically accepted this as a reason that the question was originally graded correctly.
- At 49:07, more of the discussion that has been happening on twitter is brought to screen, where Eric correctly points out that Crispin's proof doesn't work for the constant function f(x) = 0, which Sam had said all along much earlier and I misread.


Thanks for the good discussion, and the tolerance of some live befuddlement.

author: @oximas
textdisplay: I have a nice question does all functions that satisfy f(a+b) =f(a)f(b) produces values that are bigger than or equal to zero or can a function with such property have a negative output?

author: @theloganator13
textdisplay:
‚Äã@@oximas Let's assume there is a continuous (you can draw it without lifting your pencil) function f(x) such that f(a+b) = f(a)f(b), and that at some place this function is negative, say f(c) < 0.
In the spirit of this post, we can see that f(c+0) = f(c) = f(c)f(0), so f(0) = 1.
We know that f(0) = 1 and f(c) < 0, which means that there must be a number d between c and 0 such that f(d) = 0.
This means that f(1+d) = f(1)f(d) = 0. But also f(2+d) = 0. And f(3+d). In fact, we would find that no matter what number x is input to the function, f(x) = 0.
But this contradicts our assumption that f(c) < 0. The contradiction means that the original assumption must be wrong, so there cannot be a continuous function f(x) such that f(a+b) = f(a)f(b) and f(c) < 0 for any number c.
Using this same argument, we can show that the only continuous function such that f(a+b) = f(a)f(b) that can take the value 0 is the function f(x) = 0.

author: @tomekczajka
textdisplay:
@@oximas For real-valued functions negative values are not possible, because f(x) = (f(x/2))^2 >= 0.

If complex values are allowed then you can get negative values, for instance...
f(x) = e^(ix)
Then f(pi) is negative.

textdisplay: It's not actually saying anything, Grant. Because you're conflating two or more domains of math (complex, real, geometry, and integers) and that is undefined.  It's not even clear or proven that you can mix integers with reals, Grant.  Is 1.0 = 1?  You don't know.  It's like mixing true and false with 1 and 0.  Sure that's a nice convenience, but is it sound?  Will it make an undecidable or false theorem?

author: @zachrodan7543
textdisplay: one theory as to why logs are one of the hardest topics to teach in math: our brain's factory default is to compare numbers logarithmically, and all the math education up until the introduction of logs is training us to STOP thinking logarithmically... and so logs go from being the way the brain wants to think about numbers (for evolutionary survival reasons: 1 more lion showing up makes a much bigger difference to survival chances if you are up against 10 lions than if you are up against 100) to only thinking in logs when comparing large numbers in a conversational setting (we do like comparing things in terms of how many times larger they are), to then having to deal with a bunch of properties that not only don't quite grok with the math we have been trained to do, but even go so far as to feel like cheating (when tutoring people, I will sometimes joke that the power property of logarithms is one of the few instances in math where you are allowed to cut and paste (the only other one I can think of is variable substitutions... because dummy variables tend to make everything easier)

author: @mst7155
textdisplay: One humble historical remark: Napier ( a Scottish genius) invented the logarithms at the beginning of the 17 century( aproximatively).His motivation was very pragmatic: at that time it was really hard to compute the multiplication of large numbers!!!!! So he invented the Logarithmical Tables.Let s explain it... Napier calculated log1,log2,log3,....log 10000000....( Log in this context means log basis 10).He noticed that: log(x *y)= logx+ log y means that x*y becomes easy if we could compute logx+ logy... Indeed using the Logarithmical tables, multiplication is reduced to addition, which is much easier!!!!!

author: @r.w.emersonii3501
textdisplay:
Regarding the relationship between log( a, b) and log( b, a):

Multiply the two and use n * log( x) == log( x ** n):

log( a, b) * log( b, a)

== log( a, b ** log( b, a)) == log( a, a) == 1
== log( b, a ** log( a, b)) == log( b, b) == 1

author: @r.w.emersonii3501
textdisplay:
Regarding the inverse question: Addition and multiplication are commutative, and that is why each has only one inverse function: E.g.,

a + Inv( a) == Inv( a) + a == 0; Inv( a) == 0 - a

Exponentiation is not commutative. 3 ** 10 != 10 ** 3. Here, the side of the operator matters. There is no one Inv function that satisifies

Inv( a) ** a == a ** Inv( a) == ?

At least, I don't know of such a function! So here we have a left-inverse and a right-inverse:

InvL( a) ** a == j ; InvL( a) == j ** ( 1 / a) == "a-th root of j"
a ** InvR( a) == k; InvR( a) == log( a, k) == "log base-a of k"

I use j and k here because we have no one identity (i) for exponentiation:

a ** i == a implies i == 1
i ** a == a implies i == a ** ( 1 / a)

author: @nopeno9130
textdisplay:
@14:12 I think another easy idea(phrasing?) here is that exponentiation doesn't have a single inverse because it does different things to its arguments. You can flip 5+2 or 5*2 to 2+5 or 2*5 and get the same result, but not 5^2. So, different functions are required depending on which of the two arguments you want the inverse for.

I know this isn't a mathematically precise explanation, but it's short and I think it's intuitive, and I'm no mathematician but I think it means the last part of his question is correct(either one could be called an inverse, or you could say there is no single inverse).

Well I have often wondered if that is a good way to represent very large quantities in nature?
Consider 1, 2^2, 3^(3^3), 4^(4^(4^4)) .. and so on
this small set = 1, 4, 7‚òì10¬≤‚Å∑, 10^(10¬π‚Åµ¬≥)

as you can see rapidly grows, so what use is it?
If we count all the atoms in the Universe (NœÖ) ~ No of galaxies ‚òì no. of stars in galaxy ‚òì size of star ‚òì Avogrados No
we get ~10^80
so please tell me the number of possible different Universes (permutations of all the atoms) that could have evolved with this amount of matter?
(10^80)! ~ 10^(10^82) = x‚•£x i..e. solve for 'x'üò¨

author: @amits4744
textdisplay: Using the Lambert W function, we can assign a value even to divergent infinite power towers. The infinite power tower of 2 is assigned a value of [-W(-ln2)]/ln2 using the Lambert W function which turns out to be a complex number. Similarly infinite power towers of 3,4,e,ùúã,100,googol,etc can get complex values using the Lambert W function

author: @alexk2515
textdisplay:
The answer to 4=x^x^x‚Ä¶ is x = exp(ln(4)/4)
Proof:
Assume k = x^x^x‚Ä¶
Then x^k=k => ln(x)=ln(k)/k => x=exp(ln(k)/k)
But also k=4 => x = exp(ln(4)/4)

author: @Robert_H.
textdisplay:
Find range for Equation: a^x = x

=> x * (1/a)^x = x * e^(Ln[1/a] * x) = 1

=> Ln[1/a] * x * e^(Ln[1/a] * x) = Ln[1/a]

=> Ln[1/a] * x = Lambert_Function( Ln[1/a] )

=> x = 1/Ln[1/a] * Lambert_Function( Ln[1/a] )

Lambert_Function( y ) is only defined for values y ‚â• -1/e

=> Ln[1/a] ‚â• -1/e

=> 1/a ‚â• e^(-1/e)

=> e^(1/e) = 1.44466786101... ‚â• a

For a -> 0, we get x -> 0

For a -> e^(1/e) , we get x -> e

-------------

Find solution for Equation: x^x = a

=> x * Ln[x] = Ln[a]

=> Ln[x] * e^( Ln[x] ) = Ln[a]

=> Ln[x] = Lambert_Function( Ln[a] )

=> x = e^( Lambert_Function( Ln[a] ))

---------------

Find solution for Equation: x^a = a

=> x = a^(1/a)

author: @AndresFirte
textdisplay:
Because the absolute value of the imaginary unit i is the same as the absolute value of the real unit 1. And the absolute value is a formalization of the intuitive notion of distance. So they are depicted as having the same distance to the origin to have a geometric intuition for them.

The absolute value for complex numbers is a generalization of the absolute value for real numbers. And it is defined as |Z| = ‚àö(Zr¬≤ + Zi¬≤), where Z is a complex number, Zr is the real component of Z, and Zi is the imaginary component of Z.

author: @retr0foxx_osu
textdisplay:
Hey, near the start of the video, I tried to find a way to more-intuitively think about a function in the form of i^(ix) which made me end up thinking about a more generic function in the form of (ai)^(ix) and I kind of thought of one way to think about it that I was kind of satisfied with.

First, I'll review the fact that a function in the form of e^(ix) traces out a circle because the derivative of this function is a 90 degree rotation of the original function. Another way to say it is the derivative at any position, is the same as that position rotated by 90 degrees. And since the line tangent to a certain point on a circle is a line perpendicular to the line from the center of the circle to that certain point, that original function traces out a circle.

We can also think of a function A^(ix) where A is a real number. This will also trace out a circle.
Let's try taking the derivative of this function. But first, I'll change the way the function is written to make taking the derivative of it easier
A^(ix) = e^(ln(A)ix)
The derivative of that is:
ln(A)ie^(ln(A)ix) = ln(A)iA^(ix)
Notice that this derivative is basically ln(A)i TIMES the original function. We know that ln(A) is a real number, so what we're doing in the derivative is the original function rotated 90 degrees (because it is multiplied by i), and then multiplied by ln(A).
The point is that the derivative is still the original function rotated 90 degrees BUT THEN it's also multiplied by some real number factor.
This simply makes the rotation process be faster by ln(A). So instead of having to evaluate the original function at 2pi to make a full revolution, you only need to evaluate it at 2pi/ln(A) to make a full revolution

Now, let's think about what happens if the derivative is the original function that is rotated by some amount that is NOT 90 degrees. What does that make??
This may be a part that needs more explanation for this whole intuitive-explanation to be more satisfactory, but if you think about it a bit...
Let's say that the derivative is the original function rotated by some amount MORE than 90 degrees.
So instead of tracing out a perfect circle... The "trace-line" will instead... SPIRAL OUTWARDS!
If the derivative is the original function rotated by some amount LESS than 90 degrees, then the function will result in an INWARD SPIRAL!
The meaning of inward and outward spiral is just where the spiral goes as x INCREASES right. idk if i needed to point that out but might as well. if it spiral inwards then it approaches 0 as x goes to infinity, but if it spiral outwards, then it approaches infinity as x goes to infinity, but approaches 0 as x goes to negative infinity.

So now let's go back to the math stuff.
Previously, we were thinking about a function in the form of A^(ix) where A is a real number and the derivative of this is that same function rotated 90 degrees which will trace out a circle.
Now let's think of a function in the form of (ai)^(ix) where `a` is a real number
Let's try taking the derivative of this function. Before that, let's review that ln(i) = pi/2i
So first, we kind of rewrite the function in a way that makes it easy for us to take the derivative of the function
(ai)^(ix) = e^(ln(ai)ix)
Now take the derivative
d/dx [e^(ln(ai)ix] = ln(ai)ie^(ln(ai)ix) = ln(ai)i(ai)^(ix)
Which, if we think of the original function (ai)^(ix) to be equal to f(x), can be rewritten as:
ln(ai)if(x)
Which is basically the original function TIMES ln(ai)i
Now this ln(ai)i actually decides how much the original function is rotated at any point. We know that if this factor is simply `i` then it's a rotation of 90 degrees. Now let's find out if ln(ai)i results in a rotation of 90 degrees. If it DOESN'T, then from what we've talked about before, we know that it makes a SPIRAL!

Before we continue, I wanna talk a tiny bit more again about complex number multiplication
So we have f(x) and f(x) is supposed to return a COMPLEX NUMBER, right.
Any complex number multiplied by an imaginary number `ai` will result in that complex number being rotated by 90 degrees and then the magnitude will be multiplied by a
But what if we multiply a complex number by... another complex number?
Say we have some VARIABLE complex number Z and we have some constant complex number (a + bi)
How much does the variable complex number Z, for any value of Z, get rotated by if we multiply it by the constant complex number (a + bi)
Well, we can try to remember the geometric interpretation of complex number multiplications.
The resulting complex number from a multiplication of 2 complex numbers z1 and z2 will have a rotation of the sum of those 2 complex numbers' rotation and a magnitude of the product of those 2 complex numbers' magnitude
First, let's try finding the individual rotation of the two complex numbers and store them in the variables t1 and t2
t1 = atan(Im(z1)/Re(z1))
t2 = atan(Im(z2)/Re(z2))
Meaning that the sum of the rotations of the two complex numbers is:
t = t1 + t2
t = atan(Im(z1)/Re(z1)) + atan(Im(z2)/Re(z2))
Now let's store the sum of the magnitude in a variable called m
m = |z1| * |z2|
The resulting complex number in terms of the product of the magnitude and the sum of the rotations will be:
z1z2 = m * (cos(t) + isin(t))
You can try expanding m and t in there to get the full formula, but I just want the big picture here, I guess.
From that formula, we know that the rotation of the product of the two complex numbers will be the sum of the rotation of the two complex numbers.
Meaning that if you multiply a complex number z1 by another complex number z2, the result will ROTATE z1 by the rotation of z2
If we think of z1 as the variable complex number Z and z2 as some constant complex number (a + bi), then we know that, for any value of Z, multiplying it with the constant complex number (a + bi) will rotate the complex number Z by the rotation of a + bi which is equal to atan(b/a)

So let's go back to the derivative of (ai)^(ix) which is ln(ai)i(ai)^(ix)
Let's rewrite this so that it looks more like a complex number
And let's actually set f(x) to be equal to the original function (ai)^(ix)
f(x) = (ai)^(ix)
f'(x) = ln(ai)if(x) = (ln(a) + ln(i))if(x)
Expand ln(i) = pi/2i and put the outer i in
f'(x) = (ln(a)i - pi/2)f(x)
And from there, we know that the derivative of f(x) IS EQUAL TO f(x) (which is a complex number Z if we compare it to the example in the discussion about complex numbers earlier) ROTATED BY the rotation of the complex number "ln(a)i - pi/2" (which is the constant complex number a + bi in the previous example) which is NOT a 90 degree rotation so this is able to make a spiral. Or, well, if the rotation is 180 degrees, notice that it will just.. make a line. In this case, the function will have the form of i^i
To be more specific, f'(x) is going to be f(x) rotated by atan(-ln(a)/(pi/2)) = atan(-2ln(a)/pi)

So, in conclusion, (ai)^(ix) can trace out a spiral or a line or even nothing if a = 0
At values between 0 and 1, the derivative of the function is the function rotated by some positive value less than 90 degrees, and at values above 1, it gets rotated by some negative value more than -90 degrees.
What that means is, if you go slowly from a = 1 to a = 0, the shape will go from a line, and then a spiral that starts by going up and "expands" really quickly, and then into a spiral that expands more slowly, and in the end the shape will approach a circle.
At values above 1, if you go from a = 1 to a = infinity, the shape will go from a line, and then a spiral that starts by going down and expands really quickly, and then the a spiral that expands more slowly, and in the end the shape will approach a circle.

Notice how the rotation of the derivative doesn't ever go above 90 degrees. Meaning the spiral should always spiral INWARDS.

you can extend this explanation again to a function in the form of (a + bi)^(ix) but im too lazy right now, haven't thought about that as much
also havent thought about the fact that negative `a` values doesn't work cuz ln <= 0 is undefined..
i think the rotation becomes atan(-ln(a)/(2pi)) or something
cuz we had ln(ai)if(x), in this case it becomes ln(-ai)if(x) = (ln(-i) + ln(a))if(x)
just think about the rotation:
(ln(-i) + ln(a))i = (i2pi + ln(a))i = iln(a) - 2pi
and the rotation of that complex number is atan(-ln(a)/(2pi))
so yeah thats that.

author: @anjunakrokus
textdisplay:
As your neighberhood physicist, I have never seen a complex number to a complex number.
In all of classical physics we are dealing with observables (amplitude, magnetisation, postition, velocity) and complex exponentials arise to ease in computations (cos(x) -> e^(ix)) and as such we don't see complex bases. In this case we are mostly interested in the real part of complex numbers since these correspond to the actual observable.
In Quantum Mechanics complex numbers are much more common (due to the complex nature of the Schr√∂dinger equation, Dirac equation, etc). But since Quantum Mechanics is equivalent to linear algebra, you still don't see complex numbers raised to complex numbers. Here we are mostly interested in the absolute value of the wave function (which is complex valued).

Finally, physics deals with observations and the real world. And we observe the universe through instruments which return real numbers. As such we are usually only interested in the real part (or absolute value) of a complex number, making detours trhough the complex world to calculate things.

But maybe quantum gravity or some weird offspring of string theory is going to change that!

author: @lunkel8108
textdisplay:
Yea, because you can rewrite it in the form e^(i*Œ∏): If we take some other number a, then a^(i*Œ∏)=e^(i*Œ∏*ln(a))
So if you use a different base, you end up also walking around the unit circle, just at a different speed. e has the special property that the length you walk around the unit circle is exactly equal to Œ∏.

author: @dogol284
textdisplay:
I wonder if you can use the formula for the arc length of a circle, s = r * Œ∏, for the inscribed angle theorem.

If P1 is a point on the center of the circle, and P2 is a point on the circle itself, and both points describe the same arc, you know that r1 * Œ∏1 = r2 * Œ∏2.

Because P2 lies on the circle, and P1 is at the center, P1 and P2 are 1 radius apart, and because the diameter is two radii, you know the radius of P1 to the arc is 1/2 the radius of P2 to the arc, or more aptly, P2 is 2x the radius of P1.

But, as per the original fact that r1 * Œ∏1 = r2 * Œ∏2, the radius of P2 cannot be 2x P1 without changing the value of Œ∏2.

How much do you have to change Œ∏2 by for the equation to remain true? You need to half it! This gives that r1 * Œ∏1 = (2*r2) * (0.5*Œ∏2), which is the inscribe angle theorem! :)

This might be wrong, so if anyone still reads these comments, please feel free to prove me wrong.

author: @foxy19681904
textdisplay:
Something to think about is that problem solving is not like doing math. It's not an equation with a problem on one side and a solution on the other. Yo solve problems correctly you need to be able to see and understand the relationships between all the interacting parts of the environment that the problem exists in, you then alter the environment so that the problem disappears. Solutions always make the problem disappear. This is also different from solving a puzzle which is also not a problem. Please do not describe puzzles as problems because they are not. It's very important that you understand that solving a "puzzle" is not solving a "problem", and finding an "answer" to a mathematical "equation" is also not solving a "problem". It does confuse people though so its important that it is clarified. Too often I see/hear people using the term problem when describing a puzzle or an equation which is completely wrong.

I don't think this guy is truly qualified to be trying to educate others about problem solving seeing as he clearly doesn't have the required understanding of the concept.

author: @mahneh7121
textdisplay: I found a conceptual answer for the last question. Instead of 0.96, imagine a coin with the chance of tails = 0.5. Now if we throw a coin 100 times and we ask for the chances of getting heads, in 10 or 20 or 30,40,50, ...,100 it will be a max in 50: there is no reason why tails would be more likely than heads. Now if we have 0.6 instead, then it would be 60; 0.9 would be 90, and 0.96 would de 960 in a thousand or 48 in 50. Basically the most probable array of values, is that which corresponds which how the "object" is made.
