author: @flipflipshift855
textdisplay:
Even as a mathematical abstraction, one needs to be really careful. Go to the wikipedia page for Freling's Axiom of Symmetry and see the objections. It mentions that the theoretical ability to throw a dart on [0,1] uniformly tacitly assumes a total uniform measure on [0,1] which conflicts with the axiom of choice.

The takeaway imo is that you either have a universe where you can platonically throw darts on a real line or you have a universe with the axiom of choice. Not both.

author: @Narokkurai
textdisplay:
The way I had probability explained to me was, "A measure of how often betting on a particular outcome would be a good idea."

If the probability is .50, that doesn't mean it will happen 50% of the time, but it does mean that betting on every alternate coin toss coming up heads is a reasonable strategy.

Therefore, if something has a probability of zero, that doesn't mean it's impossible, but it does mean that it will never be a good idea to bet on it. No matter what the circumstances, it would always be the more rational decision to not bet on it happening, even though it could happen.

author: @orisphera
textdisplay:
I think you should have explained why it isn't like in the following example:
Let's say there's a sphere with uniformly distributed charge. The field it generates? Its value near it on the outside points towards it and depends only on the density, the field constant, and the number of dimensions. Inside, there is no field. So, it seems like a plane should have the same field. However, it actually is 2 times weaker, but exists on both sides.
In the situation I've described, the expected and actual outcome differ by a uniform field, which can be there without any charges in the theory of the closed action. I think that's a part of the explanation
UPD: Here's a non-rigorous explanation: When we increase the size of the circle, we can expect that the limit will be the same as if we had two parallel lines, one of which is infinitely far away. In this case, the brightness from the far away line will approach 0, so the end brightness will be this

author: @miloszforman6270
textdisplay:
@@orisphera
There is a thing called "electrical charge", another one called "electrical field", and a third called "electrical voltage" (or simply "voltage", as this is unambiguous). Of course, there are several other electrical quantities.

The electrical field is zero inside of a sphere which uniformly charged on its outside. But what does this have to do with the Basel problem?

Hint: It's good practice to first get one's terms clear, and post afterwards. And there are dictionaries and translation programs in abundance on the web.

author: @orisphera
textdisplay:
@@miloszforman6270 > But what does this have to do with the Basel problem?

In the proof in the video, they increase the size of the circle and consider the limit case. The supposed limit case is a straight line. I used a field to show that it's not always exactly like that. Perhaps it would be better to equate it to a different limit case (see the UPD)

author: @miloszforman6270
textdisplay:
@@orisphera
What's a "UPD"? (once again: unclear terms).
"The supposed limit case is a straight line. I used a field to show that it's not always exactly like that. "
I'm beginning to understand. If we observe the electrical field from a fixed distance to a a charged sphere, the opposite side of the sphere apparently still doubles the field at our point of observation, as opposed to a mere plane with the same distance and charge per area.

Well yes, interesting. However, there is no direct correlation to the Basel problem, because in the latter case a scalar quantity (namely light intensity) is summed up, as opposed to the vector quantity of the charged sphere. This summing procedure is not carried out in the video, he only says (without explanation) that the far side of the circle has a neglectable intensity for large diameters. This is not very hard to prove, though. The video is kind of heuristic - which is sufficient, in I my opinion.

On the other hand, if we had spheres instead of circles of lighthouses, with constant intensity per area, the angular intensity would remain the same independently from the size of the sphere. That argument from the video would not work any more.

author: @miloszforman6270
textdisplay: This does not seem to be related. The video shows the Leibniz formula by using number theory, which is a somewhat amazing result. It makes use of prime numbers, but the distribution of prime numbers doesn't seem to have anything to do with it. Proofs of the prime number theorem usually make use of complex analysis and the zeta-function. There are proofs which are more elementary but they are said to be lengthy - "elementary" here certainly not meaning "easy".

author: @FTFP1300
textdisplay:
Having seen many 3Blue1Brown videos multiple times, I was surprised that I hadn't seen this one yet (that, or I did see it and simply forgot the whole thing). Also, it's very cool to see that even the older videos still hold up incredibly well, which gives me hope on the impact these videos will have in the years to come.

This video also reminded me of a problem I had in undergraduate ring theory about the probability distribution of the gaussian integers (I don't completely remember, but it was some subset of gaussian integers having infinitely many members, but ultimately being a very small number with some limit being equal to zero), and I used a similar method of the circles approach, but instead with squares, so it was very fun to remember my thought process and struggles with solving it.

These videos are so cool, and the sense of wonder and ingenuity is helpful for me as I go through new challenges in graduate school.

author: @foli9092
textdisplay:
For anyone who has done Number Theory and wonders how this generalizes:
The same argument holds for the other 8 complex quadratic field extensions for which the ring of inters is a UFD. You just need to consider which primes split (completely), rammify and stay innert. We then have X(p) = 1, 0, -1 respectively.
As it turns out for the rings of integers in Q(sqrt(-p)), p odd prime we have X(n) = (n/p) with (n/p) the legendre symbol.
This is a special case of the Class Number Formular. If you want to do some more research I recommend checking out
"The class number formular for quadratic fields and similar results" by Roy Zhao

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Some added notes (copied from the pinned commend to the next video):

1) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ‚âà x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

2) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word ‚Äúphase space‚Äù to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. You should know, though, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the ‚Äúphase space‚Äù here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term ‚Äúconfiguration space‚Äù, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we do next video.

author: @LKC9215
textdisplay:
"For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count!"

As pi is irrational, doesn't that mean that every possible number can be found in there as there is no point at which the digits of pi would start to repeat? Sure, it would probably be too far in to matter by then, but yes, the last n digits of pi being 9 would be true at some point.

author: @MAYOJAMESD
textdisplay: @@LKC9215 I'm not sure how true this is. Just because a sequence of numbers is infinite does not mean that it contains every imaginable combination of numbers. For example, there is an infinity of numbers between 1 and 0. There's .0001, there's 1/3, you got pi over ten, etc. Yet, even given the infinite count of numbers you get between 0 and 1, you can never get any number larger than one. There is an infinite number of numbers, yet not all numbers are included. So even though Pi is irrational, I don't think it necessarily means that you get every possible combination of digits. In fact, since by the very definition of it being infinite we can never create all of its digits, there will always be some combination of digits that we cannot give a proof for being included in pi.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Some added notes (I may come back to add more later):

1) There's a slight error in the video where I say the answer is floor(pi/theta). Really it should be ceil(pi/theta) - 1, to account for the cases where pi/theta is an integer. For example, when the mass ratio is 1, theta will be pi/4, so pi/theta is 4, but there are 3 clacks. As stated in the video, though, you still think about this is "how many times can you add theta to itself before it surpasses (or equals) pi?"


2) What I animate here as I say "angle of reflection" and "angle of incidence" differs a little with convention. Typically in optics, you look at the angle between the beam and a line perpendicular to the mirror, rather than with the mirror itself.

3) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ‚âà x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

4) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word ‚Äúphase space‚Äù to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. This is common in the context of math, but you should know, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the ‚Äúphase space‚Äù here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term ‚Äúconfiguration space‚Äù, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we did here.

I hope you enjoyed this little sequence. I still get happy whenever I think about the phenomenon and the various explanations for it.

author: @socraticmathtutor1869
textdisplay: Absolutely love this channel, but tbh this video misses the point. The uber-geniuses of any given age aren't much impacted by debates like the pi/tau debate, because these debates concern themselves with the difference between two representations that are computationally easy to go between. Thus in the IQ range of 150+, such distinctions make essentially no difference. Now if your IQ is 140 or below, on the other hand, suddenly every CPU cycle has to be treated as really quite precious, and any time spent laboriously transforming between these two viewpoints is time spent not doing productive thinking. So, that's the secret: the reason the pi/tau debate matters is because these concepts are taught to millions of people with IQ's in the 70-140 range, and in this range the difference really, really matters. Incidentally, I personally believe that quad = tau/4 = pi/2 = 90 degrees is the correct (read: easiest) constant. So my ranking is this: quad is easiest to understand, tau is second easiest to understand, and pi is the hardest and most confusing of the three.

author: @miloszforman6270
textdisplay:
Of course you have to take these other points on the other side of the circle into account. Hopefully, the contribution of any such point is canceled by the point mirrored on the x-axis.

We may set N = K^3 for some large number K, and we want to show that all points that are more distant than K^2 points from 1 contribute an error smaller than 1/K.
The common error of the product of two such opposing points is of the order (1/K^2)^2 =1/K^4, so our total error is indeed smaller than K^3* 1/K^4 = 1/K. Ok, that's bit of hand waving math, but I think you can show it this way.

author: @arnevandycke1429
textdisplay:
Hi, I found an alternative, but easy visual way to find the distance product of Observer replacing one of the lighthouses at 12:00
First, calculate the distance product of the Observer but only using lighthouses 1, 3, 5, 7. Then the Observer is 1/2 of the way between lighthouse 7 and 1, so the distance product is 2. You then still have to multiply this by the distance product of the Observer and the remaining lighthouses (2,4,6). Here you do the same thing, you calculate the distance product of the Observer with lighthouses 2 and 6, which is equal to 2. Then only lighthouse 4 remains and the distance product of the Observer with lighthouse 4 is equal to 2 as well. You then multiply these 3 distance product to get the answer, 8.

author: @AndrewMikhno
textdisplay: 8:45 You are not allowed to replace x with an arbitrary point O. The equations x^N-1=0 and (x-L0)*...=0 are written to determine the lighthouses points, and work only for those points. There is no proof that by equating these 2 equations, they will be valid for any points. Thus equation (x^N-1)=(x-L0)*...*(x-Ln_1) is valid only for points of lighthouses and we cannot use it for arbitrary points without proof.. Example: x^N-1=0 and (x-L0)*...=0 ===> 537*(x^N-1)=0 and (x-L0)*...=0 ===> 537*(x^N-1)=(x-L0)*...*(x-Ln-1). So You left out the factor 537 in the first equation ))

author: @miloszforman6270
textdisplay:
"The equations x^N-1=0 and (x-L0)*...=0 are written to determine the lighthouses points, and work only for those points. There is no proof that by equating these 2 equations, they will be valid for any points."

Of course there is a proof, but it is left out in the video. It is sometimes taught in highschools or otherwise in first courses of math in fields which strongly depend on math (like engineering, or physics).

If p(x) is a polynomial, and a is a solution of p(x) = 0, then p(x) is divisible by x - a. The remaining polynomial must then still be divisible by all other solutions. This way you can factor p(x) step by step. The degree of the remaining polynomial is decreased by one every time, so at last a linear term is left which is our factor for the last solution. We here must use the basic theorem that every polynomial has a solution in the complex numbers.

The video does not deny that its proof of the Wallis product theorem relies on some complex algebra.

author: @RadishHarmers
textdisplay: Many ratios have well-defined limits (that is, asymptotic values), even if the two quantities whose ratios are being considered each separately approach ‚àû. When we say ‚àû / ‚àû is "undefined" or "indeterminate", we don't mean that no such thing has a limit; we just mean that different such things have different limits, instead of all coming to the same limit. The limit of a constant sequence is definitely well-defined and equal to that same constant, even though it can be expressed as a ratio of two things that each separately approach ‚àû.

author: @miloszforman6270
textdisplay:
The equation
1 + O + O¬≤ + ...+ O^(N-1) = (O - L1)(O - L2)*...*(O - L_(N-1))

would certainly hold even if the factor (O - L0) (= O - 1) is omitted on both sides. These are both continuous functions, they can't have any steps at O = L0.

Your objection is certainly justified, but it is kind of "hand waving mathematics" in this video. It does not pretend that this is not the case, however.

author: @nanyubusnis9397
textdisplay:
7:12 Sure, "1 and only 1 of those 4 outcomes leaves P1 and P2 on the opposite side of the circle" , but that's not the one that includes the center in it. Draw a line straight through the center from P3 and draw one exactly perpendicular to that. The outcome that leaves P1 and P2 on the opposite side of the circle, is where P1 and P2 are located at the top half of the circle. So, while what you're saying is true, it doesn't need to be the opposite to include the center apparently.
I guess you meant to say "1 and only 1 of these 4 outcomes, leaves P3 within the angle opposite of P1 and P2, which includes the center." Leaving out the details is quite important for people like me who look at these kinds of lessons from a teacher, and then, back in highschool, would conclude: "Either I'm stupid, or I'm surrounded by idiots, but in either case, I have no hopes for my next exam." Whenever I try to ask for more clarity, I could never find the right words which just left the teacher confused because from their perspective I seem to be struggling to accept the fact that 1 + 1 = 2, but from my perspective what they're saying is "1 + one = 2" which is clearly not the same.

author: @aaronherman1056
textdisplay: I'm kicking myself. I tried thinking about this on my own for a bit, but I couldn't get my head around it even in two dimensions. So I simplified this problem down to ONE dimension and then understood it perfectly: given an interval and two random numbers within the interval, the center of the interval is only between the two random numbers if they're on opposite sides of the interval, which has a probability of 1/2. Then I couldn't figure out how to generalize to multiple dimensions, got lost, tried to think about properties of triangles, and thought, "Now I'm going to watch the rest of the video and realize I had a really hard problem by the neck and couldn't do the final step" - and it was true! Three points on a circle contain the center if two of the points are on the opposite side of the circle from the third! Four points on a sphere contain the center if three of them are on the opposite side of the sphere from the fourth!

author: @ArchibaldCoke
textdisplay:
Calculating the average size of the triangular section is not that difficult. And you don't need multi-variable calculus.

If a triangle on a unit sphere has internal angles A, B, C, then its area is A+B+C-œÄ.

It isn't hard to show that when you join a point on a sphere with geodesic curves to two other random points forming an angle, all angles between 0 and œÄ are equally likely to be formed, and therefore the mean angle is œÄ/2. So the mean triangle area ‚ü®A+B+C-œÄ‚ü© = ‚ü®A‚ü© + ‚ü®B‚ü© + ‚ü®C‚ü© -œÄ = 3œÄ/2-œÄ = œÄ/2.

For the centre of the sphere to lie inside the tetrahedron the fourth point has to land inside the triangle. The probability of this is (Mean triangle area)/(Area of sphere) = (œÄ/2)/4œÄ = 1/8, which is the answer sought.

That said, I couldn't have solved this problem in 3 hours. It took more like 3 weeks. And my first solution involved a big numerical integral. Only afterwards did I notice the simpler way, and even then I must admit I have used a theorem that I don't know how to prove.

I enjoyed this problem. Really challenging but doable.

author: @AscendantPerfection
textdisplay:
Hey guys.
Here to simplify things.

Let's begin with dimensions.
Left, right, up, down, forward and backwards.
An easier way to explain dimension is, the general path anything takes when it's being squished on two ends.
If something squishes you from right and left, you can only go up and down, or forward and backward.
Therefore forward and backwards are you dimensions.
If something squishes you forward and backward, left and right, you can only go up and down.
Therefore up and down are your dimensions.

So area is simply how many times has a single line in one or two dimensions been repeated in another one dimension.

This definition applies to areas, not volumes.

Area of a rectangle is length times width because that straight line length which goes left or right, has been repeated width number of times, width being either forward or backwards OR up or down.

Now for a rectangle, the length is a straight line. And so is the width. So the area is a simple multiplication.

But in the case of a sphere, that length is a diameter of a circle, which has expanded left and right (one dimension), as well as forward and backwards (another dimension) in all possible ways you can turn.

Like a wave that forms when a stone is dropped in a pond of calm water. That circle has stretched out by its diameter.
And that diameter is our length.

If a circle has stretched out left and right, forward and backwards, that means the only other dimension left is up and down.
Meaning the circle can be flipped or rotate up and down.

So here's the question with area of a sphere.
How many times did a diameter of a circle which goes left and right, forward and backward, repeat itself in going up and down.

To visualize this...
Picture one circle, let's call it Circle A, with a diameter that goes left and right, forward and backwards.
Imagine that circle A is fitted inside another circle, let's call it Circle B with a diameter that goes up and down.

Now keep on drawing more circles like Circle A, as if to get a picture by picture rendition of rotating circle A around circle B provided they all fit in circle B, and it won't be long before you notice that you're tracing out the circumference of Circle B.

Equally so, you'll notice that there will be two ends of circle A, that will not rotate and will stay fixed. These two connected, form your diameter, such that if you're rotating circle A in circle B, there will be two points in circle A, that will not touch circle B and will stay fixed throughout the rotation.
The distance between these two points is what we are measuring the repetition of.

And so a very logical definition based meaning is that how many times did we repeat that diameter in going up and down.

Diameter is 2r. And the circumference is 2œÄr...
Multiply these two and you get your surface area.

I'm not sure if any of this made sense, but I'm putting it out here to whoever will understand or care.

Aight!

author: @lexus_bkl
textdisplay:
Question #1
Circumference of circle = 2œÄRsinŒ∏
So, Area of ring = 2œÄR¬≤sinŒ∏dŒ∏
Question #2
Area of Shadow of the ring
= œÄ(RsinŒ∏+RcosŒ∏dŒ∏)¬≤ - œÄR¬≤sin¬≤Œ∏
= œÄR¬≤(sin¬≤Œ∏ + cos¬≤Œ∏(dŒ∏)¬≤ +2sinŒ∏cosŒ∏dŒ∏) - œÄR¬≤sin¬≤Œ∏

As (dŒ∏)¬≤‚âà0,
Area of the shadow of the ring
= 2œÄR¬≤sinŒ∏cosŒ∏dŒ∏
= œÄR¬≤sin(2Œ∏)dŒ∏

Let Œ± be the angle of the ring, and Œ∏ be the angle of the ring corresponding to the shadow.

Hence,

I like the problem. The corresponding ring is the one at doble of the angel theta.

1) 2piRsin(tetha)

3) 2piR^2sin(tetha)cos(theta)d-tetha=1/2(2piR^2sin(2tetha)d-tetha)
4) To each ring at tetha correspond a second ring at 2xtetha
5) While tetha goes from zero to pi/2, 2thetha goes from zero to pi. So, the north hemisphere is sweept with theta, while 2tetha sweept the whole sphere. And finally, tetha going from p/2 to pi, the south hemisphere, 2tetha goes from pi to 2pi. There is the factor 4.

I would recommend someone like Bill Bryson for example for english students, as he uses a wide , yet precise vocabulary and colloquialisms from the modern era.

textdisplay: 12:16 To get a clean image (An image identical to what you would get if you were to see those spirals in real life), you have to have each pixel take several random samples inside of itself and average the color. You can't just take an 8k image and downscale to 4k, that will just push the Moire patterns further. But, if each pixel had its own random sampling, it would render more like "film", which does not show Moire patterns, matching our eyes.

author: @KieranLeCam
textdisplay:
I may be saying something "nooby" here, or have misunderstood... but I would explain Dirichlet's theorem differently.

You should expect every mod class to have the same amount of numbers regardless of whether or not they are primes. And the explanation is simple. It's because of modulo. The operation modulo, or in the video "mod" achieves 2 things:

1) it reduces a whole number, no matter how small or large to a residue.

2) that residue is automatically between 0 and your modulo.

You essentially reduce all numbers to a residue between 0 and your modulo. And why would all numbers, in any particular base, have a preferred residue? All whole numbers...exist on the whole number line.

Prime numbers are the same, you've defined the class mods you should expect to have primes in beforehand (1,3,7,9), and as every modulo number along the whole number line has, in any unchanging base, the same amount of residues, you should expect an equal distribution. In other words, the equal distribution should be a property of the modulo operation itself in any unchanging, regular counting system with any unchanging base. Again I might be wrong, or perhaps I'm accidentally saying the same thing as the math I don't quite understand. But it makes logical sense to me.

author: @Toztabud
textdisplay: Imagine you have 2 pairs of parallel lines of infinite length that are perpendicular to each other. form a rectangle with the four corners as the points where the lines intersect. Now imagine you have a loop of arbitrary length that passes through said points. If you stretch or skew each pair of parallel lines you can prove that if a loop has two perpendicular rectangles of alternating length to width ratio, then a square should be found by scaling parallel lines between them. Some 'loops' such as an equilateral triangle may not have squares of area greater than 0 if they do not have integer coordinates on the x/y plane.

author: @lone0017
textdisplay:
For the excercise at 12:27, there is this explanation that I like to use (because it's more visual):
Imagine you start at the top of the triangle and travel downward. Each step you can either turn left or right. So at 5th row, 3rd element (counting from 0), you have taken 5 steps in total, 3 of which are right turns. And there are "5 choose 3" ways to get there. But you can only get there by turning right at 4th row, 2nd element or by turning left at 4th row, 3rd element. Hence (n k) = (n-1 k) + (n-1 k-1).

author: @XYZ_youtube
textdisplay:
11:18 correct me if I am wrong but you cannot calculate n choose k if k>n. 2 choose 4 would for example be calculated like this:
(2!)/(4!*((2-4)!))=(2!)/(4!*(-2)!)
Factorial cannot be calculated for negative whole numbers. ("Lines that connect" made a video on how to calculate the factorial for other numbers than just natural numbers.)

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
By convention, (n choose k) for k > n would be 0. Which makes sense, how many ways can you choose a subset of size 5 from 3 elements? Zero! It's impossible.

Incidentally, when you extend the definition of factorial to negative values, and just plug in the formula, it's consistent with this convention.

author: @KieranLeCam
textdisplay:
I was curious about why we get 2 for the planar graph equation. Edit: I wrote this comment before seeing your explanation, but I think the explanation in your video is missing an intriguing fact, read on!

It's because vertices always go up by 1, but depending on where it's placed, (assuming we've already placed 3 vertices minimum, to manifest the first zone) will increase the amount of edges, by 1 more than the number of zones it creates.

Example: a vertice creating 5 edges will automatically create 4 new zones.

Add that difference of 1, to the infinite zone we would normally not count, you get 2.

What this means is that every vertice added creates a division. If you ignore how the division is made, with how many divisions of area, by subtracting the amount of new zones to the number of new edges created by this intent to divide, you end up with 1.

1 division.

So this constant in the planar equation actually stands for Division itself. I just thought that was interesting. üòä

Assume you are find
f(0) = 0, f(1) = 1, f(2) =2,f(3) = 3.......and you continue this for 1000 times, still same pattern;

author: @thompsguy
textdisplay:
I decided to finally stick a problem to the end, on my own, with this one, and after about 8 or 9 total hours (over several days of course, haha) I found a solution to this problem using nested sums instead, as the extent of my knowledge is Calculus 2. My solution, preceded by its process, goes as follows:

"To connect all points to each other, each point is connected to all unconnected point in clockwise sequence. The point being connected to other points is the active point, p_a; the final point in sequence is p_f. The number of sections created (in other words, added to, and not including, the total number of sections prior to connection) between p_a and some target point p_t is equal to the number of connections made between points p_(n<a) and points p_(a<n<t) (where n is some whole number), plus one for the "base" connection between p_a and p_t. Such a number of connections may be represented by [p_(n<a) * p_(a<n<t) + 1]."

After jotting down the notes above subsequent to a couple rough drafts on the problem that were either incomplete or just wrong, I arrived via some trial, error, and intuition at the function below:

"s(f) = 1 + Sum(Lower: i=1 ; Upper: f-1){Sum(Lower: n=i+1; Upper: f){(i-1)(n-1-i)+1}}" (I realize this is a mess without the special Desmos notation, I can provide a picture of my notebook if needed)

I think this demonstrates that math is more open-ended than how it's taught in K-12, and that math seems to "overlap" on itself from time-to-time. Thank you for these math videos, they're largely what's given me an interest for pure math

author: @harshitgoyal3394
textdisplay: Can someone point out where in Alice's method has it been used that all rotations have equal probability density (explained as the normal vector can fall anywhere onto the sphere..explained in the video). Because for a sphere, the Expected projected shadow area is independent of the distribution of rotations (as any rotation results in the same shadow area). For the cube however say we have a distribution that has probability 1 for the square faces being aligned parallel to the xy yz zx planes (take only one specific of the many ways to do it by, one you give a fixed numbering to the faces ) and 0 probability to every other alignment. This distribution gives expected shadow area s^2 which is not  what's obtained in the video (it wasn't expected also as this distribution here isn't uniform but I want to ask where did alice's method use the fact that the distribution is uniform)?

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay: It comes very subtly during the part where she goes from adding terms row by row to column by column.  This implicitly assumes that the distribution over orientations will not change if you premultiply them all by some rotation. For example, in saying that the distribution of shadows for one face of the cube is necessarily the same as the other, it means applying the transformation that takes one face to the other will not alter the distribution.

author: @Ricocossa1
textdisplay:
My physicist intuition tells me of another way to justify that the answer should be proportional to the area of the solid: there is only one scale in the problem, so the answer should be O(1)s^2, unless some hidden Symmetry makes the constant not O(1).

In the problem of a light source at finite distance. If we have a large hierarchy of scales, ie. D >> s, where D is the height of the light source, then it should be possible to find an elegant solution as a perturbative expansion in the ratio s/D. So the answer should look like s^2/2( 1+ O(1)s/D + ... ). If D is of order s however, then the answer would look completely different.

author: @unforseenconsequense
textdisplay:
At uni it really could feel like every lecturer loved showing how they were Alice, then they would give you a problem set to be like Bob, though with a question at the end that required an Alice moment of insight. This Alice moment for the whole class may as well have been called a Google moment because they always used some beautiful formula that hinged on many leaps of logic and assumptions, as a student though it would have been much nicer if they taught the Alice moments with small ideas first, like here where Alice worked out that the top and bottom 3 faces both covered the shadow.

But at uni it felt like you just needed to be Bob until you needed to find Alice's generalization to any convex shape at the end. I was doing Engineering though and we almost always got insufferable maths dept lecturers that never had practical examples to show (even though they exist and are very helpful tools).

author: @patriciawulf3830
textdisplay:
The method I would use first when posed the original question. Critiques are welcome, obviously time is one:
My method:
1. Find the triangular number with 2000 as its base side.
2. Every number at or below that one that ends in a 5 or 0 will be divisible by 5, so for every 10 numbers, 2 of them will be divisible by 5. That means that if you start at the first number divisible by 5 at or below triangular(2000), 1/5 of that will be the amount of sums divisible by 5.
3. For each sum found in step 2, find all the combinations that could sum to that.
4. Cross out duplicate combinations if you used a disorderly method.

author: @Mothuzad
textdisplay:
Still early in the video, but I wanted to share my thoughts about how to motivate the application of a generating function to this problem.

If you already have a polynomial whose properties correspond to the solution to a simpler version of the problem, say a set of 1 through 4, and if you know how multiplying by a binomial and taking the resulting coefficients can act like counting the number of corresponding elements in your solution, then you might notice that you can expand the 1-to-4 solution into a 1-to-5 solution by multiplying by a binomial representing the two possibilities of either including 5 (x^5) or excluding the 5 (x^0 = 1, aka the Identity operation which simply copies the solution to the simpler problem into the calculation of our new solution).

A better way to explain this might be to look at an even simpler version first, such as a nearly trivial set {1}.

My thoughts here are motivated by a computer science background, but the underlying technique is one we simply "stole" from mathematics, and also bears a striking similarity to induction. There are also hints of topology here, since we're finding a way to treat binomial multiplication as informationally equivalent to counting subset sums.

Maybe the rest of the video will already say all this. üòÖ I guess I'll find out soon enough.

author: @stevezagieboylo9172
textdisplay:
As I write this I've only gotten far enough to frame the problem, and I absolutely don't see where imaginary numbers are going to come into play. But my approach below seems like it is going to lead to a solution.

In the numbers from 1-2000, we only care about their value mod 5

400 of them are zero mod 5. We don't even need to think about these. We can just take our result from the other groups and multiply by the combinations of these numbers, which is 2^400.

I was going to use the typical mod 5 values, but I think it is better to identify them as 1, 2, -2, and -1 as their mod 5 values. This will make symmetry easier. Of course, there are 400 of each value.

Consider the 2^400 ways I could choose subsets from just the 1 group. How many of them produce each mod 5 value? It isn't clear to me, though obviously it isn't evenly distributed, since 2^400 is not divisible by 5. I think if I take the sum when N goes from 0 to 79 of 200 choose 5N+1, then 200 choose 5N+2, etc. I wonder if that simplifies or if it becomes a mess.

Yeah, it's a mess.

OK, that's all I got so far. üôÇ Now to continue the video.

author: @Achrononmaster
textdisplay: @17:00 ok, so maybe only a pro would get that bit, but using rotations in a plane to ask questions in number theory is pervasive, it's basically the essence of the Riemann Hypothesis. So no need to talk so incredulously? It's like the old A.Clark line, or Grothendieck, which I might paraphrase: To any sufficiently knowledgeable mathematician every Olympiad problem looks like a tinker toy puzzle. Or, The Rising Sea lifts all tricky math puzzles up to mere hand waving (which your students find completely mystifying). ;-)

author: @Achrononmaster
textdisplay: @7:00 but wait! Your "motivation" is clear and beautiful. How would you go about forming an equation with coefficients representing counts of discrete quantities? You'd choose a basis set of functions with unique expansions, and form the product, no one in their right mind would go Legendre, Fourier or Hemite etc, you'd go for the monogenic polynomials for starters. It's not too big a leap of faith.

author: @Attemptedburger
textdisplay:
ok, so I'm pausing to try and guess, so let me work through this from the point right after you said "please do pause"



ok, I can't figure it out, but my two most interesting observations are that

1. a cone and a plane can both be revolutions of 2d counterparts, triangles and lines.

2. I know if you cut a triangle the end you cut off will fit backwards because the edge is guaranteed to be the same length along the cut, and that the cone is guaranteed to be a triangle from all angles when viewed along the plane.

3. a sphere that is tangent to the cone can be tangent to the intersection of the plane and the cone at two points, and will be centered on the intersection as well. because the cone and the plane are both symmetrical in this axis, their intersection will be symmetrical in this axis as well.

4. because the intersection is symmetrical across the shortest path through the center and the longest path through the center is perpendicular, I think, but I'm not quite smart enough to piece together at this hour, that any line that passes through the center can be reflected by the long path to show a symmetry that means the cone could be sliced by the plane and then rotated 180 around an axis pependicular to the plane so that the shapes on either side of the slice match back up, showing that the shape is fully symmetrical along the long path of the intersection.

5. math in my head is hard, and I deserve a gold star for trying this

6. I don't know how the spheres help exactly, but It looks like they are tangent to the plane at the foci of the intersection.

I'm resuming the video now.

Tried to generalize to points that are not infinitely far away but not sure how to do it. I think it has something to do with how the direction of the plane that is preserved under projection from a point at infinity now changes a little because of the slant of the cone.

Triangles (including right angles).

For me... I realize that, on the cone, the distance between a circle above the elipse and a circle below the elipse (measured along a ray anchored at the vertex of the cone) is a constant. From this we see that any curve which passes around the cone has the property that the sum of the distance to the two circles is constant. Then I am lead to the spheres for which the cicles are tangent.

This is interesting as it introduces a family of new conic sections which are not described by a plane (slicing a cone) but by anything slicing a cone.

author: @pauselab5569
textdisplay:
for the specific 2 types of jewls problem, you can find a more self contained proof but it doesn't generalize well.
note that making any 2 cuts create 3 complementary subsets of the original set of say order n. the 3 subsets need to be seperated to 2 people, and so it has to be 2 to one of them and 1 to the other and so one subset must have order n/2.
now think about a string of 0 and 1s that has n digits. start by looking at the first n/2 terms and note how many 0 and 1s there are. if that isn't a solution, move the whole subset to the right by 1 digit. repeating this will make sure that there is a way to seperate the necklace to 2 people.

author: @GopherpilledTunneler
textdisplay: I thought of an interesting way to think about the 2-jewel problem. Make the jewels into colored segments, then connect the ends of the string together to make a circle. Then pick a color and find the centroid of all the segments of that color (the circle excluding the segments of the other color). This gives you a point where all of the lines that go through it split the color 50%. Then make a line that goes through the center of the circle and the centroid of one of the colors. This splits the circle 50% and also the proportions of the gems are equal on both sides, so you can mark where the line cuts the circle and undo the string connection. This gives 2 cuts at most for the 2-jewel problem. Maybe this can be generalized.

I have Another crazy Visual proof of this, Iet me explain:

Imagine you have that good ol' 2d plane, with 4 circles... note the diameter of Inner Circle.... Now imagine the 3D version of this, just pulling of from that 2D plane....

NOW this 3D sphere have a Larger Diameter than, it's 2D counterpart which is At the Bottom of the cube... this is because by Introducing a 3rd Dimension You allowed that 2D inner Circle to "expand" more, and turn into a Expanded Sphere...

Now you can go higher, By Introducing 4th Dimension, you'll Allow that 3D sphere to grow, and turn into a 4D hypersphere... and so on

author: @rossholst5315
textdisplay:
I have a question about what essentially is mean by the term dimension?

I have seen a 3D object as it changes over time used to represent a fourth dimension visually because we typically struggle to visualize higher order equations.

However that got me to wondering what makes time as a variable special? Could we not instead use position vs temperature or any other tracked variable to represent a 4th dimension?

Which then yields the question does the term dimension really just refer to how much information we are wanting to track simultaneously?

And that made me wonder if you could use things like color changes and/or brightness to depict higher order functions along with the normal spacial representations moving over time?

Could we not assign a specific color to a dimension like Yellow for a 4th order, red for 5th order, and blue for 6th order where the intensity (brightness) changes based on the magnitude?

Would things like this work to try to map higher order functions?

author: @robfatland
textdisplay: just saw this video - yay algorithm. And it reminds me of a problem / solution / extension. I tap out the abbreviated version in case it is of interest. Problem: kid carrying a 5-foot metal post wants to board a bus. Bus driver says 'no carry on items over 3 feet in any dimension allowed'. What is the kid to do? Solution: Of course the kid ducks into a (say FedX) shipping store and purchases a 3 x 3 x 3 foot box. Now the kid is depending on the bus driver to use the implicit box-based coordinate system. Extension: Suppose FedX has started selling 4D boxes. Or 20-dimensional boxes. Is it true that the kid can purchase a very "small" box -- say 4 inches on a side for each of 20 dimensions where this box will accommodate the five foot post?

author: @Dexuz
textdisplay:
To shed some light on the apparent impossibility of the 4-dimensional sphere to touch the box, you just need to realize how the 3-dimensional example would already appear impossible from a 2-dimensional perspective; the center sphere being that big in 3D, if put into the 2D example, would be clipping through the 4 outer spheres (circles).

In other words, this experiment on our 3D world does in fact break physics from the perspective of a 2D world.

author: @santerisatama5409
textdisplay:
At 5D, the 1/5 of outer sphere corresponds with 9^2/10^2 - 1/2 = 81/100-50/100 = 31/100 of inner sphere. I find it easier to think with fractions instead of decimals. The 9^2 nominator at 10/2=5/1 helps to understand why the break out happens at 2*5D
The inner radius SQRT(5)-1 directs thoughts to the following question:

The question about the image at 11:15 has an interesting related question, is there some special projective geometry perspective, from which the furthermost line segment of the horizontal triangle behind the vertical triangle forms a golden section with the hypotenusa of the horizontal triangle?

Square roots have repeating representations as continued fractions and as path information in Stern-Brocot type structures, where with Farey addition, 5/1 is the mediant of 1/0 + 4/1 and 1/5 is the mediant of 1/4 + 0/1. It can be very useful to think of Stern-Brocot fractions as a binary tree of tau turns of a full rotation.

PS: A wild conjecture: the exponential/logarithmic drop towards zero after the breakout is somehow closely related to the sequence 1^n+2^n+3^n.

author: @lexibyday9504
textdisplay: I can't find it anymore but somewhere on youtube was a video about tiling a space in higher dimensions. It occured to me, and I'm sure people smarter than me thought of it first, but this is how we find the limit of the multiverse. What is the highest spacial dimension possible? We look for a dimension that cannot be tiled no matter what. Because if no shape in that dimension can tile space in that dimension then no shape in that dimension can be cut up into units of any size and that would mean the dimension has no length, no height, no mass, no speed... there is no measuring it in any way and a thing that can't be measured does not exist in any meaningful way.

author: @oliverdowning1543
textdisplay: Just to hammer home the "not needing to visualise to think visually" point. I experience aphantasia (which means my imagination and memory lacks, or has very weak, visual imagery. In short, I can't visualise) and yet I have no problem following your visual geometric arguments, even without the diagrams in front of me because of things like spatial reasoning and just generally the ability to build intuition using these diagrams and animations. I can refer to and use the concept of a number line and compare the positions of points on it without ever having to visualise a line and I feel I am at no disadvantage when using this concept; it's a fundamentally visual tool but I simply cannot visualise it as a result of my state of being (which is quite likely related to my autism according to some interesting research I saw with brain scans but that's beside the point) and yet the tool still works to build intuition by defining relationships in an intuitive*spacial* manner.

author: @General12th
textdisplay: Nice! It's good to remember that coordinate systems and geometric reasoning are good for more than just spatial dimensions. All sorts of properties are orthogonal to each other -- for example, temperature, pressure, and humidity, or health, attack, and cooldown rate -- and that means they can be described with this kind of logic.

author: @Lleanlleawrg
textdisplay:
The isosceles triangle "proof" is kind of interesting..
Drawing the perpendicular bisector of BC splits it into two lengths of equal length. With you so far.
Bisecting angle A into the alpha angles does create angles alpha that are are half of A.
Marking the intersection of the bisectors as P.. fair enough.
Drawing the lines PE and PF is where things start to get interesting. Since these lines are different lengths, and AE / AF are also different lengths, yet you use the idea that AFP and AEP are the same to try to convince us that this means AB has to be equal to BC, which does not follow.

author: @JJ-fr2ki
textdisplay:
Vision misleads, but the foundations of formal math arise from sensation by us or the ancestors that passed these brain powers through our genes. Charismatic mathematical programs such as Set Theory carry on despite contradiction and the revision of the concept of function and alternative geometries cause us to distrust the synthetic a priori (or fill- in your source of knowledge of forms).
I am a workaday applied mathematician, not a daily skeptic, but haunted by skepticism, mainly of a Wittgensteinian or Ian Hacking or Lakatos sort. Math doesn‚Äôt need foundations or unity to be true, but conceptual clean-up of the sorts in Mark Wilson‚Äôs papers on Heaviside should be funded. Too much is bet on Category Theory, and it does not directly address the specter of skepticism that concerns me.

Very easy to disprove the first one.

Step 1. Understand that the Radius that extends from the center of the sphere to the surface of the sphere is different to the "radius" that is curved on the sphere surface.
They have very different lengths.


Lets call them center radius, & curved radius

Step 2:
Everything is fine until he equates the curved radius to be equal to the center radius when he derives the formula
(œÄ/2)√ó R.
As the circumference of the sphere, which he found first is found using the center radius
He can't then deride œÄ/2 using the circumference of the center radius
for the length of the curved radius since r is completely different.

author: @kora.costa.
textdisplay:
i had different reasoning for why the proof was wrong, but i'm not sure if i'm right or not:

let the point at which the line passing through A and P intersects the line BC be called point G.
Point G does not equal point D, therefore the triangles ADB and ADC have the same angle at point A and a common side length |AG|. However, as point G does not equal point D, |BD| does not equal |DC|, so ADB and ADC are not congruent, therefore the triangle ABC is not isosceles

did i miss or overlook something? someone please let me know!

author: @Muhahahahaz
textdisplay:
1:18 before looking at the answer, here‚Äôs what I came up with:

Basically, this problem boils down to taking convex hulls, starting with Hull(S) and working our way down from there (intuitively speaking, this is just the ‚Äúsmallest‚Äù convex polygon that contains all the points in S). Ultimately, we will take a nested sequence of convex hulls. Each time we find a new hull H, we will remove the points of S that live on the boundary of H (which are exactly the vertices of H), then take the convex hull of the remaining points. Eventually, we will be left with a set of 0-2 points that cannot form any further hulls (call this set Z), and we will be left with a single, smallest convex hull, call it H*

Select P to be any vertex of H* (which must be in S), and L to be any line that goes through the inside of H* (for sake of simplicity, we can choose L such that it does not intersect any other points of S, since S is finite). After that, our ‚Äúwindmill‚Äù process will force L to stay inside of H* forever, in the sense that the intersection of L with H* will always be a nontrivial line segment (i.e., not a single point). Furthermore, L will hit every point of S infinitely many times (including the points of Z), all while remaining ‚Äúlocated‚Äù inside of H*‚Ä¶ Proof to follow


First, consider the scenario where the points of S happen to form a single convex polygon, call it H for Hull. Then we can simply take P to be any point of S, and L can essentially be any line (though for simplicity, suppose we avoid lines that hit any of the other vertices). If this line L is completely outside H (in the sense that it only intersects H at P), then the windmill process will simply take L on a cyclic tour around the outside of H, eventually arriving back at our starting pivot P. (Feel free to consider small examples of 2-4 points for a moment to see this)

On the other hand, if L begins ‚Äúinside‚Äù H (in the sense that it intersects H at exactly 2 points, since H is convex), then L will forever remain ‚Äúinside‚Äù H. Ultimately, L will take a cyclic tour around the inside of H, before returning to the starting pivot P. (Either way, our windmill process works, but it is instructive to consider the difference between L being inside vs outside H for such a simple S, before moving on to more complicated scenarios)


But what if S were to also contain some points either inside or outside of H? For instance, suppose S consists of the vertices of a single equilateral triangle, plus one point (C) in the center of it. Well, if we select P to be one of the vertices, and L to start outside the triangle, then L will forever remain outside the triangle, and will never hit C

On the other hand, if we select P = C (with L being any line that doesn‚Äôt hit the vertices), then the windmill process actually works out (in fact, we could actually choose any P to be any point of S, so long as we choose L to be inside the triangle, rather than starting outside). I leave it to the reader to ponder/verify this 4 point case, since we are about to show much more general results anyway (this was just an introduction to thinking about the problem)


Lemma 0 (Inside Now = Inside Forever): Let H be a convex polygon, whose vertices are in S. If P is a vertex of H, and L is any line through P that intersects H at more than one point, then the windmill process will leave L ‚Äútrapped‚Äù inside H forever. (That is, L will always intersect H at more than one point, at every moment, of every rotation about each pivot point)

Proof: In the intro, we saw how this works when S = H, but what if there are points inside H? (Or even outside, though that won‚Äôt actually matter)



Lemma 1: Let H_1 and H_2 be two convex polygons, whose vertices are in S, such that H_1 is contained in the interior of H_2. If P is a vertex of H_1, and L is any line that intersects H_1 only at P, then the windmill process on P and L will force L inside of H_1 (after a finite number of steps), and

author: @loogi_is_die
textdisplay:
I don't want to look at the solution yet but
Is it so that the flip of your coin makes all the coins next to the key have the lowest probability of being that way from the start
For example if 7 out of 9 of the coins next to the key are heads you should flip the last one so all of them are heads
There might be also some hijinks in how you define being around a coin to maximise the probability
Since the bigger the length it stretches makes the "weight" of your flip matter less while making it smaller makes it more likely for other coins to have a likely pattern
Ill just go on a limb and say a 3 by 3 area around the coin is the best solution

author: @KingWesleyIV
textdisplay:
I hate riddles like these because they all ignore 2 glaring issues.
1. The way the riddle is worded makes the pattern always seem random. Which means the initial conditions of the board are not ever predictable and therefore always random and always unsolvable.
2. The second prisoner is just a random person with no idea what you're going to do.
In 63 out of 64 cases of the riddle, you and prisoner 2 will always be stuck there in prison. Only 1 random guess with ensure your freedom because it's relying on random people, and random starting conditions. The riddle is that the riddle itself is lying to you to make you think it's random.

author: @Calculsus
textdisplay: Another way is by using the fact that any integer square is a sum of odd numbers. Since we are summing two squares together the smallest term squared (if it is odd) becomes the next term in the partial sum of odd numbers for the larger term to produce the c term. So 3^2+4^2=5^2 is 1+3+5   + 1+3+5+7 = 1+3+5+7+(1+3+5)=1+3+5+7+9

author: @Muhahahahaz
textdisplay:
I‚Äôve seen this formula for Pythagorean triples, but it seemed absolutely mystical until now‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs literally just the result of squaring any Gaussian integer a + bi ! So easy lol

(And the conditions on a and b simply guarantee that the triple is primitive, and doesn‚Äôt involve any zero-length sides)

These sort of origin proofs/demonstrations should be absolutely mandatory for all math pedagogy. Doing it any other way is just unmotivated equations and theorems

author: @Muhahahahaz
textdisplay:
Give a man an equation, and he‚Äôll compute Pythagorean triples for a day‚Ä¶

Teach a man to derive that equation, and he‚Äôll compute them for a lifetime!

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
For the question at the end, the intended answer is not "the handle lets you go in three dimensions", because for that matter a sphere is three-dimensional, but you could never solve it there. Think about what makes the surface of the mug (or a doughnut) distinct from that of a sphere, and how that affects the argument. I think I went years knowing that Euler's formula looks different on different surfaces but had never really thought through why. In particular, the exercise will set good intuitions for learning about homology, if that's something in your future.

Also, my apologies for two names typos here: Veritasium, and James Grime (evidently I accidentally pluralized him to "Grimes"). That's what I get for throwing on titles late at night, my bad!

To everyone saying "I can't believe the math guys hadn't heard of this puzzle before". I agree that would be surprising! It's a very famous puzzle in math circles. Maybe I accidentally obfuscated this too much in the editing, but all the math guys most certainly were familiar with the puzzle. I mean, three of them make and sell the thing! This is why their contributions were either direct explanations or jokes. Derek and Henry had seen it before, but long enough ago that it still involved a little trial and error.

author: @pablorosada9788
textdisplay: Euler's formula depends on the fact that, if you connect and edge to a vertex that already exists, a new face HAS to be created. But in a torus, there is a set of edges that can be connected to existing vertexes that do not make a new face. Namely, the edges that go around the entire surface of the torus. This allows the creation of a 5th face with just 9 edges.

author: @RainAngel111
textdisplay:
I think the difference on the mug is that you're creating a new region in the third dimension.

I paused this video to try and solve it on paper and I guess you needed to define the rules a little more, because after my first failure, I decided not to treat the houses as points, but squares. Essentially if you moved a line through a point, you cannot move any other line through that point without creating an intersection. However if you treat the house as a 2 dimensional object with width and height, you can pass multiple lines through the house without intersecting the lines.

I think that's kind of a nice symmetry with the real solution, which is if you think something is impossible, just try adding another dimension

Look what is on the video at 5:17. Then think: there is always at min 1 point of intersection between lines. What do we build when there is an intersection of roads and we do not want cars to hit each other? Bridge. Where is a bridge on a mug? ...

All you have to do is just squeeze, and draw around like a maze to recreate 5:17 on a mug with 2 lines intersecting on the mug handle. One goes on the handle, another below it...

author: @bettyg7710
textdisplay: Not impossible, think like a computer buss and it solves the problem, three straight lines one for each utility. The house are stacked in a row parallel to the utility line. Each separate house attaches to the buss at a different point. All three utilizes are now connected to all three houses with no crossing lines. In fact this is the way it is done in the real world as well.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Some notes on the intended use of this series. I was deliberate in using the phrase "tour of differential equations", as opposed to "introduction to" or "essence of". I think of the relationship between watching this series and taking a course as being analogous to the relationship between touring a city vs. living in it. You'll certainly see a lot less with the tour since you're spending less time overall, but the goal will be to walk around some of the most noteworthy monuments and town centers with helpful context given to you by a guide. And just as someone who lives in a city may very well have never gone to visit some of the historical sites of their town, despite living there for years, many differential equations students may not always get the chance to zoom out and appreciate the central cornerstones of the subject amidst all the computations they are learning.


I hope you enjoy the tour, but at the same time know that it is, by design, very different from taking courses on the subject.

author: @Alan-zf2tt
textdisplay:
Ah - about 06:50 this highlights one of my favorite rants in whole of math at the moment. And that is why use tangent based explanation when a secant based explanation seems more robust with helpful implications going forward regarding discontinuities and so forth? Plus! Around a wobble of some sorts in a graph it seems easier to adapt secant as an approximation of tangent at a single point. Then, perhaps, in a small interval around a single point the secant exists either side of that point.
The tangent approach seems naively risky, and some may say there is no harm in that, because it only considers tangent on one side of a point and not other side(s). and may be extended easier into multiple dimensions too?
PS: the example about 12:50, to me, is just crying out for secant linearity based on outer two values compared to inner value.

author: @pedrosso8995
textdisplay:
The moment I understood the introduction of the sine way I finally found out the relevance of fourier series. 3B1B had already given everything necessary before, that
1. f(x., t=0) can be written as a sum of sines
2. sines are often useful in differential equations because sin''(x)=-sin(x)
3. a sum of a solution is still a solution
->
the solution with the initial condition of f(x,0) can be written as the sum of sine solutions with the help of fourier series.

You mention someone will not Boundary conditions not only in heat terminology but also in hydrology because we use Fourier transformation ~also~! Whether F(t) is periodic or not, a complent description of F(t) can be given using sines and cosines.
I am delighted you mention the same basic thread runs through most branches of physical science, from light, accustics through engineering, fluid mechanics to quantum mechanics. Also like you illustrated frequently happens that greater insight into the physical procesess which are described by Fourier transform can be achieved by a diagram rather a formula. As civil engineer (subpart of hydrology) we in 90% use some functions in researching which occure again and again in physics and extremly useful like The 'top-hat' function like Fourier pair obtained by integration, The Gaussian function, The Direc or Double Dirac function. We must be greatfull for the science, scientifics, that use and research transformable certain conditions, known as Dirichlet conditions as well as other one.

I think why it's hard to grasp these things is that when you look at everything at once there's just too much to try to make sense of. while in reality you can just do a whole bunch of simple equations over a time period to not alone get there but also describe how something is changing and using that information for your modeling.

this, has been the most satisfying part about diving into maths thus far. like you said, these videos give you the confidence to try to tackle problems. and the more i'm learning about maths the more I realize it's not really about trying to make sense of numbers. it's about thinking of a practical way to solve problems and built up a toolkit for doing so

author: @Mageling55
textdisplay: We've started here with relatively simple boundary conditions. A particularly common in practice (albeit so common that we've pre-solved it for a range of variables and use simple approximations or lookup tables) is fluid flowing in an unisulated pipe. You have forced convection on the inside of a pipe: dT/dt|r=r_i = -kv_fluid (T(r_i) - T_fluid), free convection (ugly perturbation theory equation at r=r_o, and steady state if your lucky (dT/dt = 0). There are lots of interesting boundary conditions that radically change the solutions, so having a tool this flexible is insanely powerful

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Complex exponents are very important for differential equations, so I wanted to be sure to have a quick reference for anyone uncomfortable with the idea. Plus, as an added benefit, this gives an exercise in what it feels like to reason about a differential equation using a phase space, even if none of those words are technically used.


As some of you may know, Euler's formula is already covered on this channel, but from a very different perspective whose main motive was to give an excuse to introduce group theory. Hope you enjoy both!

author: @ganonschlachter
textdisplay: So does multiplying a number by i/2 rotate it around 45 degrees?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
no, that still rotates it 90 degrees but halves its size

let's say you wanna rotate a number z by 180 degrees, first you would rotate once by 90 degrees (z*i), and then once more (z*i*i)
so, to rotate 180, you don't multiply by 2i, you multiply by i squared which is the same as multiplying twice by i
likewise, if you wanted to rotate 45 degrees, you'd need to multiply by a number that multiplies with itself to get i, because doing it twice should get you back to 90 degrees

and this number is the square root of i

author: @WhyDoesThisHappen
textdisplay:
but why e?
e is a constant, it's like about 2.71 or somthing, right?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay: he explained at the start of the video

author: @WhyDoesThisHappen
textdisplay:
@@2fifty533 okay
but WHY
WHY e???

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
@@WhyDoesThisHappen because the function e^x is its own derivative, in other words, the rate of increase in the result (or speed) as x increases is always equal to the current position at any given time

and the speed of e^2x has the same property, except the speed is twice the current position

when you do e^ix, the velocity is always the current position but rotated 90 degrees, which results in a circle being drawn

textdisplay: He's a helluva nice guy for making this video, and he has come up with an excellent set of graphics tools that communicate very well, however, I find it really annoying that the name he chose for the STATE VECTOR (with a ‚û° appearing above it) was the lower case 'v'. I mean, most people are going to look at that and immediately say to themselves "AH! that means VELOCITY!" and, in this video, they would be wrong. The subsequent derivative (of v with a ‚û°appearing above it) IS the velocity (of v with a ‚û°appearing above it.) Apparently, he chose 'v' as a general way to represent the word 'vector', however, v is so often used to denote velocity, that it really makes for a lot of confusion.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Some added notes (copied from the pinned commend to the next video):

1) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ‚âà x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

2) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word ‚Äúphase space‚Äù to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. You should know, though, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the ‚Äúphase space‚Äù here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term ‚Äúconfiguration space‚Äù, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we do next video.

author: @LKC9215
textdisplay:
"For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count!"

As pi is irrational, doesn't that mean that every possible number can be found in there as there is no point at which the digits of pi would start to repeat? Sure, it would probably be too far in to matter by then, but yes, the last n digits of pi being 9 would be true at some point.

author: @MAYOJAMESD
textdisplay: @@LKC9215 I'm not sure how true this is. Just because a sequence of numbers is infinite does not mean that it contains every imaginable combination of numbers. For example, there is an infinity of numbers between 1 and 0. There's .0001, there's 1/3, you got pi over ten, etc. Yet, even given the infinite count of numbers you get between 0 and 1, you can never get any number larger than one. There is an infinite number of numbers, yet not all numbers are included. So even though Pi is irrational, I don't think it necessarily means that you get every possible combination of digits. In fact, since by the very definition of it being infinite we can never create all of its digits, there will always be some combination of digits that we cannot give a proof for being included in pi.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Some added notes (I may come back to add more later):

1) There's a slight error in the video where I say the answer is floor(pi/theta). Really it should be ceil(pi/theta) - 1, to account for the cases where pi/theta is an integer. For example, when the mass ratio is 1, theta will be pi/4, so pi/theta is 4, but there are 3 clacks. As stated in the video, though, you still think about this is "how many times can you add theta to itself before it surpasses (or equals) pi?"


2) What I animate here as I say "angle of reflection" and "angle of incidence" differs a little with convention. Typically in optics, you look at the angle between the beam and a line perpendicular to the mirror, rather than with the mirror itself.

3) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ‚âà x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

4) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word ‚Äúphase space‚Äù to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. This is common in the context of math, but you should know, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the ‚Äúphase space‚Äù here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term ‚Äúconfiguration space‚Äù, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we did here.

I hope you enjoyed this little sequence. I still get happy whenever I think about the phenomenon and the various explanations for it.

author: @Curious_Southerner
textdisplay: Grant, thank you for this beautiful video! I have a naive question: we stated that when the polarized light goes through the solution, certain wavelengths get rotated more than others. However, if we were to look at the end of the pole, we would still observe white light, indicating that the superposition is similar to the initial linearly polarized light. Is it expected or intuitive that the superposition of the income light that is in the same plane should be the same as the superposition of the wavelengths that are rotated and are in different planes? Sorry if it is a confusing question; I can clarify if needed.

author: @lunkel8108
textdisplay: The wavelengths will be polarized in different directions. But your eyes can't tell the difference between differently polarized light. The outgoing light is "similar" to the incoming light in that it contains the exact same wavelengths at (pretty much) the exact same amplitudes, so it looks the same to our eyes. That's all they measure.

author: @samculver8279
textdisplay:
I love the video, but Im skeptical about the explanation for the diagonal bands. In the graphic the viewer is shown very close to a very large tube, which makes up maybe 40 degrees of their field of view. This would correspond to a large change in perceived angle by the viewer, and would be a plausible explanation for the strips.

In the actual video though the tube is very small compared to the field of view of the camera, it maybe makes up a 3 or four degree angle for the field of view. This would correspond to an equally small change in perception of the direction the light is polarized, again maybe 3 or 4 degrees. (Comparing the top of the tube to the bottom in a vertical strip). Lets compare that to the visual evidence we see in the video.

We see the light go through nearly a full rotation as it travels through the length of the tube, meaning it changes its angle about 300-400 degrees along the full length of the tube. (for one wavelength of light, each wavelength having a unique total change in angle as we saw).

Just from eyeballing it, it looks like the bands of equal intensity light travel about a sixth to a quarter of the tube as they go from the top of the tube to the bottom. From my earlier aprox that would correspond to somewhere around a 50 degree change in perceived polarization angle from the top to the bottom, because our percieved polar angle is shifted this much as we go from the top to the bottom of a vertical slice. (and 50 is 1/6 of 350).

This is very wishy washy and just form me eyeballing the footage, and I could just have a critical error in my reasoning but that seems wayy to drastic of a difference, (a 50 degree visual approx to the 2-5 percent angle I think we would see just from perception reasons) Let me know if I am misunderstanding or f you think there might be more to this.

That said I have a degree in physics and this was a better explanation of light waves than I got my entire college study, love the channel and the vid.

author: @groseran
textdisplay:
joining to the previous commenters with admiration and gratitude for your amazing videos!
however...
I'm pretty sure your explanation about the X/Y asymmetry (where Z is in the direction parallel to the length of the tube ) is wrong.
your explanation doesn't actually explains any kind of broken symmetry along the perpendicular direction that wouldn't be symmetrical with regard to the (viewer * Z) plane. I currently cannot reproduce this experiment at home but I'll suspect one of the following:
1. liquid density/composition/impurities gradient - can be easily verified by agitating or mixing the solution, may cause a shift in the overall phase shift per unit Z
2. your first polarizer might be slightly shifted or damaged so that light getting into the tube with slightly different polarization along the Y axis
3. light source / optics - might cause light to be already polarized. please notice that if you use any type of semi crystalline material in your optical path such as polycarbonate or polystyrene, you might get quite string polarizations initially...
you can verify this easily by looking at a beam of light through your optics without any solution in the tube

author: @TheAzerty100000
textdisplay:
About the challenge question :
- Take any point A in the middle (vertically) of the tube. Observe the color at this point.
- Now if you look at the middle of the tube 10cm further, say point B, you dont get the same color because twisting happened.
- However, you can look for the same color you had at point A searching vertically from B.
- If you find the color you had on A above B, because we're looking at the tube from the left, it means the resulting vector has rotated left side, if you find this color beneath B, the vector rotated right.
Diagonal stripes "going down" here mean that we are in the second case. The resulting vector is rotating to the right side, meaning that left-handed light is more slowed down.
