author: @disgruntledwookie369
textdisplay: I realise this is an old video but I am in a rare position of having something to add to it and thought I'd leave a comment. First of all, there are special words for the things you called "harmonious" and "cacophonous", they are "consonance" and "dissonance" respectively. Secondly, and more interesting, I can explain why certain ratios of notes sound consonant. You're on the right lines thinking in terms of the "patterns" of the "beats" in the individual waves, but it's more beautiful than that. When two regular rhythms overlap with a simple ratio (eg. 3:4) it is called a "polyrhythm" in music theory. Depending on the ratio, the combined pattern will itself repeat with some frequency which is less than or equal to the lowest frequency of the two notes, for dissonant intervals this combined frequency is often much lower in pitch than either of the two source notes and not really audible, but more generally this "extra" note of a frequency we can hear, and this effectively introduces a third note into any interval. The trick is that extra note may or may not itself have a simple relationship to the other two notes! Take the example of a perfect fifth, specifically let's use the notes C and G. The higher note (G) has a frequency 1.5 times the lower note (C), a ratio of 3:2. This means that the combined pattern repeats with a frequency exactly half of the lower note. Halving or doubling the frequency of a note just gives the same note in a lower or higher octave respectively, so in the case of C and G, the "extra note" is actually another C, just one octave lower. This result is at the heart of how consonance works. In much the same way, the "combined note" of a major third (eg. C and E) is also the same as the root note, this time it's two octaves lower, but it's still a C, and this why perfect fifths and major thirds are arguably the most consonant intervals. A minor third on the other hand, let's say A and C, will "resolve" to a note which is neither A nor C, in fact it is F. This is essentially why minor thirds are not quite as consonant as major thirds, but it's actually still fairly good in this case. The note F is at least part of the A minor scale, and has strong relations to the note A (major third in fact). So there is still a kind of internal consistency which makes it sound good, just not quite as good as a perfect fifth. If you take a very dissonant interval instead, such as a semitone (eg. C and C#) with a ratio close to 16:15 then combined (resolved) frequency is 16x lower (4 octaves) than the higher (C#) note, in fact an 12TET semitone is not exactly 16:15 and the resolved note is even more out of tune with the two source notes. For an irrational ratio with no good nearby rational approximation, the combined rhythm technically never repeats. I have only mentioned two-note intervals for simplicity but this model really shines when you consider more complex chords. Every pair of notes within a given chord interact with each other to form a kind of "high speed polyrhythm" which itself has some frequency of repetition. For a triad, you have 3 source notes and 3 "extra" notes from the combinations. The relationship between all SIX of these notes is what drives the character of the chord. A major triad for example C, E, and G is extremely consonant because all 3 "extra notes" resolve to C (C4+E4=C1, E4+G4=C2, C4+G4=C3)

author: @swampwiz
textdisplay: This spanning tree explanation is good.  As for myself, I reasoned Euler's Characteristic Formula by looking at a tetrahedron, and then considering what would happen if an edge got a new vertex inside (it would be accompanied by the original edge splitting into 2 edges, and then there being a new pair of edges within each of the 2 face adjacent to the original edge and those 2 faces splitting into a pair of face), or if a new edge was inscribed in a face (the face would split into a pair of faces) , or if a face got a new vertex inside (it would be accompanied by a new set of edges with the number being the face rank (M), and the original face being split up into a new set of faces with the number also being the face rank), with the net result being the formula.

author: @npip99
textdisplay: 12:16 To get a clean image (An image identical to what you would get if you were to see those spirals in real life), you have to have each pixel take several random samples inside of itself and average the color. You can't just take an 8k image and downscale to 4k, that will just push the Moire patterns further. But, if each pixel had its own random sampling, it would render more like "film", which does not show Moire patterns, matching our eyes.

author: @KieranLeCam
textdisplay:
I may be saying something "nooby" here, or have misunderstood... but I would explain Dirichlet's theorem differently.

You should expect every mod class to have the same amount of numbers regardless of whether or not they are primes. And the explanation is simple. It's because of modulo. The operation modulo, or in the video "mod" achieves 2 things:

1) it reduces a whole number, no matter how small or large to a residue.

2) that residue is automatically between 0 and your modulo.

You essentially reduce all numbers to a residue between 0 and your modulo. And why would all numbers, in any particular base, have a preferred residue? All whole numbers...exist on the whole number line.

Prime numbers are the same, you've defined the class mods you should expect to have primes in beforehand (1,3,7,9), and as every modulo number along the whole number line has, in any unchanging base, the same amount of residues, you should expect an equal distribution. In other words, the equal distribution should be a property of the modulo operation itself in any unchanging, regular counting system with any unchanging base. Again I might be wrong, or perhaps I'm accidentally saying the same thing as the math I don't quite understand. But it makes logical sense to me.

author: @LinhNguyen-nh8oq
textdisplay: The way I think about this is that the larger the sum, the more likely the pattern. So basically, It made the decision on how much percent the pattern appear base on previous input. And in the process of making a decision, neurons which have the most weight is the most important input in making a decision. So the more green the weight is, the more important of the neuron in the process of determing the percent. And reverse for red weight. So back to your question, we want to identify the edge pattern(which is a white line and the surrounding will be black pixel), so the middle pixel have to be the brightest and the surrounding will be darkest. Hope this helps you

author: @drewarnold6741
textdisplay: Digital neural networks are not and will not be part of any type of general intelligence. Intelligence is not stored data and an architecture to relate and access it. Look at it this way... a person is not "intelligent" because of basic network wiring in their brain. Rather their intelligence stems from two cells (egg and sperm) which propagate and self assemble into a complex organism that it self can observe and manipulate the world around it. That is intelligence. We are so far off from creating something like that and touting that a "neural network" is a key component or accelerator to general AI is pure fantasy.

author: @Windprinc3
textdisplay:
I encountered a simple problem with a rather counterintuitive solution: of two manufacturing lines, one showed 20 defects from a random sample of 200 (10% defects). The other showed 25 defects from a random sample of 400 (6.25%). Yet, the proportions_ztest() function in Python says that there is no statistical difference, and consequently it is not worth the money to look into whether the two lines are different or to improve the one that has a higher percentage of defects. While I understand that the 2 different samples are random, and may just have these defect rates by accident, and that these rates are not indicative of the "population," it still seems counterintuitive. If you have the time, would you mind creating a video with a few of these seemingly counterintuitive results to emphasize the importance of statistics?

Thanks!

author: @3hustle
textdisplay:
üìä The video discusses the Galton Board and the Central Limit Theorem, which explains the common occurrence of the normal distribution in probability.
00:00
The Galton Board demonstrates how even chaotic and random events can have precise statements about the distribution of outcomes.
00:00
The Normal distribution, also known as a Bell curve, is a common distribution in probability.
00:27
The Central Limit Theorem is a key fact that explains the prevalence of the Normal distribution.
01:09
The video aims to provide the fundamentals of the Central Limit Theorem and normal distributions.
01:21
The video plans to delve deeper into the theorem's proof and the underlying formula of the normal distribution.
01:35
The simplified model of the Galton Board is used to illustrate the Central Limit Theorem.
02:05
The final position of the ball in the Galton Board model is the sum of random choices between plus one and minus one.
02:31
The number of balls falling into different buckets gives an idea of the likelihood of each bucket.
03:10
üé≤ The central limit theorem states that as the size of a sum of random variables increases, the distribution of that sum approaches a bell curve.
04:15
The central limit theorem applies to random variables, which are associated with numbers based on the outcome of a random process.
04:15
By taking multiple samples of a random variable and adding them together, the distribution of the sum tends to resemble a bell curve as the size of the sum increases.
05:11
The central limit theorem allows for making predictions about the range of values a sum of random variables is likely to fall within.
05:27
The central limit theorem has three assumptions that must be true for it to hold, which are revealed at the end of the video.
05:56
The central limit theorem applies to both fair and weighted dice, demonstrating its generality.
05:56
Simulations of rolling a weighted die demonstrate that the central limit theorem still applies, regardless of the distribution of outcomes.
06:25
Running multiple simulations of summing samples from a skewed distribution shows that the resulting distribution approaches a bell curve.
06:40
The video encourages viewers to predict the three assumptions of the central limit theorem before they are revealed.
06:59
üé≤ The video explains the central limit theorem using simulations and theoretical calculations for different dice distributions.
07:25
üé≤ The video discusses the central limit theorem and how the mean and standard deviation of a distribution affect its shape.
10:57
The central limit theorem states that as the number of samples increases, the distribution of the sums tends to resemble a bell curve.
10:57
The distributions in the video are shown to shift to the right and become more spread out as the number of samples increases.
11:13
The mean of a distribution is a measure of its center of mass and is calculated as the expected value of the random variable.
11:36
The variance is a measure of the spread of a distribution and is calculated by squaring the difference between each value and the mean.
12:18
The standard deviation is the square root of the variance and is a more intuitive measure of spread.
12:45
The mean of the distributions increases linearly with the number of samples.
13:15
The variance of the sum of two random variables is equal to the sum of their individual variances.
13:53
The standard deviation does not add when summing random variables; it is the variance that adds.
14:07
üìä The video explains the central limit theorem and the formula for a normal distribution.
14:20
The variance of the sum of 'n' different realizations of the same random variable is 'n' times the variance of the original variable.
14:20
The standard deviation of the sum is the square root of 'n' times the original standard deviation.
14:33
The distributions are realigned so that their means line up and rescaled so that all standard deviations are equal to one.
15:13
This process results in a universal shape described by a normal distribution.
15:28
The formula for a normal distribution involves the function e^(-0.5x^2/Sigma^2).
16:00
The constant Sigma represents the standard deviation of the distribution.
17:27
The area under the curve of a probability distribution must be one.
17:42
üìä The video explains the concept of probability density functions and how they relate to the area under the curve of a bell curve distribution.
17:54
Probability density functions represent the probability of a value falling between two different values.
17:54
The area under the curve of a probability density function represents the probability of an event occurring.
18:08
The basic bell curve shape of the function does not have an area of one, but dividing it by the square root of Pi gives the desired area.
18:20
The factor in front of the function ensures that the area under the curve is always one, regardless of the value of Sigma.
18:49
The Standard Normal Distribution is a special case where Sigma equals one and plays an important role in the lesson.
19:20
The mean and standard deviation of a distribution can be used to describe the sums of random variables.
20:02
By modifying the expression to have a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one, the distribution can be visualized in a more elegant way.
21:00
The modified expression tells us how many standard deviations away from the mean a sum is.
21:14

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Complex exponents are very important for differential equations, so I wanted to be sure to have a quick reference for anyone uncomfortable with the idea. Plus, as an added benefit, this gives an exercise in what it feels like to reason about a differential equation using a phase space, even if none of those words are technically used.


As some of you may know, Euler's formula is already covered on this channel, but from a very different perspective whose main motive was to give an excuse to introduce group theory. Hope you enjoy both!

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: I noticed you depict the length of "i" same as the unit length in x axis. So, are you saying that sqrt(-1) is equal to 1?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
no
1 is on the x axis (to the right), i is on the y axis (going up)

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay: @@2fifty533 Yes but i and 1 are depicted EQUAL IN LENGTH. Why?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
@@pelasgeuspelasgeus4634 because they are equal in length
value is not the same thing as length though. -1 would be represented by an arrow of length 1, but that doesn't mean that -1 = 1

author: @pelasgeuspelasgeus4634
textdisplay:
@@2fifty533 I'm not sure I get you. So, i and 1 have the same length but aren't equal in value? Really now?
You are another victim of fake math. When you make ridiculous assumptions like i^2=-1 then ridiculous outcome follow. Here is one example:
-1=i^2=i*i=sqrt(-1)*sqrt(-1)=sqrt((-1)*(-1))=sqrt(1)=1. Where is the error?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
@@pelasgeuspelasgeus4634 like i said, negative one and positive one are equal in length, but are not equal in value, the same applies here

calling complex/imaginary numbers "fake math" is just ignorance because they are used over and over in so many different fields and have proved themselves useful

author: @ganonschlachter
textdisplay: So does multiplying a number by i/2 rotate it around 45 degrees?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
no, that still rotates it 90 degrees but halves its size

let's say you wanna rotate a number z by 180 degrees, first you would rotate once by 90 degrees (z*i), and then once more (z*i*i)
so, to rotate 180, you don't multiply by 2i, you multiply by i squared which is the same as multiplying twice by i
likewise, if you wanted to rotate 45 degrees, you'd need to multiply by a number that multiplies with itself to get i, because doing it twice should get you back to 90 degrees

and this number is the square root of i

author: @WhyDoesThisHappen
textdisplay:
but why e?
e is a constant, it's like about 2.71 or somthing, right?
so why e?

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay: he explained at the start of the video

author: @WhyDoesThisHappen
textdisplay:
@@2fifty533 okay
but WHY
WHY e???

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
@@WhyDoesThisHappen because the function e^x is its own derivative, in other words, the rate of increase in the result (or speed) as x increases is always equal to the current position at any given time

and the speed of e^2x has the same property, except the speed is twice the current position

when you do e^ix, the velocity is always the current position but rotated 90 degrees, which results in a circle being drawn

author: @oioisexymlaoy
textdisplay: WHY should you never have a boundary that just contains two colours? I didn't understand why it has to be so for this example

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
I don't know of a simple self-contained explanation, but the follow-on video goes on to explain how this follows from a general result about Julia sets.

The loose intuition is that points on this boundary will bounce around chaotically never landing on any root, and in fact (this is the non-obvious part) it's sort of as chaotic as it possibly could be, in the sense that any arbitrarily small neighborhood of points around it will blow up and get spread almost everyone on the plane as you repeat this process.

author: @smalleranimals
textdisplay:
the comparisons to audio reverb in comments here are onto something important. convolving an audio signal with the impulse response from a room duplicates the reverb of that room.

and when you convolve an image using a kernel where all the values are the same (ex.. your 1/9 example) you are in a sense, imposing the smoothness of the kernel onto the image => blur. and when the kernel has a single positive point in its center and all surrounding values are negative (ie. maximum difference between the center and the rest of the kernel), the result will pick out places where image points are different from their neighbors and exaggerate the difference => sharpen. and, as you showed, kernels with vertical and horizontal features highlight those same features in the image. that's the same thing that happens in audio - the nature of the kernel is imposed on the image.

and when you get into binary morphological convolutions, the link becomes even clearer. for example, the 'dilation' operator takes a kernel of 1s and 0s, and the convolution outputs a 1 only when at least one pixel underneath it lines up with a 1 in the kernel. the result is a duplication of the kernel's shape, all over the image.

textdisplay: 20:05 so what keeps Alice from making a fraudulent transaction, and broadcasting it to everyone not just Bob? If she broadcasts it to everyone, she doesn't have to mine.

author: @theopantamis9184
textdisplay:
The attack is badly described here. A better description of it is in the video by curious inventor quoted in description.

Everyone broadcast transaction to everyone so Bob will heard the fraudulent transaction in your case. Conversly, Bob don't really get the signed transaction from Alice herself, he will heard of it by others and he will also broadcast his transaction. The conflict can only resolve when blocks are mined with one of the two transactions. This is why Bob should not give what Alice paid to him until the transaction is confirmed. That's what force Alice to not sign a double-spending transaction that would prevent any confirmation for the transaction paying Bob....

author: @marvinmeng7213
textdisplay:
So to clarify, there are two measures of security:
1. The digital signatures using secret / public keys: This authenticates transactions and doesn't allow people to change transactions after it has been signed, because the message and secret key make the signature. I.e. it lets me know that no one is stealing money from me.
2. The hash for the block of transactions: After making sure each transaction is valid with a signature, we want everyone else in the world to know the valid transaction happens. I.e. that the money is transferred and people know person A now has 10 LD from person B.

Together these two provide the following: Makes sure every transaction on the block is true (1). Makes sure everyone knows all the true transactions (2).

If (1) fails, then you can make fake transactions. If (2) fails, then even if you have real transactions no one will believe you.

Is this line of thinking correct?

author: @theopantamis9184
textdisplay: This is absolutly correct ! Notice that (1) protects the transaction's sender of modification by anyone else and (2) protects the receiver against modification by the sender. Notice that (2) is not really that no one would believe you (you have valid signature of a sender after all !) but that some people may consider that your money comes from already spend transactions' outputs that the sender signed but you didn't heard of.

author: @theopantamis9184
textdisplay:
You can sign a feeless transaction but it may not reach miners because nodes only relay transactions with a minimum amount of fees to protect themself against spam, the bare minimum to pay is then close to a penny no matter the amount send.

A miner may or may not pick the transaction, he choose. But any miner has this choice and you just need one to include your transaction in a block. Generally, miners include the transaction with the highest feerate per bytes. So if you pay a small fee you may wait until your transaction is one with the highest feerate waiting to be confirmed.

author: @harrywilkinson4826
textdisplay: Is it always the number of 0's used in Bitcoins POW consensus? Surely that means that you'd just need to save the solutions when you find X number of 0's at the start of each computation and then pulling from your stored solutions? Instead is it the character length at the start of the output hash that changes, but each of the characters can be 1's or 0's?

author: @theopantamis9184
textdisplay:
A hash is a number between 0 and 2 power 256 minus 1 and it can be written in binary or hexadecimal format with 256 bits or 32 bytes respectively.

The real criteria is not that the hash start with many zero but that it is lower then a target, typically 2 power 180 currently. This means that when I write the 256 bytes or 33 bytes of the hash of the last block, the first higher weight 256-180=76 bits or 10 bytes will be 0.

author: @rossholst5315
textdisplay:
When we make this extension, it appears as we are trying to make the resulting image symmetric around a vertical axis around x=1/2.

However the initial symmetry would have been around the x=0 axis. And if we just had a mirror image of the function for negative values, we should have a gap between -1/2 and 1/2.

Is there some distortion on the negative half of the numbers?

Because we didn‚Äôt re-center around a point equal distant between the two boundaries? We shifted the left half over a full unit such that it now joins at 1/2 instead of having a gap between -1/2 and 1/2.

Now it also seems suspect that the middle point in the lost section is 0 and the gap is 1 unit. It also seems like 1/2 is fitting as 0 is is half way between -1 and 1, or an initial point is 1/2 the distance from a unit to the right and a unit to the left.

Also what happens to all the grid lines for values less than 1 and greater than 0? It would seem all of those points should move as well. I would think they would all stretch out to some infinite point being 0 or infinity.

Basically why is this centered around 1/2 and not 0?

author: @user-qb3hm3qn6f
textdisplay: to get an easyer expression of the Riemann-Zetafunction try Zeta (x) = 0.5 + i(e^(x+pi*pi-6)). If you put the n (element of natural numbers) as start of its Indefinite integral and n+1 as end you will get the square of the n-th prime number. This is a proof of the Riemann hypothesis. If you want another proof draw a circle with any radius >1 from the origin (0/0) then draw a complex conjunction of this [p2(0/1)] the intersections are the ony viable points and the real part is always 0.5 -> qed

author: @CubicPostcode
textdisplay: I have an important point to make regarding using the Riemann zeta function to map complex numbers to other complex numbers. I am eager to hear insightful responses on this matter. In my view, the best approach to uncover meaningful patterns from feeding complex inputs into the zeta function may be to use a split screen: the left side could show the complex plane with dots of particular colors denoting complex inputs, while the right side maps those inputs through the zeta function, using the same colors to connect inputs to outputs. This visualization may reveal salient correspondences and patterns. The name "1blueComplexInput1blueComplexOutput" reflects this color-coded mapping of complex numbers. I believe this technique will yield valuable insights, patterns, and formulas relating complex inputs to outputs of this profound mathematical function. What are your thoughts on this proposed approach? I welcome your perspectives. Eager to hear from you, namely, about in what sense you would call this a very Monte-Carlo simulation approach to find unknown underlying patterns. You say?

textdisplay:
As dr got smaller, we got more accurate, when the rectangles were big i.e. when the dr was bigger, the error was also bigger (error here means the tiny area that was at the top of rectangle and below the line of function) and as the size of dr got smaller, the error reduced, which means that when dr was bigger it didn't account for tiny area that was left at the top of rectangle and as the rectangles became thinner, they started accounting for the area that was left (we became more accurate, as the error reduced).

To answer your question the (tiny amount of)height of triangle changed because the height of rectangle changed, you should think backward, the area with smaller dr was correct (increased height of rectangles(or triangle) was correct) but as dr got bigger they started leaving tiny amount area at the top (the error) and hence the change in height of rectangles changed which kinda eventually changed the height of triangle.

I tried mate especially with my poor English, sorry if you still didn't get it, try to draw on the paper, one diagram will contain bigger rectangles and another will contain smaller. "The height triangle didn't really change it only got more accurate."

author: @juststudying1019
textdisplay:
Thanks.

This is a simple PHP program that do what is in the video.

<?php

define('RADIUS', 6);
define('RINGS_COUNT', 6 * 10000000);

// Represents dr.
$thickness = RADIUS / RINGS_COUNT;

// The area of the circle, that we are calculating.
$circleArea = 0;

// Loop through each ring from the circle.
for ($i = 1; $i <= RINGS_COUNT; $i++) {
// Calculate the radius of the current circle (ring after cutting it).
$radius = $i * $thickness;

// Circumference of the current circle.
$height = 2 * pi() * $radius;

// Since the shape is almost a rectangular shape, its area is : height * width.
$ringArea = $thickness * $height;

// Sum the area of the current current ring to the circle.
$circleArea += $ringArea;
}

echo "[Algorithm]: " . $circleArea . PHP_EOL;

echo "[Formula]: " . pi() * (RADIUS*RADIUS) . PHP_EOL;

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
it's strange how many times you invoke the claim that 3 is a bare, dimensionless number, yet you also claim that 3+5=8.

addition cannot operate over bare, dimensionless numbers. when you attempt to do that the result is undefined:

1 dog +1 dog = 2 dogs; this is the addition you think we're always using
1 dog +1 quail = 2 wings; this is something different, despite using the same exact numbers and relation between them
1 dog +1 quail = 6 legs; now 1+1=6
1 foot +1 yard = 48 inches; 1+1=48
1 half +1 third = 5 sixths; 1+1=5
1 frog +1 pond = 1 pond; 1+1=1
1 C water +1 C dirt = some mud; 1+1 is undefined

addition only works when the units on all terms are the same. the combination of a number and a unit is obviously not a number, because that would be blatantly absurd. 7 giraffes is not a number, 7 is. 4 hours is not a number, 4 is. these combined objects are vectors. so when we're working with 1-dimensional vectors that have no specified unit, and we're adding or subtracting them, we're necessarily using Integers. this in turn renders subtraction just as commutative as addition, because in truth neither is an operation, since the + and - symbols are merely the unit of the term whose magnitude follows the sign. this is why:

4 -3 = -3 +4

these are simply all possible spell-outs of the unordered list of Integers {+4, -3}. the + doesn't appear on the 4 in initial position due to historical reasons, namely + is an abbreviation of the Latin word 'et', meaning 'and', which only further illustrates that addition has always been about listing things, not performing some mystical addition operation over them. and the - symbol was only introduced quite recently, and must appear on negative terms in initial position because negative values are not the default.

this has the effect of invalidating the assertion that the Naturals are a subset of the Integers, since the Naturals are numbers, but the Integers are vectors, as well as showing that the Peano Axioms are nonsense, since they attempt to derive the Naturals from a type of addition, via the successor function, which is later derived into an addition operator in Peano Artihmetic. but we already know that addition has no operator. it further impacts what it means for something to be an Abelian Group (part of the problem is that negative numbers were not systematically accepted in Algebra until the year after Niels Henrik Abel died, so when the concept of Abelian Groups was established later on, based on Abel's work, it naturally excluded them, and subtraction... even though this exclusion is entirely cultural and artificial), among other things.

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
why do we say that |5| = +5?

that's just as incorrect as saying |5| = -5. except, the former is literally baked into the axioms that make up ZF(C).

how is this acceptable?

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
I'd be wary of the claim that it's been proven that all the simple groups have been found.

the reason is that the nature of an axiomatic logic is that it can prove things to be valid with respect to the chosen axioms, but not sound. for soundness, and thus a proof that's actually worth a damn, the axioms must be perfectly correct in the first place.

as I've already demonstrated, modern mathematics is built on a foundation of faulty axioms, since some flavor of the Dedekind-Peano Axioms are central to anything commensurate with ZF(C), but they build up numbers and arithmetic incorrectly. so whatever you prove from them, which is pretty much all of the last century worth of mathematics, including the subject of this video, is suspect.

this isn't to say that I believe that the Monster Group isn't a real mathematical object. it's merely to point out that the path we took to get there is built on mistakes and lies, and thus should be tread with care.

for an example of another core axiom that's simply ridiculous, consider Dedekind Completeness. the idea here is that the Archimedean Property implies that the Reals are continuous... despite no other Archimedean Group being continuous, and the Archimedean Property specifically resulting in the infinite bifurcation of every identifiable gap, rather than the erasure of them. the notion is insanity at best, and sheer idiocy at worst. yet, it's usually included as an axiom.

these things should trouble you.

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
there's a saying that English teachers have. 'Every rule has an exception.'

your invocation of 'logical necessity' at the end, sounds very similar to this. and my issue with that is the source of this saying among English teachers is that the rules they espouse are actually just wrong.

for instance, everyone claims that English uses an alphabet. yet, everyone who can read English knows this is false, since most English words are very clearly not written alphabetically.

another one is the claim that English has plural marking on nouns. even though 'plural' means more than 1, but you can have 'no dogs', 'one dog', 'two dogs', 'many dogs', etc. so the '-s' appears everywhere that the noun is not singular, not when it's plural. and worse, when the subject noun is singular, this '-s' moves onto the verb:

The dogs run fast. '-s' on non-singular subject noun
The dog runs fast. '-s' on verb with singular subject noun

and then this observation leads us into recognizing that English doesn't have verb tenses. if this '-s' which appears on verbs, and indicates the 'simple present tense', is the same '-s' that appears on non-singular nouns, then it's obviously not fundamentally marking verb tense, is it? further, the other alleged tense markers, '-ed' and '-ing', can appear on adjectives and nouns as well. not to mention, the 'simple present tense' is used to talk about things that are timelessly true, which by definition means it's not a tense. and '-ed' and '-ing' can appear with a past, present or future reference, so they obviously don't indicate tense either.

methinks similar things are going on with mathematics. the reason things seem so weird to you is that the rules you've put your confidence in are simply wrong.

and honestly, it'd be very weird if this weren't the case. for the most part, this type of mathematics derives from a roughly 50 year spurt of innovation in the early and mid-1800s, which strongly corresponds with the period between the end of the Napoleonic Wars and the Unification of Germany and the formation of the Kingdom of Italy. following this period of innovation was a period of codification, wherein we get figures like Georg Cantor, Giuseppe Peano, Richard Dedekind, David Hilbert, Bertrand Russell, etc. and the goal was to reformulate mathematics to encapsulate everything that was newly discovered in the early years of the 19th century. this period of codification ran roughly from the time of the Unification of Germany to the First World War.

after this, the major players in the mathematics industry suffered so many losses that it's accurate to say that we're looking at a mass extinction event in, not only mathematics, but across the sciences in general. in the wake of which the Vienna Circle grew to prominence, and with the rise of National Socialism, disbanded across the globe. where their ideology took hold just in time to seed the generation that would repopulate these industries after the second wave of mass extinction occurred during WWII. out of this we actually even specifically get Kuhn, who saw precisely what I'm describing, but misinterpreted it as being about the quality of ideas, rather than repopulation events. but all of his examples of revolutions come immediately after horrendous wars, like Newton's rise in the immediate aftermath of the English Civil War.

and this pattern is in fact so robust that French mathematicians in the interwar period, recognizing that they were mostly students, largely ignorant of the nuances of the discoveries of the 19th century, came together and formed Nicolas Bourbaki in order to preserve what fragmented knowledge they had left between them. and this sets the stage for the era we're in now, and have been in since about the 1920s. which is an era of popularization.

so when you review this timeline it should strike you that the major pivotal moments come not due to any specific thing occurring within the field of mathematics, but things occurring in the world of geopolitics. the transition from innovation to codification came not because the innovation reached some specific level of sophistication, but because the way people thought about the world, and their place in it, changed. and this era of codification ended not because it was in any way finished, but because WWI happened. and the era of popularization occurred not because the two stages that came before were tidy enough to be disseminated to the masses, but because the risk of forgetting everything was a very real looming threat in the aftermath of WWI and WWII.

so, it's an odd position to take to say that this foundation which was hastily patched together by just a few men, under the belief that mathematics should be couched in the language of logic, a belief which was later shown to be misguided, is something that will stand the test of time. because there's absolutely no evidence supporting that conclusion.

author: @GenesisAria
textdisplay:
This helps with getting into quantum mechanics as a field of research/study, but quantum effects are not required to understand the polarization filter triplet. The polarization rotation causes a gradient fade as you rotate them approaching perpendicular. The 3rd simply counterrotates that partially between the fore and aft ones, allowing some of the light to go through again.

Think of it this way: your hole is vertical one side and horizontal the other side. If you are completely perpendicular then only an infinitesimal amount of you can get through, if it's on an angle, then some of you can get through. You get turned sideways going through the first, then the second one puts you back the other way somewhat, and that gives you enough to go through the last one diagonally. That's just analogy, as nothing is actually trying to travel from somewhere to somewhere else through oddly shaped holes.

Linear polarization is merely a phase match of 2 rotations, and the filters offset these phases to affect apparent wave amplitude, they do not actually "block light" as if it was something travelling from somewhere to somewhere else. Light is merely the medium oscillating, similar to sound. I do not know what causes the assumption of light being "absorbed" on certain axes (you'd have to observe proportional heating on the surfaces of the filters, ie if you have 2 filters and "block" the light completely, they should heat proportionally to 100% of the energy of the light that would go through them if they were actually blocking or absorbing).

author: @gustavoteles5994
textdisplay:
Great video, man! However, regarding your pet peeve (15:50)... Keep in mind that the radar analogy (Range ambiguity resolution) isn't completely interchangeable with the Heisenberg uncertainty principle/unsharpness relation. The range ambiguity resolution is a problem with THE RADAR, not the objects being measured.

But, in the quantum realm, atomic particles like the electron adhere to the strange DUALITY PRINCIPLE, which you didn't discuss. The particle/wave duality is key to understanding the limits of range ambiguity resolution as an analogy to quantum physics because it introduces this mysterious and strange aspect of quantum mechanics. The problem in measuring the plane lies with the radar. The problem in measuring the electron is the electron itself (we could say it's inherent to nature).

P.S.: I'm a physics major, and I was thrilled that you even read De Broglie's seminal paper. Excellent work! Just highlighting something I thought was important and... flew under your radar (ba dum tss).

author: @googleyoutubechannel8554
textdisplay:
I wonder if we can use Fourier relationships to understand when specific properties are more derived or emergent vs more fundamental. For all classical conjugate pairs of quantities where Fourier transforms apply it seems that one side of the pair is more observable, and the other is a derived property that is useful as a model. eg "many pressure measurements over time" (observed) translates into 'frequency' values (model).

For QM conjugate pairs that are (supposed to be) subject to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, what hints or clues could the above idea indicate? Are 'position' and 'momentum' both equally useful models or physical ideas? Does this Fourier relationship indicate that one is more emergent or derivative than the other?

author: @Matze_S
textdisplay: Being german, I've never thought that I would see german in one of your videos. You've helped me every now and then to get a deeper understanding about mathematics all through my physics bachelor's degree. Thank you very much for this, it helped me to appreciate the beauty of it. To the german english translation: here and there I noticed the deviation of terms in physics and mathematics when it comes to translation (e.g.: in german there's a difference between the real like reality (ger.: real) and the real in real numbers (ger.: reell)). I'm always curious where the original comes from and why the difference may be there. On a practical note, while I'm pretty sure that it's not true in general, it surprised me quite a few times that german wikipedia articles on scientific topics were more elaborate in german than in english. I even stumbled over a few ones (sometimes for more or less important topics) that exist only in german. There were also ones that existed in german and other languages, with none of them being english.

author: @stephenzhao5809
textdisplay: 2:20 ... I think when I first heard someone reference fractional dimension like this I just thought it was nonsense, right? I mean, mathematicicans are clearly just making stuff up. 2:29 Dimension is something that usually only makes sense for natural numbers, right? A line is one-dimensional; a plane, that's two dimensional; this space that we live in, that's three dimensional, and so on. 2:38 ... 4:25 Typically in math, the word that you use for this is "Measure", but I think it might be more intuitive to talk about "mass". As in, image that metal: A thin wire, a flat sheet, a solid cube, and some kind of Sierpinski mesh. Fractual dimension has everything to do with understanding how the mass of these shapes changes as you scale them. 4:46 The benefit of starting the discussion with self-similar shapes is that it gives us a nice clear-cut way to compare masses. When you scale down that line by one half, the mass is also scaled down by one-half, which you can viscerally see because it takes two copies of that smaller one to form the whole. 5:04 When you scale down a square by one-half, its mass is scaled down by one fourth, where again you can see this by piecing together four of the smaller copies to get the original. Likewise, when you scale down that cube by one half, the mass is scalled down by one eithth, or one-half cubed, because it takes eight copies of that. 5:25 ... 9:12 ... What I've described so far, everything up to this point is what you might call "self-similarity dimension". It does a good job making the idea of fractional dimension seem at least somewhat reasonable, but there's a problem. 9:26

author: @Benjamin-ii5ei
textdisplay:
Human intelligence is the human capacity or ability to acquire, apprehend and apply knowledge.[1] It is marked by complex cognitive and intellectual feats, and high levels of motivation, creativity and self-awareness.

With intelligence, humans can learn, form concepts, understand, apply logic and reason, including the capacities to recognize patterns, plan, innovate, solve problems, make decisions, retain information, and use language to communicate.

There are conflicting ideas about how intelligence is measured, ranging from the idea that intelligence is fixed at birth to the idea that it is malleable and can change depending on a person's mindset and efforts.[2] In psychometrics, human intelligence is commonly assessed by intelligence quotient (IQ) tests, although the validity of these tests is disputed.

Several subcategories of intelligence, such as emotional intelligence and social intelligence, have been proposed, and there remains significant debate as to whether these represent distinct forms of intelligence.[3] In general, higher intelligence is associated with better outcomes in life.

author: @wayneyadams
textdisplay: 13:24 The two vectors do have to be perpendicular to get flow rotation. Having the two vectors perpendicular results in the maximum change and circular flow around the refence point, while any other angle still results in rotation just not the maximum value and not circular. An example would be the elliptical orbits of the planets around the Sun.

author: @wayneyadams
textdisplay: 12:36 An easy way to visualize this is to imagine walking along a hill where we consider rising elevation to be positive. One vector is your motion in a certain direction. The second vector is the change in elevation straight up the hill toward the peak. The divergence would be your change in elevation. Walking straight up toward the peak has the two vectors aligned so you get the maximum rise in elevation possible. Walking along perpendicular to the peak of the hill results in no change in elevation. Walking at any other angle to the top of the hill results in some change in elevation between those two extremes. Walking down the hill results in decreasing elevation, or more correctly a negative change of elevation.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Some notes on the intended use of this series. I was deliberate in using the phrase "tour of differential equations", as opposed to "introduction to" or "essence of". I think of the relationship between watching this series and taking a course as being analogous to the relationship between touring a city vs. living in it. You'll certainly see a lot less with the tour since you're spending less time overall, but the goal will be to walk around some of the most noteworthy monuments and town centers with helpful context given to you by a guide. And just as someone who lives in a city may very well have never gone to visit some of the historical sites of their town, despite living there for years, many differential equations students may not always get the chance to zoom out and appreciate the central cornerstones of the subject amidst all the computations they are learning.


I hope you enjoy the tour, but at the same time know that it is, by design, very different from taking courses on the subject.

author: @user-ud6ui7zt3r
textdisplay: He's a helluva nice guy for making this video, and he has come up with an excellent set of graphics tools that communicate very well, however, I find it really annoying that the name he chose for the STATE VECTOR (with a ‚û° appearing above it) was the lower case 'v'. I mean, most people are going to look at that and immediately say to themselves "AH! that means VELOCITY!" and, in this video, they would be wrong. The subsequent derivative (of v with a ‚û°appearing above it) IS the velocity (of v with a ‚û°appearing above it.) Apparently, he chose 'v' as a general way to represent the word 'vector', however, v is so often used to denote velocity, that it really makes for a lot of confusion.

textdisplay: A 2x2 matrix, where the first row is [a, b] and the second row is [-b, a], emulates all of the behavior of the complex number a + bi. author: @taupring
textdisplay: Thank you for these videos!  It really has helped me to start to understand vectors from the different perspectives.  Speaking of which (of course not the fault of the video creator) - one thing that bothers me is why do they confuse things in the computer science realm by naming a vector's dimension after the number of elements in it?  That is so confusing to call what I see as a one dimensional array of numbers (or list of numbers)  an x-dimension vector (where x is the number of elements in the array).  In doing so it completely confuses folks and muddies the water since multiple dimensions in computer science refers to how many types of items you can have, not how many elements under each of those types.  They should have called them elements, as in this would be a 1 dimensional vector with 2 elements: [5, 10].

textdisplay: Thank you so much. I got into a sort of ML bootcamp, where I suddenly find that ML is just math with a fancy coat of paint on top. author: @erictheepic5019
textdisplay: @Philosopher's Dream ¬†¬† In the case of two errors, the method that gives you the accuracy to find a single bit breaks down. Imagine that there are two bits flipped in one set. Say, two bits flipped in column two. The row parity can find that there are two errors, but the column parity can't give any information on where the bit is, because as far as it can tell, parity still checks out. For more complicated cases, just get yourself a piece of paper and two coins (or any object, really). Draw out a 4x4 grid, and then place the two coins in two random spaces to represent errors. Try to determine the positions of the errors purely through the group-based parity checks. The only case I could find that allows both errors to be solved is when there's one in the top corner in the case that that's a parity bit. In every other case I tried, it's impossible to pin down the location.

author: @chongchonghe3748
textdisplay: The beauty here is that, by constructing the parity bits in this way, there is not a single parity bit that is located in the territory of another parity bit. So, flipping only a parity bit will cause that parity bit to be errored and all other parity bits not errored. By that, you know the errored parity bit is the errored bit.

author: @kevinmcnamee6006
textdisplay:
I taught this stuff as part of data communications course in the 80s. Your rows and columns method is an excellent graphical explanation of what's going on and the second video does a great job of explaining how easy it is to figure out which bit is in error.

My explanation involved assigning the data bits a sequence number from 0 to 15. Parity bit 1 covered all bits with the 1 bit set in their sequence number (1,3,5,7,9,11,13,15). Parity bit 2 covers all bits with a 2 bit in their sequence number (2,3,6,7,10,11,14,15). Parity bit 4 covered all bits with a 4 bit set in their sequence number (4,5,6,7,12,13,14,15). Parity bit 8 covers all bits with an 8 bit set in their sequence number (8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15). This essentially created a parity check for each column of the bit sequence number and provides an easy way to determine which bit had fipped.

If a single bit error occured, to figure out which bit was in error, you simply added up the values of the parity bits that were wrong and it told you exactly which bit needed to be fixed. Lets say bit 12 had flipped. That would mean the parity calculations associated with parity bits 4 and 8 would be wrong... meaning fix bit 12 (4+8). An error in bit 3 would mean that parity bits 1 and 2 would be wrong indicating bit 3 (1+2) should be fixed.

author: @PaoloGasparini-ux2kp
textdisplay:
As is known, Euler's identity is a formula that Richard Feynman, like many others, found remarkable because it connects some very important mathematical constants.
= is the necessary condition
1 and 0 are the neutral elements of the product and the sum respectively,
e is the base of natural logarithms,
i is the imaginary unit, the complex number whose square is -1, and finally
pi represents the ratio between the length of a circle and its diameter.

The first formulation makes explicit the relationship between the five mathematical constants contained therein:
The number 0, is the neutral element for addition.
The number 1.
The number pi is fundamental in trigonometry; is a constant for a world that is Euclidean or for small scales in a non-Euclidean geometry (otherwise, the ratio of the length of a circle's circumference to its diameter would not be a universal constant, i.e. the same for all circumferences ).
The number e is a fundamental constant (also called Nepero's number) connected to the study of logarithms in analysis (such as differential equations).
The imaginary unit i is a unit in complex numbers. The introduction of this unit makes all non-constant polynomial equations solvable in the field of complex numbers (see fundamental theorem of algebra).
The formula contains an irrational power (the Neperian irrational number e, raised to an exponent containing the irrational factor pi), is rare in mathematical formulae. It connects real irrational numbers (e), imaginary irrational numbers (pi), and integers (1).
Furthermore, all the fundamental operators of arithmetic are present: equality, addition, multiplication, and exponentiation. All the basic assumptions of complex analysis are present, and the integers 0 and 1 are related to the field of complex numbers.
(source: wiki)


The mathematical analogy seems to me thus instituted with a philosophical theorem of creation. It could be the following:
the world (the created universe) adds nothing to God, and this can be represented by Euler's identity.
"To create is to continually create new"
[Luther, Resolutions on Indulgences (WA I, p.563)].
"If you try to subtract the Spirit from creation, all things mix and their life appears without law, without order, without any determination"
[Basil the Great, Of the Holy Spirit, XVI, 38 (PG 32, 137 B].
"Without the Spirit, the whole of creation cannot last" (Ambrogio, Dello Spirito Santo, II, 5, 33).
"The universe was about to fall back into chaos and dissolve in dismay in the face of passion if the great Jesus had not poured out the divine spirit of him, exclaiming:" Father, into your hands I commend my Spirit "(Lk 23:46) . And immediately, with the diffusion of the divine Spirit, as revived, quickened and consolidated, the universe found its stability"
[Ancient Easter homily, 55 (SCh 27, p. 183)]

So, finally, considering in a hierarchical steps the four main disciplines of human endeavors, we could state an interdisciplinary comment like that.
The word poetry means "making", literally ‚Äì poiesis. Poetry is fundamental speech. Prose is less fundamental speech. Prose is fallen poetry; poetry is not decorated prose. The original language, for Heidegger and for Lewis in The Magician's Nephew, was music. Now music usually has words, so words are in the music. But those words are words for music. Take them out of the music and they're still poetry, but make them fall one step further and they're prose. Make them fall one step further and they're mathematics, which is the only univocal, unambiguous language in the world. The most ambiguous language in the world is music. And therefore it's the richest. How will the tower of Babel be undone; how will we understand each other in heaven? Will we all speak English, or Dutch? No, we'll all speak music.

author: @angeldude101
textdisplay:
I actually personally hate the typical version of e^iœÄ + 1 = 0, and this video shows why: because it mixes the additive group with the multiplicative group. The additive group belongs solely in the exponent, not down to be added to the result of said exponent, which otherwise lives in the multiplicative group.

The presence of the "5 most important numbers in mathematics" is frankly a meaningless property and its beauty pales in comparison to the equation showing that a 180¬∞ rotation is equivalent to an inversion across the origin. Two different multiplicative actions that might look different at first, but are really the same thing (at least in 2D).

author: @codelapiz
textdisplay:
i think the introductory example is disingenuous. When people ask a question like that "here is a description of a person is he class A og B", it is not appropriate at all to assume this is person is randomly sampled from the population. i think what is instead implied, the way most people hear such a question, is that the person is sampled from the archetypes of their respective classes. Eg you take the x most libererian libererians and x most farmer farmers, and pick one. why would you say its eigther a farmer or a liberarian if not. Is a more valid answer that you think hes a teacher because those are more common?

now i would say as an example to teach bayes theorem, this is not that bad. However many people will use such thought experiments to try to convince people to use a more "logical" mindset. The fact is in the real world when you are faced with a question like that, not asked by someone that designed it to trick you, cleansing your mindset from context, and trying to find a few variables and use math will be less accurate than using your intuition on the whole context of the question asked, why it was asked, who asked, etc.

author: @bohanxu6125
textdisplay:
What seems to bother/confuse me is that bayse theorem just looks like a static equation about joint probability. It seems to just describe a static reality... But the interpretation is a dynamical/iterative scheme to update subjective belief.

The libertarian-farmer example has a hypothesis that has a well defined prior probability (the fraction of librarian is a objective reality). In other context, the probability about belief is fundamentally ill defined. For instance, the likelihood of string theory is correct (over all current theory) has a definite binary answer while our assignment of prior probability is totally ill defined and subjective... This example is more about updating subjective belief while the librarian-farmer example is more about describing well defined static reality. One example requires some kind of iterative convergence to give rigorous result while the other give rigorous result without the need for iteration

author: @N.i.c.k.H
textdisplay:
I think it is interesting to show how this shows why you cannot change the minds of rational, true believers: For a true believer, P(H)=1 and therefore P(NOT(H))=0 and so, for ANY evidence E, P(H|E) reduces to P(E|H)/P(E|H) = 1
(This assumes that they even do the calculation, because P(H)=1 implies that P(E|H) should be 0 for any true counter evidence and hence either E is not actually counter evidence at all or else it must be faked)
I've seen somewhere that 0 and 1 should not be thought of as probabilities in the same way the infinity is not a number and this shows why that view makes sense, or at least that they can only reasonably be used to as probabilities in the mathematical realm where they are kind of the values by definition e.g. probability that 1+1=2 where, if you have counter evidence then it can only be because we mean different things by "1","+" and/or "=".

author: @fischerdev
textdisplay:
Unity


Quaternions are used to represent rotations.

They are compact, don't suffer from gimbal lock and can easily be interpolated. Unity internally uses Quaternions to represent all rotations.

They are based on complex numbers and are not easy to understand intuitively. You almost never access or modify individual Quaternion components (x,y,z,w); most often you would just take existing rotations (e.g. from the Transform) and use them to construct new rotations (e.g. to smoothly interpolate between two rotations).

The Quaternion functions that you use 99% of the time are:

Quaternion.LookRotation,
Quaternion.Angle,
Quaternion.Euler,
Quaternion.Slerp,
Quaternion.FromToRotation,
Quaternion.identity.

(The other functions are only for exotic uses.)

author: @rcengineer
textdisplay: One interesting question I have after this: In the "seeing via hearing" example, the requirement that similar frequencies be mapped to nearby points in the plane is made. However, the inverse of this - That far-apart frequencies should stay disparate in the output - is left out. We can see from the convergence animation that this is not true of the Hilbert curve, as points on opposite ends of the input can be mapped to points infinitely close together. So my question is: Is there a formal way to define "separate inputs stay separate," and if so, is there a space-filling curve that satisfies this requirement?

author: @rossholst5315
textdisplay:
@3blue1brown

Grant,

I was curious if the set of rational numbers bounded between e and pi was a countably infinite set?

It seems to me this set would not be countable as there is never a number closest to pi or e. There are always an infinitely many more rational numbers.

It would also imply that you needed to know the sequences of e and pi to an infinite number of digits.

However if we consider uncountably infinite sets to be larger than the countably infinite sets of all rationals, it would imply this subset of rationals is larger than the entire set of rational numbers.

Implying a subset can be larger than the entire set. Every rational bounded by this space will also be listed in the entire set of rational numbers. The entire set will also contain an uncountably larger amount of rationals that lie outside these bounds.

So either, this rational subset is countable or this subset is larger than the set? So the partial set is larger than the full set?

Thanks if you have time to respond.

author: @rossholst5315
textdisplay:
I am assuming there is a way to count them, I just cannot think how it could be done.

But if these rationals are a subset of a countable set, then this set should also be countable.

I was hoping there was a proof out there that you might be aware of to assist.

author: @LinhNguyen-nh8oq
textdisplay: The way I think about this is that the larger the sum, the more likely the pattern. So basically, It made the decision on how much percent the pattern appear base on previous input. And in the process of making a decision, neurons which have the most weight is the most important input in making a decision. So the more green the weight is, the more important of the neuron in the process of determing the percent. And reverse for red weight. So back to your question, we want to identify the edge pattern(which is a white line and the surrounding will be black pixel), so the middle pixel have to be the brightest and the surrounding will be darkest. Hope this helps you

author: @drewarnold6741
textdisplay: Digital neural networks are not and will not be part of any type of general intelligence. Intelligence is not stored data and an architecture to relate and access it. Look at it this way... a person is not "intelligent" because of basic network wiring in their brain. Rather their intelligence stems from two cells (egg and sperm) which propagate and self assemble into a complex organism that it self can observe and manipulate the world around it. That is intelligence. We are so far off from creating something like that and touting that a "neural network" is a key component or accelerator to general AI is pure fantasy.

author: @igorg4129
textdisplay:
Guess that Literally ALL (please fix me, I hope to be wrong) videos about the Gradient Descent miss one key thing.
They forget to mention that the Loss surface (the one we search the global minimum on) is actually different for each and every observation. It is not like I have one surface and I deal with it all the way, it is wrong! The truth is that I have N different loss surfaces while N is the dataset size. This fact especially matters when trying to explain stochastic gradient descent where after each observation we want to update the weights.
p.s
Yes I am aware that when we do batch gradient descent there is some kind of average loss surface whose existence is a problem by itself, but this fact never emphasized

author: @5yago.960
textdisplay: Sorry, just noticed a mistake and wanted to point it out. What you are calling Stochastic Gradient Decent is actually called Mini Batch Gradient Decent. SGD is actually when you take a gradient and update the parameters at every single observation, while MBGD is where we split the data into subsets and update the parameters based on each subset (what you were referring to in the video). Loves the video though, a lot was clarified  for me. Keep up the good work :)

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Two things worth adding here:
1) In other resources and in implementations, you'd typically see these formulas in some more compact vectorized form, which carries with it the extra mental burden to parse the Hadamard product and to think through why the transpose of the weight matrix is used, but the underlying substance is all the same.

2) Backpropagation is really one instance of a more general technique called "reverse mode differentiation" to compute derivatives of functions represented in some kind of directed graph form.

author: @ggsproud
textdisplay:
Why value of cost function at 01:36 is (activatation - desired ) ^2 ?

Saw it in previous video, but not sure why it that value, why it can't be any other value say "cubed" or "sqrt" ?

author: @moswanedev
textdisplay:
We are looking to minimize the distance between activation and desired. if (activation = desired), then it means that our activation layer is giving us exactly what we are looking for because (activation = desired) when (activation - desired) = 0 (A minimised cost function). We square it so that we get the distance(but squared) between the two because the distance is never negative.

Ideally, we should minimize C = |activation - desired| = sqrt(activation - desired)^2 because this is the real definition of the distance. But that's an extra layer of computation that would not affect our resultant weights and biases.

I hope this helps a bit.

author: @securemax
textdisplay: For everyone wanting to implement backprop from scratch: don't use dC/da = 2*(a-y). Instead use dC/da = a-y. This is because the cost function would actually be defined with a factor 1/2 in front which is missing here. Hence, the derivative changes. All other derivatives are good :)

author: @h_ass_an
textdisplay: 8:03 why did the height of the triangle increase as dr got smaller?

author: @sunyog
textdisplay:
As dr got smaller, we got more accurate, when the rectangles were big i.e. when the dr was bigger, the error was also bigger (error here means the tiny area that was at the top of rectangle and below the line of function) and as the size of dr got smaller, the error reduced, which means that when dr was bigger it didn't account for tiny area that was left at the top of rectangle and as the rectangles became thinner, they started accounting for the area that was left (we became more accurate, as the error reduced).

To answer your question the (tiny amount of)height of triangle changed because the height of rectangle changed, you should think backward, the area with smaller dr was correct (increased height of rectangles(or triangle) was correct) but as dr got bigger they started leaving tiny amount area at the top (the error) and hence the change in height of rectangles changed which kinda eventually changed the height of triangle.

I tried mate especially with my poor English, sorry if you still didn't get it, try to draw on the paper, one diagram will contain bigger rectangles and another will contain smaller. "The height triangle didn't really change it only got more accurate."

author: @h_ass_an
textdisplay: @@sunyog I think understand now, so the smaller dr got, the more accurate the measurement of area became and the apparent increase in height is a result of that. Thanks for clarifying.

author: @juststudying1019
textdisplay:
Thanks.

This is a simple PHP program that do what is in the video.

<?php

define('RADIUS', 6);
define('RINGS_COUNT', 6 * 10000000);

// Represents dr.
$thickness = RADIUS / RINGS_COUNT;

// The area of the circle, that we are calculating.
$circleArea = 0;

// Loop through each ring from the circle.
for ($i = 1; $i <= RINGS_COUNT; $i++) {
// Calculate the radius of the current circle (ring after cutting it).
$radius = $i * $thickness;

// Circumference of the current circle.
$height = 2 * pi() * $radius;

// Since the shape is almost a rectangular shape, its area is : height * width.
$ringArea = $thickness * $height;

// Sum the area of the current current ring to the circle.
$circleArea += $ringArea;
}

echo "[Algorithm]: " . $circleArea . PHP_EOL;

echo "[Formula]: " . pi() * (RADIUS*RADIUS) . PHP_EOL;

author: @stevendebettencourt7651
textdisplay:
I would like to add one thing about the change in speed at an instant thing, and my apologies if someone e rose already pointed this out in the comments, but it is important to note.

In mathematics, we can keep subdividing intervals as much as we want without regard to reality. Hence, why we get paradoxes line Gabriel‚Äôs Horn and Achilles and the Tortoise. So in Calculus, we can end up with these situations that seem inherently not in keeping with our everyday experience.

However, physics eventually takes hold in the real world. Quantum physics shows that time CANNOT be infinitely subdivided. Once you reach the Planck Time or Planck Length, you cannot get a smaller interval; this is as small as it gets. And here is where all paradoxes are resolved.

author: @cooperclark362
textdisplay:
Been sitting at my desk for 2 hours. Here's my thoughts (with tons of other people's ideas I found) for the proof of the derivative of 1/x.

First important thing to keep in mind is that we're looking for d(1/)/dx = ???

We know that the area must be equal to 1. So, even with the "small nudge", the change in the width and height should net the change in area to 0.

Therefore, we know that x (the original width) + dx (the small nudge in width) times 1/x (the original width) plus d(1/x) (the small nudge in width) will still equal 1.

So, we have¬†
1. (x + dx) times 1/x + d(1/x) = 1
We need to isolate d(1/x) so we can plug it into our original question: d(1/x)/dx = ???
Divide both sides by x + dx
2. 1/x + d(1/x) = 1/(x + dx)
Move 1/x to the right side
3. d(1/x) = 1/(x +dx) -1/x
Combine the terms by making a common denominator of x(x + dx)
4. d(1/x) = x - (x + dx)/x(x + dx)
Distribute the negative in the numerator and expand the denominator
5. d(1/x) = x - x -dx/x^2 + x(dx)
The exes in the numerator cancel out
6. d(1/x) = -dx/x^2 + x(dx)
Plug this in for d(1/x) in the original question
7. [-dx/x^2 + x(dx)]/dx
Divide by dx
8. -dx/x^2 +x(dx) times 1/dx = -dx/x^2(dx) + x(dx)^2
Each term now contains at least 1 (dx) which can be cancelled out
9. -1/(x^2 + x(dx))
Allow (dx) to approach 0 and you're left with
10. -1/x^2

author: @xnonqme3716
textdisplay: The derivative of sqrt(x), in visualization, is a carbon copy of the derivative of x^2, which we know is 2x. Substituting sqrt(x) for x^2, you get: d(x)/d(sqrt(x)) = 2(sqrt(x)). Flip the fraction, you get d(sqrt(x))/d(x) = 1/2sqrt(x). This 'pattern' can be replicated for any derivative that can be visualized as a square.

author: @Suffered_Heart
textdisplay:
For people wondering about similar triangle claim. Read below:

First let's name:
radius mentioned with angle ùúÉ rad from x axis: OB
radius in x axis: OA
d(sin(ùúÉ)): DC, C being closer to x axis than D
d(ùúÉ): BD

Now stretch the line (tangent) BD towards x axis to arbitrary point P

*Draw them and name them in paper first*

Now we gonna use following theorems:

1. When a triangle's side is extended, the resultant exterior angle formed is equal to the sum of the measures of the two opposite interior angles of the triangle.
2. Tangent is perpendicular to circle
3. AA similarity rule: When 2 angles are equal then both triangle are similar.
4. If a transversal cuts two parallel lines, each pair of alternate interior angles are equal.

We have this assumption: that BD is along the tangent.

Now let's prove ‚ñ≥OAB ~ ‚ñ≥DCB

‚à†OBA + ‚à†ABP = 90¬∞ (Theoram 2) - - -i

‚à†CBO + ‚à†OBA + ‚à†ABP = ‚à†BDC + ‚àüDCB ( Theoram 1) - - - ii

(‚à†CBO + ‚à†OBA + ‚à†ABP) - (‚à†OBA + ‚à†ABP) = ‚à†BDC + 90¬∞ - 90¬∞ (ii - i)

‚à†CBO = ‚à†BDC - - - iii

s line CB || line OA and thus:

OB is transversal here so:

‚à†CBO = ‚à†BOA = ùúÉ (Theoram 4)

=> ‚à†BDC = ‚à†BOA = ùúÉ (iii) - - - iv

‚àüDCB = ‚àüBOA = 90¬∞ - - - v

From iv & v we can apple AA similarity rule (Theorem 3); ergo ‚ñ≥OAB ~ ‚ñ≥DCB. Furthermore statement iv basically tells us that angle he told was ùúÉ.

author: @akankshagupta4138
textdisplay:
Hi, I'm having a problem getting -x^-2. Can you please help me out?

Area remains constant as we change the dimensions of the rectangle.
Hence, initial area = final area.
1= [ x + dx ] [ (1/x) - d(1/x) ]
1= x (1/x) - x d(1/x) + (1/x) dx - dx d(1/x)
x and 1/x multiply to give one.
We subtract one on both sides to get zero on one side.
We multiply both sides with -1.
0 =x d(1/x) - (1/x) dx + dx d(1/x)
x d(1/x) + dx d(1/x) =(1/x) dx
x + dx = (1/x) [ dx / d(1/x) ]
x^2 + x dx = dx / d(1/x)
As dx tends to 0, x dx also tends to 0, hence we can sort of ignore it.
x^2 = dx / d(1/x)
d(1/x) / dx = x^(-2)

author: @isaac4727
textdisplay:
the sum rule is simply the sum of the derivative of the parts, for example you can most likely differentiate x^2 + x in a second. this is a sum of two functions, you can see it pop right out from first principals if you take some a(x) and some b(x)
and want to differentiate their sum, you can plug it into the defining formula for the derivative. let f(x) = a(x) + b(x)
f(x+h) will be a(x+h) + b(x+h)

f(x+h) - f(x) is the same as
(a(x+h)-a(x))+(b(x+h)-a(x))
note that here, this sum is the numerator of the first principle formula for both a and b, and given both will be divided my the same denominator h, the addition is found just adding them. so the derivative of the sum of some functions, is simply the sum of their derivatives

author: @aram5642
textdisplay: This mnemonic for product rule is inefficient IMO. Because it makes you create a separate mnemonic for the quotient rule. If you optimize the mnemonic to gx'fx + fx'gx, you can have basically one mnemonic to remember (just add gx^2 in the denominator). This way you'll never get the order confused - which is essential for the quotient rule but indifferent for the product rule. Therefore always start with the derivative of the second/denominator. My version of the mnemonic is: start with g prime [, divide by g]

author: @r.w.emersonii3501
textdisplay:
Has anybody ever checked to make sure that the derivative rules are consistent?

I just did -- as an interesting exercise. And I'm happy to report that they appear to be. For example:

# Chain rule + product rule
d( 1 / ( 1/x)) / dx
= -1 / ( 1 / x)^2 * ( -1 / x^2)
= x^2 / x^2
= 1


# Quotient rule:
d( x^m / x^n) / dx
= ( m * x^( m-1) * x^n - n * x^m * x^( n-1)) / x^n^2
= ( m-n) * x^( m+n-1) / x^n^2
= ( m-n) * x^( m-n-1)

# Chain rule
d( a( cx+d) + b) / dx
= ac

What a relief! Of course, this is just empirical. I wonder whether there is an actual proof of consistency, and whether there are variations of the derivative that lead to inconsistent (non-commutative) results!

I just found a beautiful connection between this and another definition for e.

I tried to model this in desmos to see when this proportionality constant equals 1, but I wanted to sort of generalize it.
So I modeled the equation (y^x-1)/x=1
I did some manipulation
(y^x)/x-(1/x)=1
(y^x)/x=1+1/x
(y^x)/x=(x+1)/x
y^x=x+1
y=(x+1)^(1/x)
y=(1+x)^1/x
In the limit here, x is supposed to be approaching zero.
And if you do this, you get the other famous definition of e! I was not expecting to get this, so the algebraic manipulation wasn't the most clean, I just thought this was a really cool find.

author: @soumyadipbanerjee2074
textdisplay: 8:36 anybody confused about how the expression for dS comes about should consult the formula df=(Œ¥f/Œ¥x)dx+(Œ¥f/Œ¥y)dy+(Œ¥f/Œ¥z)dz if f is a function of x, y and z. Œ¥f/Œ¥x is called the partial derivative of f with respect to x, and it is found in exactly the same way a normal derivative is found, except that we treat y, z and any other variable that f might depend on other than x as constants. The same is true for Œ¥f/Œ¥y and Œ¥f/Œ¥z, with x and z being treated as constants in the first case and x and y as constants in the second case. Now consider S=x^2+y^2. Œ¥S/Œ¥x=2x and Œ¥S/Œ¥y=2y. Thus dS=(Œ¥S/Œ¥x)dx+(Œ¥S/Œ¥y)dy=2xdx+2ydy. That's your very short introduction to multivariable calculus, and the rule that you just used is called the multivariable chain rule üôÇüôÇ

author: @samirkhan6195
textdisplay: The key idea here is that in the equation y = f(x) , x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable, meaning that changes in x directly influence y . However, in an implicit function, no variable is clearly independent; instead, both variables are interrelated and constrained by the equation. Implicit differentiation tells us how changes in one variable relate to changes in another within the constraints.

author: @3blue1brown
textdisplay:
Next up is integrals. Follow the full playlist at http://3b1b.co/calculus

By the way, there is a piece of math, commonly called "non-standard analysis", which makes infinitesimals a rigorous notion, thereby avoiding the need to use limits. That is, in the real number system something like 0.000....(infinitely many 0's)...1 doesn't make sense, it's not an actual number. But the "hyperreal numbers" of non-standard analysis are constructed so as to include a number like this.

I have no problem with that system. I think it's great to invent new math and new number systems meant to rigorously capture a useful intuitive notion, although the construction of the hyperreal numbers requires some questionable usage of the axiom of choice. But I do think it's important to first learn about limits, and how mathematicians made sense out of calculus using the standard real number line without resorting to infinitesimals. It's not a matter of clinging to old systems, it's because limits help to gain a deeper appreciation for structure and character of the real numbers themselves, which in turn will help to understand any extension of those numbers.

author: @peterwenstrup9980
textdisplay: For the most part, the intuitive idea of a limit as "gets close to" works. For fun, I like to show my students the x/floor[x]. The limit as x goes to infinity is 1, but, save for a countably finite number of points and discontinuities, it is greater than one and increasing. So it is essentially never "approaching" or "getting closer to" 1.  Provides a little motivation for the epsilon / M definition of convergence at infinity.

author: @zachrodan7543
textdisplay: 0:28 I often will joke that limits are arguably one of the most intuitive concepts in calculus, or possibly even in all of math: so much so that newton and liebniz were able to manage to explain calculus without bothering to formally define limits (which, like proving that 1+1=2, is a whole lot of effort just to convince people of something they probably already knew intuitively)

author: @rubensf7780
textdisplay: The way I like to think about why you subtract off the anti derivative of the lower bound is that the anti derivative of the top bound measures the volume from zero to that point. But if the volume you want to measure starts at, let‚Äôs say, halfway, you need to subtract the area you don‚Äôt want to count from zero to the halfway point. Then you‚Äôre left with the area from the lower bound (the halfway point) to the top bound
