author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
it's strange how many times you invoke the claim that 3 is a bare, dimensionless number, yet you also claim that 3+5=8.

addition cannot operate over bare, dimensionless numbers. when you attempt to do that the result is undefined:

1 dog +1 dog = 2 dogs; this is the addition you think we're always using
1 dog +1 quail = 2 wings; this is something different, despite using the same exact numbers and relation between them
1 dog +1 quail = 6 legs; now 1+1=6
1 foot +1 yard = 48 inches; 1+1=48
1 half +1 third = 5 sixths; 1+1=5
1 frog +1 pond = 1 pond; 1+1=1
1 C water +1 C dirt = some mud; 1+1 is undefined

addition only works when the units on all terms are the same. the combination of a number and a unit is obviously not a number, because that would be blatantly absurd. 7 giraffes is not a number, 7 is. 4 hours is not a number, 4 is. these combined objects are vectors. so when we're working with 1-dimensional vectors that have no specified unit, and we're adding or subtracting them, we're necessarily using Integers. this in turn renders subtraction just as commutative as addition, because in truth neither is an operation, since the + and - symbols are merely the unit of the term whose magnitude follows the sign. this is why:

4 -3 = -3 +4

these are simply all possible spell-outs of the unordered list of Integers {+4, -3}. the + doesn't appear on the 4 in initial position due to historical reasons, namely + is an abbreviation of the Latin word 'et', meaning 'and', which only further illustrates that addition has always been about listing things, not performing some mystical addition operation over them. and the - symbol was only introduced quite recently, and must appear on negative terms in initial position because negative values are not the default.

this has the effect of invalidating the assertion that the Naturals are a subset of the Integers, since the Naturals are numbers, but the Integers are vectors, as well as showing that the Peano Axioms are nonsense, since they attempt to derive the Naturals from a type of addition, via the successor function, which is later derived into an addition operator in Peano Artihmetic. but we already know that addition has no operator. it further impacts what it means for something to be an Abelian Group (part of the problem is that negative numbers were not systematically accepted in Algebra until the year after Niels Henrik Abel died, so when the concept of Abelian Groups was established later on, based on Abel's work, it naturally excluded them, and subtraction... even though this exclusion is entirely cultural and artificial), among other things.

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
why do we say that |5| = +5?

that's just as incorrect as saying |5| = -5. except, the former is literally baked into the axioms that make up ZF(C).

how is this acceptable?

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
I'd be wary of the claim that it's been proven that all the simple groups have been found.

the reason is that the nature of an axiomatic logic is that it can prove things to be valid with respect to the chosen axioms, but not sound. for soundness, and thus a proof that's actually worth a damn, the axioms must be perfectly correct in the first place.

as I've already demonstrated, modern mathematics is built on a foundation of faulty axioms, since some flavor of the Dedekind-Peano Axioms are central to anything commensurate with ZF(C), but they build up numbers and arithmetic incorrectly. so whatever you prove from them, which is pretty much all of the last century worth of mathematics, including the subject of this video, is suspect.

this isn't to say that I believe that the Monster Group isn't a real mathematical object. it's merely to point out that the path we took to get there is built on mistakes and lies, and thus should be tread with care.

for an example of another core axiom that's simply ridiculous, consider Dedekind Completeness. the idea here is that the Archimedean Property implies that the Reals are continuous... despite no other Archimedean Group being continuous, and the Archimedean Property specifically resulting in the infinite bifurcation of every identifiable gap, rather than the erasure of them. the notion is insanity at best, and sheer idiocy at worst. yet, it's usually included as an axiom.

these things should trouble you.

author: @mickyetanotherone3401
textdisplay:
there's a saying that English teachers have. 'Every rule has an exception.'

your invocation of 'logical necessity' at the end, sounds very similar to this. and my issue with that is the source of this saying among English teachers is that the rules they espouse are actually just wrong.

for instance, everyone claims that English uses an alphabet. yet, everyone who can read English knows this is false, since most English words are very clearly not written alphabetically.

another one is the claim that English has plural marking on nouns. even though 'plural' means more than 1, but you can have 'no dogs', 'one dog', 'two dogs', 'many dogs', etc. so the '-s' appears everywhere that the noun is not singular, not when it's plural. and worse, when the subject noun is singular, this '-s' moves onto the verb:

The dogs run fast. '-s' on non-singular subject noun
The dog runs fast. '-s' on verb with singular subject noun

and then this observation leads us into recognizing that English doesn't have verb tenses. if this '-s' which appears on verbs, and indicates the 'simple present tense', is the same '-s' that appears on non-singular nouns, then it's obviously not fundamentally marking verb tense, is it? further, the other alleged tense markers, '-ed' and '-ing', can appear on adjectives and nouns as well. not to mention, the 'simple present tense' is used to talk about things that are timelessly true, which by definition means it's not a tense. and '-ed' and '-ing' can appear with a past, present or future reference, so they obviously don't indicate tense either.

methinks similar things are going on with mathematics. the reason things seem so weird to you is that the rules you've put your confidence in are simply wrong.

and honestly, it'd be very weird if this weren't the case. for the most part, this type of mathematics derives from a roughly 50 year spurt of innovation in the early and mid-1800s, which strongly corresponds with the period between the end of the Napoleonic Wars and the Unification of Germany and the formation of the Kingdom of Italy. following this period of innovation was a period of codification, wherein we get figures like Georg Cantor, Giuseppe Peano, Richard Dedekind, David Hilbert, Bertrand Russell, etc. and the goal was to reformulate mathematics to encapsulate everything that was newly discovered in the early years of the 19th century. this period of codification ran roughly from the time of the Unification of Germany to the First World War.

after this, the major players in the mathematics industry suffered so many losses that it's accurate to say that we're looking at a mass extinction event in, not only mathematics, but across the sciences in general. in the wake of which the Vienna Circle grew to prominence, and with the rise of National Socialism, disbanded across the globe. where their ideology took hold just in time to seed the generation that would repopulate these industries after the second wave of mass extinction occurred during WWII. out of this we actually even specifically get Kuhn, who saw precisely what I'm describing, but misinterpreted it as being about the quality of ideas, rather than repopulation events. but all of his examples of revolutions come immediately after horrendous wars, like Newton's rise in the immediate aftermath of the English Civil War.

and this pattern is in fact so robust that French mathematicians in the interwar period, recognizing that they were mostly students, largely ignorant of the nuances of the discoveries of the 19th century, came together and formed Nicolas Bourbaki in order to preserve what fragmented knowledge they had left between them. and this sets the stage for the era we're in now, and have been in since about the 1920s. which is an era of popularization.

so when you review this timeline it should strike you that the major pivotal moments come not due to any specific thing occurring within the field of mathematics, but things occurring in the world of geopolitics. the transition from innovation to codification came not because the innovation reached some specific level of sophistication, but because the way people thought about the world, and their place in it, changed. and this era of codification ended not because it was in any way finished, but because WWI happened. and the era of popularization occurred not because the two stages that came before were tidy enough to be disseminated to the masses, but because the risk of forgetting everything was a very real looming threat in the aftermath of WWI and WWII.

so, it's an odd position to take to say that this foundation which was hastily patched together by just a few men, under the belief that mathematics should be couched in the language of logic, a belief which was later shown to be misguided, is something that will stand the test of time. because there's absolutely no evidence supporting that conclusion.

author: @stephenzhao5809
textdisplay: 2:20 ... I think when I first heard someone reference fractional dimension like this I just thought it was nonsense, right? I mean, mathematicicans are clearly just making stuff up. 2:29 Dimension is something that usually only makes sense for natural numbers, right? A line is one-dimensional; a plane, that's two dimensional; this space that we live in, that's three dimensional, and so on. 2:38 ... 4:25 Typically in math, the word that you use for this is "Measure", but I think it might be more intuitive to talk about "mass". As in, image that metal: A thin wire, a flat sheet, a solid cube, and some kind of Sierpinski mesh. Fractual dimension has everything to do with understanding how the mass of these shapes changes as you scale them. 4:46 The benefit of starting the discussion with self-similar shapes is that it gives us a nice clear-cut way to compare masses. When you scale down that line by one half, the mass is also scaled down by one-half, which you can viscerally see because it takes two copies of that smaller one to form the whole. 5:04 When you scale down a square by one-half, its mass is scaled down by one fourth, where again you can see this by piecing together four of the smaller copies to get the original. Likewise, when you scale down that cube by one half, the mass is scalled down by one eithth, or one-half cubed, because it takes eight copies of that. 5:25 ... 9:12 ... What I've described so far, everything up to this point is what you might call "self-similarity dimension". It does a good job making the idea of fractional dimension seem at least somewhat reasonable, but there's a problem. 9:26

author: @PaoloGasparini-ux2kp
textdisplay:
As is known, Euler's identity is a formula that Richard Feynman, like many others, found remarkable because it connects some very important mathematical constants.
= is the necessary condition
1 and 0 are the neutral elements of the product and the sum respectively,
e is the base of natural logarithms,
i is the imaginary unit, the complex number whose square is -1, and finally
pi represents the ratio between the length of a circle and its diameter.

The first formulation makes explicit the relationship between the five mathematical constants contained therein:
The number 0, is the neutral element for addition.
The number 1.
The number pi is fundamental in trigonometry; is a constant for a world that is Euclidean or for small scales in a non-Euclidean geometry (otherwise, the ratio of the length of a circle's circumference to its diameter would not be a universal constant, i.e. the same for all circumferences ).
The number e is a fundamental constant (also called Nepero's number) connected to the study of logarithms in analysis (such as differential equations).
The imaginary unit i is a unit in complex numbers. The introduction of this unit makes all non-constant polynomial equations solvable in the field of complex numbers (see fundamental theorem of algebra).
The formula contains an irrational power (the Neperian irrational number e, raised to an exponent containing the irrational factor pi), is rare in mathematical formulae. It connects real irrational numbers (e), imaginary irrational numbers (pi), and integers (1).
Furthermore, all the fundamental operators of arithmetic are present: equality, addition, multiplication, and exponentiation. All the basic assumptions of complex analysis are present, and the integers 0 and 1 are related to the field of complex numbers.
(source: wiki)


The mathematical analogy seems to me thus instituted with a philosophical theorem of creation. It could be the following:
the world (the created universe) adds nothing to God, and this can be represented by Euler's identity.
"To create is to continually create new"
[Luther, Resolutions on Indulgences (WA I, p.563)].
"If you try to subtract the Spirit from creation, all things mix and their life appears without law, without order, without any determination"
[Basil the Great, Of the Holy Spirit, XVI, 38 (PG 32, 137 B].
"Without the Spirit, the whole of creation cannot last" (Ambrogio, Dello Spirito Santo, II, 5, 33).
"The universe was about to fall back into chaos and dissolve in dismay in the face of passion if the great Jesus had not poured out the divine spirit of him, exclaiming:" Father, into your hands I commend my Spirit "(Lk 23:46) . And immediately, with the diffusion of the divine Spirit, as revived, quickened and consolidated, the universe found its stability"
[Ancient Easter homily, 55 (SCh 27, p. 183)]

So, finally, considering in a hierarchical steps the four main disciplines of human endeavors, we could state an interdisciplinary comment like that.
The word poetry means "making", literally ‚Äì poiesis. Poetry is fundamental speech. Prose is less fundamental speech. Prose is fallen poetry; poetry is not decorated prose. The original language, for Heidegger and for Lewis in The Magician's Nephew, was music. Now music usually has words, so words are in the music. But those words are words for music. Take them out of the music and they're still poetry, but make them fall one step further and they're prose. Make them fall one step further and they're mathematics, which is the only univocal, unambiguous language in the world. The most ambiguous language in the world is music. And therefore it's the richest. How will the tower of Babel be undone; how will we understand each other in heaven? Will we all speak English, or Dutch? No, we'll all speak music.

author: @angeldude101
textdisplay:
I actually personally hate the typical version of e^iœÄ + 1 = 0, and this video shows why: because it mixes the additive group with the multiplicative group. The additive group belongs solely in the exponent, not down to be added to the result of said exponent, which otherwise lives in the multiplicative group.

The presence of the "5 most important numbers in mathematics" is frankly a meaningless property and its beauty pales in comparison to the equation showing that a 180¬∞ rotation is equivalent to an inversion across the origin. Two different multiplicative actions that might look different at first, but are really the same thing (at least in 2D).

author: @AscendantPerfection
textdisplay:
Hey guys.
Here to simplify things.

Let's begin with dimensions.
Left, right, up, down, forward and backwards.
An easier way to explain dimension is, the general path anything takes when it's being squished on two ends.
If something squishes you from right and left, you can only go up and down, or forward and backward.
Therefore forward and backwards are you dimensions.
If something squishes you forward and backward, left and right, you can only go up and down.
Therefore up and down are your dimensions.

So area is simply how many times has a single line in one or two dimensions been repeated in another one dimension.

This definition applies to areas, not volumes.

Area of a rectangle is length times width because that straight line length which goes left or right, has been repeated width number of times, width being either forward or backwards OR up or down.

Now for a rectangle, the length is a straight line. And so is the width. So the area is a simple multiplication.

But in the case of a sphere, that length is a diameter of a circle, which has expanded left and right (one dimension), as well as forward and backwards (another dimension) in all possible ways you can turn.

Like a wave that forms when a stone is dropped in a pond of calm water. That circle has stretched out by its diameter.
And that diameter is our length.

If a circle has stretched out left and right, forward and backwards, that means the only other dimension left is up and down.
Meaning the circle can be flipped or rotate up and down.

So here's the question with area of a sphere.
How many times did a diameter of a circle which goes left and right, forward and backward, repeat itself in going up and down.

To visualize this...
Picture one circle, let's call it Circle A, with a diameter that goes left and right, forward and backwards.
Imagine that circle A is fitted inside another circle, let's call it Circle B with a diameter that goes up and down.

Now keep on drawing more circles like Circle A, as if to get a picture by picture rendition of rotating circle A around circle B provided they all fit in circle B, and it won't be long before you notice that you're tracing out the circumference of Circle B.

Equally so, you'll notice that there will be two ends of circle A, that will not rotate and will stay fixed. These two connected, form your diameter, such that if you're rotating circle A in circle B, there will be two points in circle A, that will not touch circle B and will stay fixed throughout the rotation.
The distance between these two points is what we are measuring the repetition of.

And so a very logical definition based meaning is that how many times did we repeat that diameter in going up and down.

Diameter is 2r. And the circumference is 2œÄr...
Multiply these two and you get your surface area.

I'm not sure if any of this made sense, but I'm putting it out here to whoever will understand or care.

Aight!

author: @fggolding
textdisplay:
I like the problem. The corresponding ring is the one at doble of the angel theta.

1) 2piRsin(tetha)
2) 2piRsin(tetha)Rcos(theta)d-tetha
3) 2piR^2sin(tetha)cos(theta)d-tetha=1/2(2piR^2sin(2tetha)d-tetha)
4) To each ring at tetha correspond a second ring at 2xtetha
5) While tetha goes from zero to pi/2, 2thetha goes from zero to pi. So, the north hemisphere is sweept with theta, while 2tetha sweept the whole sphere. And finally, tetha going from p/2 to pi, the south hemisphere, 2tetha goes from pi to 2pi. There is the factor 4.

author: @Rubixdecampo
textdisplay:
Great video and all that, but why should english students study Shakespeare? It is an outdated form of english and not in use today. If considering the roots of the language, maybe a bit of middle or olde english, high german or tracing the language back to sanskrit, or whatever for etymological reasons or studying literature and history .. maybe some french and latin that modern english has been infused with, but what I don't understand is : why the reference to Shakespeare? Most of the works are depressing tragedies and its matter of taste, who wants to read dark depressing works in an antiquated dialect.
I would say that there are thousands of authors with a better command of modern english, that could be recommended to english students, and just because something is old and was popular before doesn't make it better now. In the same way many modern works are total shit. I would recommend someone like Bill Bryson for example for english students, as he uses a wide , yet precise vocabulary and colloquialisms from the modern era.

author: @Attemptedburger
textdisplay:
ok, so I'm pausing to try and guess, so let me work through this from the point right after you said "please do pause"



ok, I can't figure it out, but my two most interesting observations are that

1. a cone and a plane can both be revolutions of 2d counterparts, triangles and lines.

2. I know if you cut a triangle the end you cut off will fit backwards because the edge is guaranteed to be the same length along the cut, and that the cone is guaranteed to be a triangle from all angles when viewed along the plane.

3. a sphere that is tangent to the cone can be tangent to the intersection of the plane and the cone at two points, and will be centered on the intersection as well. because the cone and the plane are both symmetrical in this axis, their intersection will be symmetrical in this axis as well.

4. because the intersection is symmetrical across the shortest path through the center and the longest path through the center is perpendicular, I think, but I'm not quite smart enough to piece together at this hour, that any line that passes through the center can be reflected by the long path to show a symmetry that means the cone could be sliced by the plane and then rotated 180 around an axis pependicular to the plane so that the shapes on either side of the slice match back up, showing that the shape is fully symmetrical along the long path of the intersection.

5. math in my head is hard, and I deserve a gold star for trying this

6. I don't know how the spheres help exactly, but It looks like they are tangent to the plane at the foci of the intersection.

I'm resuming the video now.

author: @pauselab5569
textdisplay: I have been trying to prove this with projections but could only do it for the limiting case of a cylinder. basically a projection of a circle from a point at infinity to a tilted plane must preserve distances in the direction of that plane(which can be thought as the axis of rotation). The transformation must then only affect the other dimension of the plane hence why the slice of a cylinder is always a cone. Tried to generalize to points that are not infinitely far away but not sure how to do it. I think it has something to do with how the direction of the plane that is preserved under projection from a point at infinity now changes a little because of the slant of the cone.

author: @fredeisele1895
textdisplay:
For me... I realize that, on the cone, the distance between a circle above the elipse and a circle below the elipse (measured along a ray anchored at the vertex of the cone) is a constant. From this we see that any curve which passes around the cone has the property that the sum of the distance to the two circles is constant. Then I am lead to the spheres for which the cicles are tangent.

This is interesting as it introduces a family of new conic sections which are not described by a plane (slicing a cone) but by anything slicing a cone.

author: @JudCary
textdisplay: Being a mathematician (and lawyer), these videos great.  And, this video on Wordle makes sense statistically. Some improvements? I like to start with ADIEU.  It provides information on 4 vowels.  I think vowels provide more info than consonants, at least at the BEGINNING of the puzzle. So, you could adjust the model to weight vowels higher earlier in the guesses.  Next, (in hard mode) I combine the known letters with RST, maybe Y.  again, RST, Y, are 1) more likely and 2) provide / eliminate a lot of possibilities.  From there, I dunno; use the WORDLE crutch to go from there!  Good luck.

author: @user-ud6ui7zt3r
textdisplay:
I dominate when it comes to WORDLE. I can play 600 games in a row and never fail to guess the word correctly. By design, I intentionally selected [5] words that I always play in a specific sequence.
(note: only occasionally do I alternate the sequence of my last two special words.) My [5] special words, in as few guesses as possible, exhaust all possible vowels and all possible "double s" combinations. If everyone promises to NAME my method after me (John Berry), I will now reveal my [5] special words. They are (always played in the following sequence)...

FILTH
PROSE
AMUCK
WAGES
BONDS

As mentioned before, I occasionally use the word BONDS before the word WAGES.
Try my method! Before you know it, you too will be playing 300 games in a row without missing a single word! In fact, the only time I DON'T get the right word is when there are TWO POSSIBLE WORDS with the 5 (or 4 or 3) letters that remain. When that happens, I find that the official WORDLE website always selects the word (of the two that are possible) that comes FIRST in alphabetical order.

author: @fr89k
textdisplay: At 4:20 you hear a prime example for overengineering. And it is also not surprising that it comes from a mathematician. Yes, of course it is more beautiful to have an algorithm that doesn't need to know the list of possible answers. It is more generic and hence more reusable. This is striving for perfection. However, was the initial goal to program a universal word solver? No, it wasn't. So, while striving for perfection, we lost focus of the actual goal. Thus, the resulting tool probably won't perform as well as it could. This is really a challenge for many engineers and programmers: Getting the perfectionist in you under control and keep the actual goal in focus instead of striving for the "perfect" solution, which surprisingly often isn't that perfect. Perfect is often the enemy of good. We see this at the very end, when he includes the list of possible solutions into the algorithm.

author: @codelapiz
textdisplay:
i think the introductory example is disingenuous. When people ask a question like that "here is a description of a person is he class A og B", it is not appropriate at all to assume this is person is randomly sampled from the population. i think what is instead implied, the way most people hear such a question, is that the person is sampled from the archetypes of their respective classes. Eg you take the x most libererian libererians and x most farmer farmers, and pick one. why would you say its eigther a farmer or a liberarian if not. Is a more valid answer that you think hes a teacher because those are more common?

now i would say as an example to teach bayes theorem, this is not that bad. However many people will use such thought experiments to try to convince people to use a more "logical" mindset. The fact is in the real world when you are faced with a question like that, not asked by someone that designed it to trick you, cleansing your mindset from context, and trying to find a few variables and use math will be less accurate than using your intuition on the whole context of the question asked, why it was asked, who asked, etc.

author: @bohanxu6125
textdisplay:
What seems to bother/confuse me is that bayse theorem just looks like a static equation about joint probability. It seems to just describe a static reality... But the interpretation is a dynamical/iterative scheme to update subjective belief.

The libertarian-farmer example has a hypothesis that has a well defined prior probability (the fraction of librarian is a objective reality). In other context, the probability about belief is fundamentally ill defined. For instance, the likelihood of string theory is correct (over all current theory) has a definite binary answer while our assignment of prior probability is totally ill defined and subjective... This example is more about updating subjective belief while the librarian-farmer example is more about describing well defined static reality. One example requires some kind of iterative convergence to give rigorous result while the other give rigorous result without the need for iteration

author: @N.i.c.k.H
textdisplay:
I think it is interesting to show how this shows why you cannot change the minds of rational, true believers: For a true believer, P(H)=1 and therefore P(NOT(H))=0 and so, for ANY evidence E, P(H|E) reduces to P(E|H)/P(E|H) = 1
(This assumes that they even do the calculation, because P(H)=1 implies that P(E|H) should be 0 for any true counter evidence and hence either E is not actually counter evidence at all or else it must be faked)
I've seen somewhere that 0 and 1 should not be thought of as probabilities in the same way the infinity is not a number and this shows why that view makes sense, or at least that they can only reasonably be used to as probabilities in the mathematical realm where they are kind of the values by definition e.g. probability that 1+1=2 where, if you have counter evidence then it can only be because we mean different things by "1","+" and/or "=".

author: @joeo3377
textdisplay: Technically, this isn't Snell's law, but the law of refraction (which is true for all waves). Snell's law is the application of the law of refraction to light where we multiply both sides of the equation by the speed of light c, which allows us to write the equation in terms of the indices of refraction.

author: @HunterJE
textdisplay: I remember back in my school days I would sometimes take a shortcut to class cutting diagonally across a couple of fields to get to class faster, and noticed partway there that one of the fields was firm and easy going and the other was wet and muddy and a bit of a slog to walk across. I distinctly remember wondering to myself while crossing that field one day about a hypothetical best path to trade off added distance to more of the walk spent on the firmer ground to traverse the fields as fast as possible. Some time later I learned about Snell's law and the idea immediately clicking in terms of the two fields, it was such a strange and rare instance of having somehow lived a thought experiment before learning about the concept it explains...

author: @SimulatingPhysics
textdisplay:
Here there is an alternative derivation of Snell Law (very simple), using the conservation of momentum of photons:

If in medium 1 the index of refraction is n1 and in medium 2 the index of refraction is n2 and for the definition of index of refractions and wavelength we have:
n1 = c / v1 , v1 = Œª1 * f
n2 = c / v2 , v2 = Œª2 * f

Dividing the above equations we obtain: n2 / n1 = Œª1 /Œª2
So if n2 is higher than n1, the wavelength in medium 2 is smaller than in medium 1.

Now because the photon momentum is: p = h / Œª
Applying the conservation of momentum of the incident and transmitted photon along the parallel line of medium separation:

p1 = p2 ‚Üí h/Œª1 *sin(Œ∏1) = h/Œª2 *sin(Œ∏2) ‚Üí n1 *sin(Œ∏1) = n2 *sin(Œ∏2)

This is the Snell Law!!
So the refraction is just a consequence of the conservation of momentum of photons!

There are a lot of ways of derive this law!

author: @jeffreyblack666
textdisplay:
Except the basis of this refuted by a simple mirror.
If you have light shining onto a mirror, reflecting back and hitting a detector, it takes quite a long path.
A much shorter and quicker path is for light to simply curve back around.

If the fundamental basis for this proof was actually true, laser ranging systems and radar would not work.
The fact that they do, and that light takes a different amount of time depending on the distance to the object rather than always taking the fastest path, shows that the fundamental basis for this proof is wrong.

author: @knotwilg3596
textdisplay:
Not that it means much in the bigger scheme of the tremendous value you bring, but since you seem interested in well versed criticism, I see three reasons why this animated explanation is less convincing than the standard you hold:
1) you introduce a physical representation which however does not exist
2) you say that it must be proportional to the inverse of the speed of light, but it could be the square inverse, or any power times constant
3) and force has unit of measurement Newton, which is not equal to s/m
So the whole argument is just a bit too magical to be a credible alterntive for calculus. It sure delivers the same result but we only know that through the calculus backing up the argument, not because of the intrinsic truth of the argument being made apparent through your visualization. It's more trick than truth.

But as said (and deviously hamburgering my criticism) your videos are always a treat.

author: @Xogroroth666
textdisplay:
0 (or absolute nil) is infinite.
Infinitely small, that is.
For proof:
Divide 1 without cheating until you get to 0.
With what you divide it by is up to you.

You'll notice, you'll never ever get to 0.
It is like trying to reach absolute Kelvin:
There's always a left-over.
Cannot be done.

author: @Xogroroth666
textdisplay:
This is why the silly "Static-" or "Infinite Universe" is the work of a madman:
Out of absolute 0 nothing can come forth, not even energy.
This is the biggest fail ever.

author: @Xogroroth666
textdisplay:
Dead simple logic:
Out of nothing, only ONE thing can come forth:
NOTHING.

Fact is just that:
Fact.

author: @imkharn
textdisplay:
Android app Fraksl does this! You move fingers on the screen like you would to manipulate a picture. Can move along 3 dimensions to explore the possible 'solution' space of fractals.

Its a large space to explore containing some of the fractals in this video (but all rainbow and trippy), but if you dig deep there is advanced places. An easier one to find is a tree of life looking fractal. Once you get a feel for it you can imagine a shape and feel around to see if you are getting closer. Found a black and white flux capacitor pattern. Got a dragon head once but I didn't save never able to find it again. Only tip I got is that the most novel shapes lie in regions where its really sensitive to touch and it takes a long time to render details.

author: @rcengineer
textdisplay: One interesting question I have after this: In the "seeing via hearing" example, the requirement that similar frequencies be mapped to nearby points in the plane is made. However, the inverse of this - That far-apart frequencies should stay disparate in the output - is left out. We can see from the convergence animation that this is not true of the Hilbert curve, as points on opposite ends of the input can be mapped to points infinitely close together. So my question is: Is there a formal way to define "separate inputs stay separate," and if so, is there a space-filling curve that satisfies this requirement?

author: @rossholst5315
textdisplay:
@3blue1brown

Grant,

I was curious if the set of rational numbers bounded between e and pi was a countably infinite set?

It seems to me this set would not be countable as there is never a number closest to pi or e. There are always an infinitely many more rational numbers.

It would also imply that you needed to know the sequences of e and pi to an infinite number of digits.

However if we consider uncountably infinite sets to be larger than the countably infinite sets of all rationals, it would imply this subset of rationals is larger than the entire set of rational numbers.

Implying a subset can be larger than the entire set. Every rational bounded by this space will also be listed in the entire set of rational numbers. The entire set will also contain an uncountably larger amount of rationals that lie outside these bounds.

So either, this rational subset is countable or this subset is larger than the set? So the partial set is larger than the full set?

Thanks if you have time to respond.

author: @rossholst5315
textdisplay:
I am assuming there is a way to count them, I just cannot think how it could be done.

But if these rationals are a subset of a countable set, then this set should also be countable.

I was hoping there was a proof out there that you might be aware of to assist.

author: @gravemind7545
textdisplay:
Is the answer 57? I haven't seen the video yet. Let's see if I got it.
Edit - Alright I did get it, but I found it in a different way :
1-2-4-8-16-31
Difference between numbers of first series :
1-2-4-8-15
Difference between numbers of second series :
1-2-4-7
Difference between numbers of third series :
1-2-3
Voila! So next number in fourth series is 4, so next number in third series is 7+4=11, so next number in second series is 15+11=26, so next number in original series is 31+26=57!

As for myself, I reasoned Euler's Characteristic Formula by looking at a tetrahedron, and then considering what would happen if an edge got a new vertex inside (it would be accompanied by the original edge splitting into 2 edges, and then there being a new pair of edges within each of the 2 face adjacent to the original edge and those 2 faces splitting into a pair of face), or if a new edge was inscribed in a face (the face would split into a pair of faces) , or if a face got a new vertex inside (it would be accompanied by a new set of edges with the number being the face rank (M), and the original face being split up into a new set of faces with the number also being the face rank), with the net result being the formula.

author: @David-cm4dr
textdisplay: consider n types of gems, each with infinit amount of numbers of gem, with a uniform distribution the cut would be in the middle of the chain, thus being the best case. An example would be (ABCDABCDABCD....). The opposite of this best case would be that all the same gem occupies the same section of the chain followed by the other grounps of same gem, cutting this chain would require a cut in the middle in each gem group, precisely n cuts for n types of gems. An example for this would be (AA\AABB\BBCC\CCDD\DD....). Iterate this patten for a limited workable amount of gems would yield the same conclusion.

textdisplay: Watch the actual video. This question can actually be used to prove that on ANY planet, there are 2 points completely opposite of eachother that have the EXACT same temperature and pressure, no matter the weather.

textdisplay: @@bloopletank2491 I heard that before but I didn‚Äôt believe it one bit. Curious to see how dividing a necklace proves it tho

author: @Carl_with_a_k_
textdisplay: @@bloopletank2491 watched the video, and it definitely did NOT prove that 2 points on earth have the same temperature and pressure. The theoretical version of this using a graphed sphere is 100% true and proven, but absolutely not on a planetary scale where the pressure and temperature are the same. The earth is so large and complex with miles of atmosphere giving us BARELY predictable weather patterns. Even more untrue when you bring up gas giants like Jupiter.

author: @bloopletank2491

author: @sploofmcsterra4786
textdisplay:
@Tripster369 If a plane wave of light hits a medium at an angle, if it didn't change direction in the medium, the plane wave would now be travelling at an angle to its wavefront. This is because the light that hits the medium first is slowed down for longer, and thus is behind the rest of the light.

Since light is a wave, and can be described (to first order) as an infinite sum of spherical wavelets at the wavefront, it's easy to see why the light bends.

author: @tomsterbg8130
textdisplay: I saw a visualization of refraction in a textbook and it really helped to understand the subject. Basically the beam of light was crossed by perpendicular lines that change angle when entering the prism. This easily allows us to see how the light gets deflected as the perpendicular lines would change angle and they would still be perpendicular to the beam inside the prism and after. Think of it like throwing a metal rod in water.

author: @musiccer7446
textdisplay: Actually it‚Äôs just that, as the light slows down, by Feynman logic, the path of the shortest amount of time changes, thusly, since all other paths cancel each other out (remember photons interfere only with themselves) the middle path that can‚Äôt get cancelled out emerges. Since all frequencies have different interference points they all shift slightly from each other seperating the colours.

author: @kingames1
textdisplay:
I'm no expert and please correct me if I'm wrong, but wouldn't having your redundancy being a single line mean that your code will be repeated?
So for example let's say the redundancy code is 1010
If we have a full code that can all be restored from that, the code can be:
(1010)(1010)(1010)(1010) (the brackets are to explain it better)
Which means, that the file stored on the disc will be repeated, and, the file will also be repeated
So if 1010 stands forüü©üü¶, then the whole code will be üü©üü¶üü©üü¶üü©üü¶üü©üü¶

Yes it looks like the pixel resolution has reduced, that‚Äôs because we have removed the ‚Äúhigh frequency components‚Äù of the image, aka the sharp edges. We could now represent the blurred image with fewer pixels without losing any information, as the number of sample points required is set by the highest frequency component in the image. This is a really useful trick for reducing computation time for computer vision algorithms, e.g. SIFT

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
5:06
actually, calculating this product by hand is quite nice and easy with some clever tricks involving how quaternion multiplication relates to the 3d dot and cross products
instead of expanding out (a+bi+cj+dk)(xi+yj+zk)(a-bi-cj-dk),
do it in this form instead: (s+b)(v)(s-b)
where s is the scalar part of your quaternion, and b is the imaginary part (linear combination of i, j and k)

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
hint:
the product of two "pure imaginary" quaternions, q1 and q2, is equal to -q1‚ãÖq2 + q1√óq2
where ‚ãÖ and √ó are both the familiar 3d dot and cross products

this equality doesn't appear out of thin air either, the stuff that defines quaternion multiplication (ij = k, ji = -k, i^2 = j^2 = k^2 = -1 etc) are precisely the same things that define the dot and cross products of 3d vectors

by saying that x = [1, 0, 0], y = [0, 1, 0] and z = [0, 0, 1], we can demonstrate this:
ij = k | x√óy = z
ji = -k | y√óx = -z
jk = i | y√óz = x

i^2 = -1 | -x‚ãÖx = -1 (same for j and k)

of course, this correspondence works for all imaginary quaternions and 3d vectors
when 2 imaginary quats are orthogonal to each other, their product is just their cross product because the dot product is 0
and you can probably guess what happens when they're parallel

author: @2fifty533
textdisplay:
(s - b)(v)(s+b) = (sv - bv)(s+b)
= (sv - b√óv + b‚ãÖv)(s+b)
= s^2v + sv√ób - sv‚ãÖb - s(b√óv) - (b√óv)√ób + (b√óv)‚ãÖb + sb‚ãÖv + b(b‚ãÖv)
= s^2v + 2(sb√óv) - (b√óv)√ób + b(b‚ãÖv)

and we're done! all that took was 4 or 5 relatively short steps, you can now plug this formula into a program and it works fine
(admittedly I did miss out a couple steps involving removing terms that cancel each other out, but this is trivial if you know the basics of how cross and dot products work and interact)

author: @meinsmart6415
textdisplay:
A line rotates around a point, the latter being element of the line. this rotation describes a plane.
0D 1D(rotating) 2D

1 dimension higher:
a plane rotates around a line, the latter being part of the plane. this describes a space.
1D 2D(rotating) 3D

next level (it cannot be imagined, but is a mere analogy of the former 2 rotations):
a space, eg a sphere, rotates around a disc, the latter being element of the sphere, it is the disc inside the equator. this rotation describes a hypersphere (does it?).
2D 3D(rotating) 4D
Can this be calculated and shown with quaternions?

author: @Jay-kb7if
textdisplay:
would love a response to get this straight:
-rotation is 3d, and can only rotate in 3 dof so eulor or any crude way to move from 1 point to another in 3d is to zig zag, quaternions are a linear uni-approach
-you can't actually rotate along an axis that intersects between the 3 planes, but qauternions allow you to do this.
-people get confused because of local and global space, and that the way they work is to a sphere moves independently from global space and then locally rotates (bit of a bda explanation but you get the jist).
-hyperbolically, ther is no rotation, just stretching, but the equation perfectlly stretching in one direction has diametric "in-stretching" to give the illusion of rotation.
-people are thinking of vectors and not about the whole sphere

author: @masterclash9959
textdisplay:
Here‚Äôs a small experiment to see how Gimbal Lock works:

Place your phone face up on a surface, with the charging port facing you. We‚Äôll define the phone‚Äôs center as the origin, right of the phone to be positive x, up from the phone as positive y, and away from the phone (the side with no charging point) as positive z.

When I say ‚Äúrotate clockwise‚Äù around an axis, that will mean facing the positive axis from the origin and rotating clockwise from that perspective.

First, rotate your phone 90 degrees cw around the y-axis. Your phone‚Äôs charging port should now be facing to the right.

Now rotate your phone 180 degrees around the z-axis. Your phone should now be upside down with the port still facing to the left.

Alright, keeping that in mind, we‚Äôll start again.

This time, your first step will instead be to rotate your phone 180 degrees around the z-axis. Your phone should be face-down and have it‚Äôs charging port facing you.

Next, rotate your phone 90 degrees around the y-axis. Your phone will now be face down with its port facing to the right.

Notice how in both scenarios, we used the same two steps, only in a different order. However, in the first situation, the charging point was to the left while it‚Äôs to the right in the second one.

This phenomenon is known as Gimbal Lock, and is significant because this type of rotation is how 3D rotation matrices work.

Quarternons are necessary here to keep these steps consistent.

author: @angeldude101
textdisplay:
If you're in 2D, then you can interpret quaternions as being not an axis through the origin, but a point on a sphere. Unfortunately, rotations around these points wouldn't look like rotation that you're familiar with, but if the axis was through the origin, it would be normal rotation, and the closer you are to the origin, the more like Euclidean rotation it becomes. This could be described by two of the quaternion components being infinitesimally small, though at that point, why not just throw universal inverses out the window and say that those two basis vectors actually have a magnitude of 0 despite being non-zero. This is something that some mathematicians might scoff at or become horrified by, but it's actually used in a number system called the "dual numbers," which are to flat euclidean space what complex numbers are to spherical and elliptic space.

Because i, j, and k are stupid names, I'm instead going to use dÃÇxÃÇ, ≈∑dÃÇ, and xÃÇ≈∑. You can then represent any 2D point (x, y) as xÃÇ≈∑ + x≈∑dÃÇ + ydÃÇxÃÇ (If this feels backwards, that'd because points aren't actually the primitive in this space, and they're actually built from a more fundamental element.) This is very similar to a quaternion, but with two of the imaginary components (the two including a factor of dÃÇ) squaring to 0 rather than -1. These can also be exponentiated just like quaternions, but the different squares makes things slightly different. Namely, a rotation of Œ∏ around a normalized point PÃÇ (normalized meaning that |PÃÇ|¬≤ = 1) can be described as exp(Œ∏PÃÇ/2) = cos(Œ∏/2) + PÃÇsin(Œ∏/2).

If you're in 3D, then you can't rotate around arbitrary points unless you also have a plane parallel to the desired rotation. In general, 3D rotations happen around lines, which have 6 degrees of freedom. They can be represented analogously to points in terms of the basis dÃÇxÃÇ, dÃÇ≈∑, dÃÇ·∫ë, xÃÇ≈∑, ·∫ëxÃÇ, and ≈∑·∫ë. The components of these actually correspond to the Pl√ºcker coordinates of the line. The dÃÇxÃÇ, dÃÇ≈∑, and xÃÇ≈∑ components also have nearly identical meaning as in the 2D case, while the xÃÇ≈∑, ·∫ëxÃÇ, and ≈∑·∫ë have nearly identical meaning to the i, j, and k basis quaternions, though not necessarily in that order depending on who you ask. These Pl√ºcker coordinates form a 6D subspace of an 8D system called "dual quaternions," which can represent arbitrary rotations around arbitrary axes in 3D, along with screw motions and translations. Exponentiating these is a little more complicated than the 2D case, since the input might not actually be a valid line. In that case, the result is not just a rotation around an axis, but a screw motion around and along said axis.

What I've given here is based on Projective Geometric Algebra, which can describe translations, rotations, reflections, point-reflections, and any composition of them in N dimensions. It also has dedicated separate objects for planes, lines, and points, each of which can also be described as some composition of orthogonal reflections.


P.S. Most sources will use e‚ÇÄ, e‚ÇÅ, e‚ÇÇ, and e‚ÇÉ instead of dÃÇ, xÃÇ, ≈∑,and ·∫ë respectively. My use of xÃÇ, ≈∑,and ·∫ë should be fairly self explanatory, while dÃÇ I chose due to being related to the distance of a plane from the origin, along with differentials in the dual-number formulation of calculus, and of course the names of "dual numbers" and "dual quaternions."

author: @isnogod.science
textdisplay:
A stupid question from some old guy who is "out of business" (never worked in the field after study almost 50 years ago): why are the four dimensions not all interconnected with the cross product, something like
e x i = j ?
Why is the "real axis" direction not included in the cross product family?

author: @angeldude101
textdisplay:
Because the cross product takes 2 lines and gives an orthogonal line, while the quaternion product takes two rotations and gives the rotation that is the composition of the two inputs. Their connection is that if the two lines are treated as 180¬∞ rotations, then the cross product gives the axis that their composition as rotations would have.

Alternatively, you can treat the inputs as mirror planes. Their product would compose their reflections giving a quaternion that rotates by twice the angle between them, while their "cross product" gives their line of intersection, scaled by the sine of the angle between them; this line also being the axis of rotation that the full product would give.

If i understand correctly then the sphere we end up with is a tangent of the 4D hypershpere at a certain location. Traversing the hypersphere results in different tangents and therefore different spheres. Multiplying this with the inverse of the hypersphere again ensures that certain properties (volume) are maintained. From this I have two questions that might help my intuition.

1) A tangent line touches a circle at one point, both for the line and the circle, how does this extend to the tangent of the hypersphere? Is there a point on the tangent sphere that 'touches' the hypersphere, if so, what is it?

2) If the Quaternion describes a specific point on the unit hypersphere, how can we logically interpret it's inverse. E.g. How would we do this with a 3 dimensional sphere, what would the inverse of a point there be? If I understand correctly the inverse 'P of P is defined so that P * 'P = I where I is identity, what in this case is Identity?

I hope my questions make sense, since I have no idea whether my assumptions are true. Anyway I would love some input on the matter. Fascinating topic this is. Thanks alot!

author: @angeldude101
textdisplay: Question two is way easier to answer treating the quaternions as 3D rotations than as points on a hypersphere. The inverse of a rotation is literally just a rotation in the opposite direction. Rotating Œ∏¬∞ around an axis, and then rotating -Œ∏¬∞ around that same axis just gives you a 0¬∞ rotation, back where you started. That 0¬∞ rotation is also the identity.

author: @alienrenders
textdisplay: I have my own Unreal Engine branch where I implemented Dual Quaternion math for mesh skinning (move bones and the vertices follow). Dual Quaternions also help retain volume. With matrix interpolation, you get the candy wrapper effect when you twist (center between two bones goes to a single point). With Dual Quaternion, the rotation retains its volume (points rotate around a cylinder for tube like twist). Unfortunately, it tends to bulge for bends. I understand the math, but I still don't fully grasp why quaternions work when rotating a point.

author: @Ch1n4Sailor
textdisplay: I really like your videos, but now your mixing apples & oranges.... In Computer Science, hard stat sciences, there is NO such thing as Correlation. Correlation is a SOCIAL SCIENCE factor. And While in General, doing probabilities with correlation factored in probably will (most likely) yield the more accurate results, there is no such thing in Computer Science.  It's like the old expression about "putting the beer in the same aisle as the diapers," because there's  statistically a higher probability that if someone's (a male) shopping for baby Diapers, and they see Beer in the same Aisle, ODDS are they will ALSO buy Beer!   That's CORRELATION!

author: @nienke7713
textdisplay:
coin flips and dice rolls are only independent if you use a different coin/die every time. If a die or coin is weighted to favour particular results, then you should expect the chance of getting the same outcome again to be larger, and after every flip/roll you can update your expectations based on the previous results, and the more results you've seen, the more accurate your expectations tend to be.
No coin/die is perfect, so even if it's not purposely weighted, it might have an accidental bias to a certain result, and if you keep using the same coin/die, then it would be more sensible to expect results in line with prior results than to expect results differing from prior results.

author: @raconteurhermit1533
textdisplay:
From bayes rule, Most important use is to calculate Probability of Cause given Effect
P(cause|effect) = P(effect|cause)*P(cause)/P(effect)
Since most of the scenarios in any experiment or simulation ,its easy to get value of effect by applying cause ,i.e P(effect|cause) can be easily calculated by actual experiment
Now using Bayes theorm one can calculate P(cause|effect)


An example
Question:You are working on your laptop, and you hear a whirring noise from it, whenever you boot it. You go to a technician and he tells you that 80% of the cases of laptop repair that come to him, have the same problem of whirring noise. You assume that the issue is from your hard-drive, and you read online that 20% of all laptop issues are hard-drive related, while the problem of getting a whirring noise from the laptop on boot from a hard-drive related issue is 50%. Given this information, you calculate the probability that you have a hard-drive related issue in your laptop ?
Answer:This is a simple application of bayes rule.
Here whirring noise is an ‚ÄúEffect‚Äù or symptom,and Hard-Drive related issues serve as a probable ‚ÄúCause‚Äù. Then P(cause) = 20% and P(effect) = 80%, and P(effect|cause) = 50%. From bayes rule,
P(cause|effect) =
P(effect|cause)*P(cause)/P(effect) = 0.5*0.2/0.8 = ‚Öõ

author: @chaorrottai
textdisplay:
It's a math artefact. It's like negative numbers: they don't exist oustide of reletavism. In reality, there are no negative numbers, only positive quantities in antagonistic vectors.

Also, while it may not be a software glitch or even a hardware glitch, it could be an artifact of binary float multiplication and rounding. Even using an arbitrary precision library is still going to invlove rounding, especially when using the sin,cos and tan function because: just because your personal code isn't rounded, doesn't mean the internal constants being referenced aren't.

author: @DavidJohnsonFromSeattle
textdisplay: Okay, so the reason the infinite integral changes later is because the fourier transform of sinc is the rect function and when you multiply the sincs in the infinite integral and evaluate, you can get the same result by convoluted the rects the same number of times and evaluating at origin, which gives 1 up until some nth iteration (when including normalization, yadda yadda). Hopefully, when this video gets recommended to me again a year later and I have forgotten what is going on here, I will see my comment and instantly figure it out.

author: @Lighthouse_out_of_order
textdisplay:
Kudos for the effort, but I'm afraid you did this wrong. You evaluated the content (vids/presentation etc.) by peer review of mathematicians. But the true criteria should be how ùò≠ùò¢ùò∫ùòÆùò¶ùòØ (like myself) who tried to learn the subject through said content managed to get it - if at all, and how bored/ transfixed they were.
With the topmost winner, I ran into a problem at the very beginning: the crystal patterns are have too many and too dense atoms and bonds, I was unable to figure out what the structures were and how do they differ between the crystals. Since it is crucial to the rest of the presentation, I just couldn't get it. Fail.

Peer review is fine to verify the content is correct, and also to scale the content as to how advanced the topic presented is (obviously it is harder to explain the more advanced stuff, so this is an important criterion as well). But peer review means absolutely nothing to the question of how good is the explanation.

textdisplay: As a first year student, it is very discouraging to see how little there is of both motivation and clarity in my math lessons.
